She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a small cafeteria, by purchasing the necessary sugar, coffee, salt, and rice, as well as investing in a freezer. She will use the profits to purchase plates for her home as well as invest in the education of her child by purchasing school supplies and a computer. Additionally, she would like to take her family out to eat ice cream more often. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy sugar, coffee, rice, salt, and a freezer.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr: Née en 1954, D. Jacqueline est mariée à CODJIA Joseph et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Jacqueline vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari au quartier Habitat à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Jacqueline habite ce quartier depuis une dizaine d'année. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Pour assurer ses besoins, Jacqueline vend divers produits (mayonnaise, lait, pâtes alimentaires, savons, etc.) dans sa boutique. Parallèlement à cette activité, Jacqueline vend également des boissons. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Jacqueline achète ses produits. Jacqueline a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit de ALIDé, et l'a bien remboursé. Jacqueline souhaite rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Jacqueline sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Jacqueline D. was born in 1954, and is married to Joseph Codjia. She is the mother of two children. She lives with her husband and her two children, both of whom have been to school, in the Habitat neighborhood of Cotonou, Bénin's economic capital. Jacqueline has lived in this neighborhood about ten years. Together she and her husband pay for household expenses. To meet her needs, Jacqueline sells various items (mayonnaise, milk, pasta, soap) in her store. Additionally, she sells drinks. She buys her products at Dantokpa, Bénin's international marketplace. Jacqueline has repaid one previous loan from ALIDé. She wants to increase her sales to meet customer demand, and this is why she is seeking a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products (preserves, pasta, soap, mayonnaise, milk, etc.) and drinks.

loans.name: Raul

texts.es: Raúl tiene 52 años, vive con su esposa y uno de sus 3 hijos  en su casa propia. Desde hace más de 30 años elabora faldas típicas de su región, como: faldas plisadas y de mil rayas, en un taller que tiene en el interior de su casa. En ocasiones su esposa o algún familiar lo ayudan en el taller, pero cuando tiene muchos pedidos, contrata los servicios de 2 personas más. Esta muy contento con el trabajo que realiza, ya que desde niño le enseñaron esta labor, en donde pudo disfrutar de momentos agradables con su familia. La experiencia que tiene lo ha ayudado a hacer mejor su trabajo y eso ha favorecido para tener clientes, por tal motivo desea mas adelante renovar su maquina de coser. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, por tanto se compromete a ser responsable en sus pagos, además considera que el aporte que recibirá, le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, invertirá en la compra de telas, hilos y lonas, que son insumos necesarios para la confección de sus prendas.
texts.en:
Raúl, 52, lives with his wife and one of his three children in his own home. For over 30 years he has manufactured in a workshop installed in his home skirts typical of his region such as: pleated skirts and thousand stripe skirts. Sometimes his wife or a relative helps him in the shop but when he has many pending orders he hires two employees. He enjoys his work very much because he learned these skills as a little boy and he enjoyed pleasant moments with his family. His experience has made it possible for him to do his work better which has led to an increase in customers. He needs later on to improve his sewing machine. This is his first loan with MFP and he pledges to repay promptly. He realizes that the influx of capital will be very useful for his business’ success. He will use the requested funds to buy fabric, thread and canvas which are required raw ingredients to make his clothing articles.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread and canvas.

loans.name: Tres De Noviembre Cumbe(Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El bankito 3 de Noviembre esta conformado por 13 señoras luchadoras que siempre estan en la busqueda de mejores oportunidades para sus familias viven el la parroquia Cumbe, esta parroquia se encuentra ubicada al sur del cantón Cuenca. Limita al norte con la parroquia Tarqui, al sur con las parroquias Jima del cantón Sígsig y la periferia cantonal de Girón, al este con las parroquias Quingeo y San José de Raranga del cantón Sígsig, y al oeste con la parroquia Victoria del Portete. Como principal actividad económica sobresale la agricultura con la producción de maíz, papas, fréjol y habas,  la ganadería es importante también  por una excelente producción lechera, y gran parte de la población joven se traslada  diariamente a Cuenca donde realizan otras actividades como obreros de fábricas, elaboración de  artesanías, empleados en actividades de comercio, servicios y principalmente como trabajadores de la construcción. 

La señora María  Auxiliadora  es una  mujer de  48 años vive con dos de sus hijos menores  de 15 y 12 años que estudian en un colegio de  la localidad, sus otros cuatro hijos casados y viven independientes. Su esposo es albañil y con el sacrificio de mucho tiempo ha logrado construir su casa propia ubicada en la comunidad Cumbe.

Es una de las socias fundadoras del banco comunal pues ya lleva quince años en él motivada por una compañera del barrio  donde formaron un grupo  que se desintegró,  luego formo este nuevo grupo de mujeres luchadoras y emprendedoras. María Auxiliadora  es comerciante de animales compra y vende cuyes y gallinas en las ferias de Cumbe y en la feria libre de Cuenca, esta actividad le ha permitido irse superando económicamente  ya lleva en ella  20 años  trabajando  los días miércoles y sábados, y los de mas de días se dedica a cuidar de su ganado y la leche que obtiene la vende en los carros lecheros. Ahora con su crédito va a comprar más cuyes y gallinas  para revenderlos.

Su meta incrementar su negocio cada día y llegar  a comprarse un vehiculo.

La señora Luz Fernández vive en la comunidad 3 de noviembre que pertenece a la parroquia Cumbe, tiene 60 años de edad enviudó hace 18 años su difunto esposo  falleció  en un accidente de tránsito,  con él concibieron cuatro  hijos que ahora son adultos y   casados, vive en su casa propia con una de sus hijas que le hace compañía y comparte los gastos del hogar.

Luz se dedica a la agricultura siembra maíz, papas, hortalizas, etc., tiene ganado vacuno y vende su leche a los carros lecheros, también se dedica  a la cría de cuyes y pollos,  nos comenta que se encuentra en el bankito desde  sus inicios  es decir hace 15 años, los créditos le han beneficiado en su negocio de compra y venta de animales, con su nuevo crédito comprará pollos, cuyes y alimento para su crianza, así como también semillas de maíz, fréjol, arveja entre otras.

Tiene como meta seguir trabajando mientras tenga salud.
texts.en:
The 3 de Noviembre Village Bank is made up of 13 hard-working women who are always looking for better opportunities for their families. They live in the Cumbe parish, which is located in the south of the canton of Cuenca. It is bordered in the north by Tarqui parish, in the south by Jima parish of Sígsig canton and the edge of Girón canton, to the east by the parishes of Quingeo and San José in Sígsig canton, and in the west by the parish of Victoria del Portete. The leading economic activity in the area is agriculture, and the most important products are corn, potatoes, beans and milk. A large proportion of the younger population travels daily to Cuenca to work as factory employees, handicraft artisans, store employees, service workers and above all, construction workers. María Auxiliadora is 48 years old and lives with her two younger children, aged 15 and 12, who attend a nearby school. Her other four children are married and independent. Her husband is a mason, and through many years of sacrifice, he was able to build the family's own home in the Cumbe community. María Auxiliadora was one of the founding members of the communal bank, and she has been with the bank for fifteen years. She was inspired by a neighbor who belonged to an earlier group in the neighborhood which broke up. Later, this new group of hard-working and enterprising women was formed. María Auxiliadora's business is buying and selling animals. She deals in guinea pigs and hens at the Cumbe markets and at Cuenca's public market. This activity has allowed her to advance economically. She has worked for 20 years in the markets on Wednesdays and Saturdays, and on the other days, she takes care of her animals. She also keeps cows, whose milk she sells to mobile distributors. With the current loan, she will buy more guinea pigs and hens to resell. Her goal is to expand her business day by day and reach the point where she can buy herself a vehicle. Luz Fernández lives in the "3 de Noviembre" community of the Cumbe parish. She is 60 years old and was widowed 18 years ago when her husband was killed in a traffic accident. The couple had four children, who are now grown and married. Luz lives in her own house with one of her daughters who keeps her company and shares the household expenses. Luz works in agriculture; she grows corn, potatoes and a variety of vegetables. She also keeps cattle, selling the milk to mobile distributors. In addition, she raises guinea pigs and chickens. She tells us that she has been a member of the communal bank since its beginnings, that is, for the past 15 years. The loans have been beneficial for her business of buying and selling animals. With the new loan, she will buy chickens, guinea pigs and feed for her animals, as well as seeds for corn, beans, peas and other crops. Her goal is to continue working as long as her health permits.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying guinea pigs, chickens, animal feed, and seeds for corn, beans, peas, etc.

loans.name: Integridad 1,2,3 Group

texts.en:
Ana is the coordinator of her group La Integridad (The Integrity), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the Samana peninsula, a lush, rugged isthmus with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, rented structure as a single mother with three children.

Ana is excited to be taK. her first loan with Esperanza and she is excited to invest in her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her ambulatory business selling underwear by travelling to the main market in the Capital to purchase underwear and then bring it back to her community to sell at a profit. She will use the profits to purchase medicine, school supplies, and a computer for her daughters. She also would like to save toward sealing the concrete blocks of her rented home and eventually buying it. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy underwear to sell.

loans.name: Bayana Group

texts.fr:
Le Groupe de solidarité "BAYANA" est crée en octobre 2002 en même temps que le Banc Villageois qui porte le même nom. Il est composé de 08 femmes toutes issues du même village et ont en moyenne 35 ans et son mère au moins de 4 enfants. 

Elle mènent différentes activités à savoir la vente de fruits, la vente de légumes et la vente de noix d'acajous. 

pour augmenter leur capacité d'investissement afin d'accroître leur revenus financiers, le groupe a décidé d'intégrer l'institution de micro-crédit CAURIE-MF il y a de cela 08 ans et ont pratiquement toutes eu 17 fois a bénéficier de crédit. Leur dynamisme et leur bravoure ont fait qu'elles ont un bon niveau d'épargne, environs 65% de leur encours de prêt. 

La présidente du groupe, Oudé M. est âgée de 41 ans, elle mariée et mère de 09 enfants et tutrice de 04 autres qui lui sont confiés par des proches et parents. Elle est vendeuse de fruits et légumes et son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'augmenter sa capacité d'investissement afin d'avoir plus de bénéfices et pouvoir faire face aux différents besoins de sa famille. 

Les femmes, en plus des remboursements régulier de leurs prêts qu'elles font, des épargnes mensuelles qu'elles versent, participent aux différentes charges de leurs familles respectives.
texts.en:
The « BAYANA » solidarity group was formed in October 2002, at the same time as the « Banc Villageois » that shares its name. It is comprised of eight women from the same village, with an average age of 35 and having at least four children. They run various businesses, such as selling fruit, selling vegetables, and selling cashews. In order to increase their investment capacity and thus their income, the group decided eight years ago to join the microfinance institution CAURIE-MF. Nearly every one of them has received seventeen loans. Their energy and bravery has led to a good amount of savings, approximately 65% of their outstanding loans. The president of the group, Oudé M., is 41 years old, married and mother of nine children. She also takes care of four other children who have been given to her by friends and relatives. She sells fruits and vegetables. Her new loan would allow her to increase her investment capital in order to have more income and meet various family needs. The women, in addition to paying regularly on their loans and making monthly savings deposits, help to pay the various expenses of their respective families.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the group's ability to self-finance

loans.name: Un Futuro Mejor Group

texts.en:
Ana is the coordinator of her group Un Futuro Mejor (A Better Future), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the Samana peninsula, a lush, rugged isthmus with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a a single mother with her two children.

Ana is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing and jewelry, by travelling to the capital to purchase skirts, pants, shirts, underwear and necklaces and then selling them in her community at a profit. She will use the profits to invest in her home by laying down a concrete floor, a real hygienic and health benefit, as well as purchasing food and school supplies for her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy skirts, pants, shirts, underwear, and necklaces to sell.

loans.name: Dianké

texts.fr: Dianké Y. est une femme de 52 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de TEREMBASSE depuis 4 ans et demi et a 9 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Son nouveau prêt lui permettra de mieux développer son activité de vente d'huile de palme et de balais faits à base de feuilles de palmier. Cette activité lui a permis de réaliser des bénéfices jusqu'à s'équiper en meuble et achetant un lit en bois. Elle participe aux dépenses de la famille en assurant pleinement le marché quotidien.
texts.en:
Dianké Y. is 52 years old, married and the mother of three children. She has been a member of the TEREMBASSE « Banc Villageois » loan group for 4 ½ years and has been granted nine successive loans, all reimbursed without problems. Her new loan will enable her to develop her business selling palm oil and brooms made of palm fronds. This activity has so far provided income she used to buy home furnishings and a wooden bed. She contributes towards family expenses by funding daily purchases at the market.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen and promote her commercial activity

loans.name: Un Nuevo Esfuerzo Group

texts.en:
Teresa is the coordinator of her group Un Nuevo Esfuerzo (A New Endeavour), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the Samana peninsula, a lush, rugged isthmus with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and their five children.

Teresa is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling seafood, by purchasing fish, shrimp, and crab to sell from her seafood stand in her home. She will use the profits for her children by purchasing medicine, school supplies, and clothing. Additionally, she would like to finish constructing her home while finding a separate location for her seafood stand. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy fish, shrimp, and crab.

loans.name: Los Tajibos Group

texts.es:
Banco D. Emprendimiento: LOS TAJIBOS  se encuentra ubicado en el Barrio Palmira, ubicado en la calle Las Ameritas, el B.E. esta en su 2DO ciclo, compuesto por 10 personas, Se fundo el  24 D. Noviembre  del 2009, a iniciativa D. un grupo D. señoras

Como PRESIDENTA tenemos a la Señora Aída, TESORERA la  Sr. David  y SECRETARIA la Sra. Maria del Carmen en el grupo hay señoras que se dedican a la  venta D. Pastelería ,Taxista ,Aire Acondicionado, Productos Veterinaria, Colchones, Enfermería, Cosméticos, Carpintería y otros.

Las reuniones se llevan acabo los días jueves a horas   14:00 PM en la casa D. la señora Aída. Los nuevos clientes que ingresaron al Banco D. Emprendimiento, están conforme D. trabajar con Emprender debido a que dentro D. la capacitación del  B.E. LOS TAJIBOS  ,se les estableció una proyección D. sus ahorros a la finalización  del ciclo  en la cual  aprenderán a ahorrar  y compartir con sus amigas cada 14 días, con el dinero del credito comprara mercaderia al por mayor y asi surtir sus mercaderia y poder incrementar su capital D. trabajo. 

La Sra. AIDA (Presidenta) venD. cosméticos D. manera ambulante  en diferentes mercados populares y sus zonas, a parte D. esta actividad es ama D. casa  en sus tiempos libres y  le va bien el negocio. En el banco comunal ha aprendido a ahorrar, a quererse y valorarse como persona, se siente útil con lo que le enseñan en las capacitaciones. El sueño D. la señora Aída  es tener su propia vitrina, su tienda D. negocio y  progresar en la vida con su negocio.

Todas las socias son personas responsables y trabajadoras que desean mejorar la calidad D. viva D. toda su familia, estan muy agradecidos con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The entrepreneurial bank group Los Tajibos is located in Barrio Palmira on Las Ameritas Street. This group of 10 people is now in their second cycle. They were established 24 November 2009 by a group of older women. Aída is the president, David is the treasurer, and Maria del Carmen is the secretary. In the group, there are women who sell pastries, a taxi driver, air conditioning vendors, veterinary product vendors, mattress vendors, nurses, cosmetics vendors, carpenters and others. Their meetings take place Thursdays at 14:00 in Aída's house. New clients who enter the bank group work with Emprender as long as they undergo training with the group. They establish their projected savings at the end of the cycle, and learn to save and share with their friends every 14 days. With the loan, they will buy wholesale merchandise to stock their businesses and be able to increase their working capital. Aída, the president, travels and sells cosmetics in different popular markets and neighborhoods. AsiD. from this job, she is a housewife in her spare time, and her business is going well. In the communal bank, she has learned to save, and to love and value herself as a person. She feels useful with what they teach her in training. Aída's dream is to have her own showcase, her own store, and progress through life with her business. All of the members are responsible, hardworking people who hope to improve the quality of life for their families. They are very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for having enough faith in them to loan them credit.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Diariétou

texts.fr: Diariétou M. est âgée de 60 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 14 ans et demi et a 15 fois de suite reçu de crédit et n'a jamais eu de difficulté de remboursement. Elle est vendeuse d'huile de palme et son nouveau prêt lui permettra de renforcer son activité et d'augmenter ses revenus financiers. Son objectif est de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille, de subvenir à ses besoins personnels et d'assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Dianké M. is 60 years old, married and the mother of five children. She has been a member of the local « Banc Villageois » loan group for 14 ½ years and has been granted 15 successive loans, all reimbursed without problems. She retails palm oil, and her new loan will enable her to reinforce her activity and increase her revenues. Her objective is to participate in the improvement of her family’s living conditions, meet her personal needs and ensure her children’s schooling.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Reinforce and promote her activity selling palm oil

loans.name: Freddy

texts.es: Freddy tiene todo el espíritu de salir adelante, pues siempre le ha gustado su negocio. Su actividad económica es la venta de comida y un kiosco. Por lo que siempre ha trabajado por proporcionarles a sus 2 hijos lo necesario. El dio inicio a esta actividad hace 3 años, el ha logrado crecer gradualmente, por lo que la mayoría de sus clientes son amigos de Freddy además esto le ha generado mucha experiencia en el negocio. Es por eso que sueña con poder mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda. Este financiamiento es para la compra de materia prima necesaria para su local.
texts.en:
Freddy has all the spirit he needs to get ahead because he loves his store. He sells food and snacks in his stand. He has always worked to give his 2 children what they need. He started this business 3 years ago and it has managed to grow gradually because most of his clients are his friends. He has developed a lot of experience with his business. For all of these reasons he dreams of being able to improve his home. This loan will be to purchase supplies for his business.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies

loans.name: Tombong

texts.fr: Tombong M. est une femme de 30 ans, elle est mariée et mère d'un enfants en charge. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 8ans et a 16 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit. Elle est vendeuse d'huile de palme et de balais traditionnels fabriqués à partir de feuilles de palmier. Elle achète la marchandise dans sa localité et l'expatrie dans les autres régions du pays pour son écoulement en l'occurrence à Dakar. Elle souhaite participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille, de satisfaire ses besoins personnels et payer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Tombong M. is 30 years old, married and the mother of one child under her care. She has been a member of the local « Banc Villageois » loan group for 8 years and has been granted 16 successive loans. She retails palm oil and traditional brooms made from palm fronds. She gets her merchandise locally and delivers it to other regions of the country for resale, in particular Dakar. She wishes to participate in improving her family’s living conditions, satisfy her personal needs and pay for her children’s schooling.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and resell 110 liters palm oil and three packs of brooms

loans.name: Amistad De Palmira Group

texts.es:
Banco de Emprendimiento:  AMISTAD DE PALMIRA  se encuentra ubicado en el Barrio Palmira, ubicado en la calle Las Ameritas, el B.E. esta en su 3er ciclo, compuesto por 10 personas, Se fundo el  12 de Mayo  del 2009, a iniciativa de un grupo de señoras.

Como PRESIDENTA esta la Sra. JULIA, tenemos a la señora, CONSUELO como TESORERA  y la  Sra. MARIA es la SECRETARIA, en el grupo hay señoras que se dedican a la  venta de  panadería ,jugos  de frutas ,abarrotes,ropa, dulces asaditos ,empanadas y comida. Las reuniones se llevan acabo los días jueves a horas   11:30 PM en la casa de la señora Maria. Los nuevos clientes que ingresaron al grupo están contentos de trabajar con Emprender debido a que dentro de la capacitación del  B.E.  AMISTAD DE PALMIRA, se les estableció una proyección de sus ahorros a la finalización  del ciclo  en la cual  aprenderán a ahorrar  y compartir con sus amigas cada 14 días.

La Sra. JULIA (Presidenta) vende ropa de manera ambulante  en diferentes mercados populares, a parte de esta actividad se dedica a cuidar a sus nietos en sus tiempos libres y  le va bien el negocio. En el banco comunal ha aprendido a ahorrar, a quererse y valorarse como persona, siente útil con lo que le enseñan en las capacitaciones. El sueño de la señora  Julia es tener su propia tienda, y asi poder aportar en  los estudios  de sus nietos  y progresar en la vida con su negocio, con el dinero del credito comprara mercaderia ropa de temporada y asi poder incrementar su capital de trabajo.

Todas las socias son personas responsables y trabajadoras que desean mejorar la calidad de vida y de toda su familia, estan muy agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The community bank AMISTAD DE PALMIRA is located in Barrio Palmira on Las Ameritas street. The bank is in its 3rd cycle and is made up of 10 people. It was formed on May 12 of 2009 by a group of women. The president is JULIA, CONSUELO is the treasurer, and MARIA is the secretary. In the group there are women sho sell bread, fruit juice, groceries, clothes, candy, roasted meat, empanadas and food. The meetings are held on Thursdays at 11:30 p.m. at Maria's house. The new clients that entered the group are happy to work with Emprender because the communal bank AMISTAD DE PALMIRA has a training that established a savings projection at the end of the cycle in which they will learn to save and share with their friends every 14 days. JULIA ( the president) sells clothes as a street vendor in different popular markets. With this activity she takes care of her grandchildren in her free time and business is going well. In the communal bank she has learned to save, to love herself and to value herself as a person. Julia's dream is to have her own store and thus be able to pay for her grandchildrens' education and progress in life with her business. With the money from the loan she will purchase merchandise, such as seasonal clothing, an in this way increase her working capital. All of the members are responsible and hardworking people who want to improve their and their whole families' quality of life. They are very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust they have put in them by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Prosperidad 1 Group

texts.en:
C. is the coordinator of her group Prosperidad (Prosperity), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the Samana peninsula, a lush, rugged isthmus with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and three children.

C. is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing, beauty products, perfumes and accessories, by purchasing more merchandise. She will use the profits to save toward her dream of one day opening a restaurant. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy clothing, beauty products, perfumes and accessories to sell.

loans.name: María Francisca

texts.es:
La señora  María Cárdenas es una mujer muy dinámica tiene 58 años de edad, separada de su cónyuge porque la maltrataba mucho, con el concibió cinco hijos entre las edades 30 y 22 años, su primera  hija es madre soltera de tres niños, vive con su segunda hija casada con quien comparten los gastos del hogar y sus dos hijos solteros que trabajan tanto para sus gastos como para apoyar en casa ya que aun no tienen casa propia.

 Es socia del bankito La Paz  hace doce años y fue invitada por una socia que ya falleció, este banco se encuentra en la urbe de la  ciudad de Cuenca donde una vez fue el asentamiento de los Tomebamba. Está a 2535 metros sobre el nivel del mar y es la capital de la provincia del Azuay, es además la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador.

María  elabora y vende tejidos realizados a mano arte que aprendió de una comadre, además vende inciensos   hace tres  años, trabaja cinco días a la semana porque el resto cuida  de sus nietos. Con el crédito solicitado  va a comprar hilos para elaborar sus tejidos, así como incienso y romero para vender.  Su sueño es comprarse un terreno para poder construir su casa.
texts.en:
María Cárdenas is a dynamic 58-year-old. She is separated because her spouse mistreated her a lot; they had five children together who range in ages from 30 to 22 years. She lives with her second daughter who is married and shares household expenses and her two single sons who work both to meet their own personal expenses as well as to support household expenses since they don’t yet have their own homes. Her oldest daughter is a single mother of three children. She has been a member of the La Paz communal bank; she was invited to join by a member who is since deceased. This bank is located in greater Cuenca where once the Tomebamba (a former city-state in the Inca federation) settled. It is located 2535 meters above sea level and is the capital of Azuay province; in addition, it is Ecuador’s third most important city. María manufactures and sells hand-made woven articles that she learned how to make from a comadre (The name by which the godfather and godmother address the mother of their godson or daughter, and by which she also always addresses the godmother); three years ago she also began to sell incense. She is asking for funding to buy thread for her weaving as well as incense and rosemary to sell. She dreams with being able to buy a lot on which to build her house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy thread, incense and rosemary.

loans.name: Cristo Viene Group

texts.en:
Ana is the coordinator of her group Cristo Viene (Christ is Coming), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the Samana peninsula, a lush, rugged isthmus with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with husband and four children.

Ana is excited to be taK. her fifth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business of selling deodorants, creams, perfumes and makeup in her community. She will use the profits to invest in medicine and school supplies for the children, to add a room to her home, and to purchase a scooter to help her get around town. Her long term dream is to own a salon and to see her home fully constructed. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase deodorants, creams, perfumes, and makeup to sell.

loans.name: Severino

texts.es: Severino tiene 58 años, vive con su esposa, ambos tienen 9 hijos, de los cuales solo viven con dos de ellos, en su casa propia. Hace más de 19 años se dedica a realizar costuras de fajas y prendas de vestir oriundas de su región, en un pequeño taller que tiene en su casa. En ocasiones su esposa y sus 2 hijos le ayudan en este negocio, es así que trabajan intensamente durante 4 días. Durante los fines de semana, se van a las principales ferias comerciales de zona rurales, en donde llevan su mercadería para venderlo. Severino se siente muy contento de realizar esta actividad, en compañía de sus seres queridos, es por eso que seguirá trabajando en su taller con el fin de mejorar cada día más su negocio. Este es su primer crédito con MFP y asegura que cumplirá con el pago de sus cuotas,  asimismo considera que este aporte le será muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará de materiales de construcción para ampliar su taller de costura que tiene.
texts.en:
Severino, 58, lives with his wife; they have 9 children but only two of them still live at home with them in their own house. For over 19 years he has manufactured sashes and clothing items typical of his region in a small workshop he has in his home. Sometimes his wife and his two children help him with the work working very intensely for four days. On the weekends they go to the main markets in rural areas to sell their wares. Severino enjoys working like this alongside his family very much and would like to continue working in his shop every day continually improving his business. This is his 1st loan with MFP and he pledges to be very responsible with his payments; he also considers this influx of capital to be very useful for his business’ success. He will use the requested funds to buy building materials and supplies to enlarge his workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials and supplies.

loans.name: Cielito Group

texts.es:
El Banco comunal CIELITO  en su Secuencia 3, está formado por 8 clientes, esta conformado por 6 mujeres y 2 varones, los componentes de la banca viven en diferentes zonas  pero que están ubicados por zonas aledañas a las oficinas de Emprender, las socias se dedican a la venta de diversos productos como ser, venta de ropa, taller mecánico, elaboración de mantas, la confección y venta de deportivos.

La Sra. Rosa Es una de las representantes  de la banca comunal, ocupa el cargo de presidenta del banco la señora vive en la zona de Pampahasi  desde muy pequeña, viven en dos habitaciones alquiladas. La señora tiene un pequeño taller  de costura  ella trabaja principalmente con mano de obra ya que ella recibe cortes de tela (telas cortadas en cantidad para alguna empresa o pequeñas microempresas) para costura y  posterior entrega de prendas, ella aprendió este oficio hace 7 años atrás en el Paiz de la Argentina  donde permaneció cerca de 2 años al regresar se caso y pasado un año instalo su pequeño taller. Su familia esta compuesta de la señora Rosa, su esposo Néstor y su hija cielo  la cual tiene 5  años de edad. Una de sus metas es lograr comprar una casa , equipar mejor su taller para tener sus propios clientes en costura el destino del credito es para la compra de una maquina de coser ya que una sola no es suficiente para los pedidos que tiene.

La Sra. Rebeca, actualmente toma el cargo de la secretaria de actas del banco se dedica elaboración y venta de mantas, realiza trabajos a pedido  cuenta con esta actividad hace 1 año, el préstamo será destinado para aumentar el capital  compra de lana y el material necesario. La señora comenta que el empezó a convivir con su esposo  hace 3 años   ella estudiaba y  vendía flores en el mercado Rodrigues el mercado mas populoso de la ciudad de la Paz, hasta que el  esposo sufrió un accidente y tuvo que buscar otros ingresos adicionales, allí aprendió a elaborar mantas junto a la suegra lo que le permitió  sobrellevar el problema que estaba atravesando en ese momento  esto sucedió hace un año actualmente la señora se esta logrando estabilizar económicamente. Su meta y sueño es tener su propio taller con maquinas de tejer y  mas adelante   tener una casa propia  y  progresar junto familia. En su banco comunal se ha destacado como una persona responsable y puntual en sus pagos y muy alegre aunque bastante joven.

La Sra. Alejandrina  Socia  nueva   es elegida como jefa de grupo por las características que se dan a conocer  en el proceso del crédito, la señora vive en  Villa Salome  en la casa de su suegra en la cual ocupa 2 cuartos y una pequeña cocina, vive con el esposo y sus tres hijos. La señora decide empezar con la venta de fruta  para ayudar al esposo con los gastos de la casa ya que dos de sus hijos ya están en  la escuela y necesitan  para su alimentación y para la vestimenta, comienza a trabajar desde las 5 de la mañana y vende hasta las 6 de la tarde, el crédito que solicita es para aumentar su capital en frutas según la temporada. Una de sus metas es sacar  a sus hijos adelante para que en adelante desean profesionales  de manera que nunca les falte nada y mas adelante poder comprar un terreno para su familia.

Todas las socias son personas responsables y trabajadoras con ganas de superacion que desean mejorar la calidad de vida de toda su familia, estan muy agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The CIELITO Communal Bank, in its third loan cycle, is made up of eight clients; six women and two men. The members of the bank live in different areas but their businesses are located in areas near the offices of Emprender. The various products and services offered by the members include selling clothing, auto repair, making blankets, tailoring, and selling sporting goods. Rosa is one of the representatives of the communal bank and serves as its president. She lives in two rented rooms in the Pampahasi area where she has lived since she was very young. She has a small sewing workshop and works primarily by hand as she receives cuts of fabric (fabric cut in quantity for businesses or small micro-businesses) for sewing and later delivery of garments. She learned this trade 7 years ago in Argentina where she lived for about two years. After returning, she got married and spent a year setting up her small workshop. The members of her family include her husband Nestor and her daughter Cielo who is 5 years old. One of her goals is to buy a house. She would also like to better equip her workshop in order to have her own sewing customers. The purpose of the loan is for the purchase of a sewing machine as one machine is not enough to handle her orders. Rebeca is the bank’s recording secretary. She has been selling made to order blankets for one year. The loan will be used to raise capital for the purchase of wool and necessary material. She says that she has been living with her husband for three years. She was studying and selling flowers in the Rodrigues market, the most populous market in the city of La Paz, until her husband had an accident and she had to seek additional sources of income. She learned to make blankets along with her mother-in-law which allowed her to cope with the problem she was experiencing. At the time this happened, a year ago today, she was struggling to stabilize herself financially. Her goal and dream is to have her own workshop with weaving machines and later have her own house and make progress along with her family. In her communal bank, she stands out as responsible, punctual in her payments, and very light-hearted, although she is quite young. Alejandrina, a new member, was elected as manager of the group based on leadership qualities which became evident during the loan process. She lives in Villa Salome in her mother-in-law’s house in which she occupies two rooms and a small kitchen. She lives with her husband and three children. She has decided to start selling fruit to help her husband with the household expenses as two of her children are in school and need food and clothing. She works from 5:00 in the morning until 6:00 in the evening. The loan she is requesting will be used to raise capital to buy seasonal fruits. One of her goals is to give her children a good education in life so that in the future they will pursue professional careers and will never lack anything. Later, she would like to be able to buy land for her family. All members are responsible and hard-working individuals who have a desire for self-improvement and want to improve the quality of life for their whole family. They are very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for trusting them with a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Francoletti-Putz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO PURCHASE A SEWING MACHINE

loans.name: Melenaite

texts.en:
Melenaite L. is 50 and married with 4 children.  She owns a business venture, selling food products in the local community.  Melenaite has many years of experience in this business.  Melenaite  needs a loan of WST $2250 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 750 talas or US $313 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Melenaite  joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Melenaite 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es: Hilda tiene  45 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijas en su casa propia. Hace más de 2 años que tiene una tienda, en donde vende productos de primera necesidad. Una de sus hijas la ayuda atendiendo a los clientes, puesto que su establecimiento esta ubicado en una avenida comercial de su barrio, eso motiva ha que haya mucha concurrencia de gente. Es así que trabaja incansablemente, incluso los fines de semana donde hay más clientela. Disfruta mucho de su trabajo, pese que es muy agotador, le permite estar ocupada y sentirse útil, además que le gusta mucho hablar con la gente. Este negocio le da las rentas necesarias para mantener a su familia y por ello desea aumentar su capital de trabajo. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, por tanto se compromete a ser responsable en sus pagos, además asegura que este aporte le será útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo utilizará en la compra de mercadería para implementar en su tienda.
texts.en:
Hilda, 45, lives in her own home with her husband and their two daughters. She has had a grocery store for over two years. One of her daughters helps her tend to her customers because her store is located on a commercial street in her neighborhood so it is very busy; she works incessantly, particularly on the weekend which is when there are the most customers. She enjoys her work very much despite it being so exhausting because it allows her to feel useful and busy; besides she enjoys chatting with people very much. The store provides enough profits to support her family so she wants to increase her working capital. This is her 1st loan with MFP and she pledges prompt repayment; she also assures that this influx of capital will be useful for her store’s success. She will use the requested funds to buy stock merchandise for her store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

Sara needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy sugar, styrofoam cups, and cordial (flavoring).  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Sara join the program to help develop her business.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa M. es socia del bankito La Paz, vive en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca; ésta ciudad se encuentra escondida en el valle del sur donde una vez fue el  asentamiento de los Tomebamba.  Conocida  también como el camino real que unía al  Cuzco con Quito durante el imperio Pre-colombino es la capital de la provincia del  Azuay. 

 Nuestra socia tiene 66 años de edad,  enviudó hace nueve  años porque  su esposo tenía  cirrosis ya que bebía mucho, concibió siete hijos, cinco  hijos  son casados  y una de  ellos  vive en su casa de forma  independiente, comparte su techo con  un hijo invalido porque fue arrollado por un carro y a raíz de su lesión su esposa le abandono, su hijo soltero se encuentra enfermo a casusa de la bebida de alcohol,  su vivienda es herencia de su difunta suegra.

Rosa se dedica a la venta de ropa usada  en los mercados de Azogues y Gualaceo  sólo los días sábados el resto de la semana realiza los quehaceres de su hogar y cuidado de sus hijos enfermos.  Se encuentra en su sexto ciclo integrando el banco comunal La Paz, los créditos le han beneficiado para adquirir ropa para su negocio  y para comprar medicamentos para tratar el cáncer  del  que felizmente está curada, con su nuevo crédito va a comprar camisas, blusas, faldas, pantalones, etc.  para damas y caballeros para abastecer su negocio y tener un stock surtido para ofrecer a sus clientes.

 Su sueño es llegar hacer un cuarto en un terreno que tiene para entregarle a su hija.
texts.en:
Rosa M., 66, is a member of the La Paz communal bank. She lives in greater Cuenca which is located in a southern valley that was once the Tomebamba (a former city-state in the Inca federation) settlement. It is also known as the royal road that connected Cuzco to Quito during the Pre-Columbian era; it is the capital of Azuay province. Rosa was widowed nine years ago because her husband had cirrhosis due to excessive drinking. She has 7 children, five are married and one lives independently in her own home. She shares her home with a disabled son who was hit by a car; due to his disability his wife left him. Her unmarried son suffers from the disease of alcoholism. Her home was inherited from her deceased mother-in-law. Rosa is a used clothing merchant in Azogues and Gualaceo markets on Saturdays. The rest of the week she tends to her household chores and to care for her ill sons. She is in her 6th cycle as a member of the La Paz communal bank. Her previous loans have been used to buy clothing for her business and to buy medicine to treat her cancer which she is happily cured of. She will use the requested funds to buy assorted articles of clothing like: shirts, skirts, blouses, pants, etc. for women and men to have a varied stock available for her customers. Her dream is to have a room built on a lot she owns to give to her daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted women's and men's clothing.

loans.name: Solinuu

texts.en:

Solinuu needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase new facilities in order for her to provide good services to tourists and other people.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 1000 talas or US $417 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Solinuu joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Solinuu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.name: Elberta

texts.es:
Elberta es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Elberta es casada, tiene 54 años y 8 hijos, Elberta tiene un puesto en el mercado central de la ciudad de Ayacucho en donde vende comida, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de su hija.
Elberta necesita un préstamo de 2600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de leña, arroz, aceite y gas.
Los sueños de Elberta son que sus hijos sean profesionales, implementar una polleria para que trabajen sus hijos.
texts.en:
Elberta, 54, is a member of the Triunfo (Triumph) communal bank. She is married and has 8 children. She has a stall in Ayacucho’s central market where she sells prepared food; she’s open for business every day, her daughter helps her. Elberta needs a 2600 sol loan to invest in the purchase of firewood, rice, cooking oil and gas. Elberta’s dreams are that her children become professionals and to set up a poultry shop that her children can run.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, rice, cooking oil and gas.

texts.en:

Olo needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase more seedlings to plant.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Rosa es conviviente, tiene 24 años y 2 hijos, Rosa vende salchipollos, actividad que realiza por las tardes en la puerta de su casa, además Rosa vende ropa variada de acuerdo a los pedidos de sus clientes.
Rosa necesita un préstamo de 800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de gaseosa, arroz y aceite.
Los sueños de Rosa son ampliar su negocio y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Rosa, 24, is a member of the Triunfo (Triumph) communal bank. She lives with her life partner and their two children. Rosa sells salchipollos (fried potatoes and chicken) every evening at her doorstep. In addition, Rosa sells assorted clothing based on prior orders from her customers. Rosa needs an 800 sol loan to buy soft-drinks, rice and cooking oil. Rosa’s dreams are to enlarge her business and that her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soft-drinks, rice and cooking oil.

loans.name: Zenaida Lidia

texts.es:
Zenaida es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Zenaida es casada, tiene 39 años y 3 hijos, Zenaida tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, carnes, verduras, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Zenaida junto a su esposo tienen un carro el cual realiza transporte publico en la ciudad.
Zenaida necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar y gaseosas.
Los sueños de Zenaida son que sus hijos salgan adelante y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Zenaida, 39, is a member of the Triunfo (Triumph) communal bank. She is married and has three children. Zenaida has a grocery store in her home where she sells assorted grocery items like, meats and vegetables, every day. Besides, together with her husband, she owns a car that they use to provide public transportation services in the city. Zenaida needs a 600 sol loan to buy rice, sugar and soft drinks. Zenaida’s dreams are that her children become successful and to enlarge her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar and soft-drinks.

loans.name: Oloa

texts.en:
Oloa I. is 32 and married with 4 children.  She owns a business venture, catching & selling ocean-caught fish.  Oloa has 3 years of experience in this business.  Oloa needs a loan of WST $1250 to purchase a fishing boat.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Oloa is a hard working client wishing to develop her business and assist her family financially.

Oloa joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Oloa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Prosperidad 2 Group

texts.en:
Mirelys is the coordinator of her group Prosperidad 2 (Prosperity), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, a large city known for its tobacco production, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and three children.

Mirelys is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza,  after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling cleaning products by purchasing products like clorox to sell in her community. She will use the profits to save towards continuing to grow her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy cleaning products.

loans.name: La Familia Group

texts.es:
El Banco D. Emprendimiento LA FAMILIA, es uno D. los bancos más antiguos D. la Institución, viene trabajando con nosotros hace 3 años atras. La mayoria D. sus integrantes se dedica al comercio.

La Sra. ANGELICA ocupa la presidencia, ella se constituye en jefe D. hogar ya que hace varios años es viuda y esta a cargo D. sus 2 hijas, trabaja como regente en un colegio y tambien se dedica al comercio repartiendo viveres por su zona, con el prestamo comprara mercaderia ya que tiene muchos pedidos y asi poder incrementar su capital D. trabajo, tiene pensado ahorrar para los estudios D. sus hijas. 

El Sr. MIGUEL  Ocupa el cargo  D. secretario, tiene una familia numerosa. Es chofer propietario, con el prestamo realizara mantenimiento D. su movilidad y poder comprarse llantas para seguir trabajando y así cubrir los gastos D. sus hijos. 

La Sra. MERCEDES La socia es tesorera del banco tiene una familia D. 2 miembros se dedica a la costura, con el prestamo a logrado comprar telas D. diferentes calidades y tipos para poder diversificar sus modelos y sus productos, con sus ahorros tiene pensado comprar una maquina recta.

Todas las socias son personas responsables y trabajadoras con ganas D. superacion que desean mejorar la calidad D. vida D. toda su familia, están muy agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgación del crédito.
texts.en:
The Banco D. Emprendimiento La Familia (The Family Entrepreneurial Bank) is one of the oldest banks of our institution: they have been working with us for the past 3 years. The majority of its members works in the traD. industry. Angelica is the President. A widow of many years, she is the head of her family, and she provides for her 2 daughters. She is the manager of a school and she also dedicates herself to the traD. industry, selling provisions in her area. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy products, as she receives many requests, in order to succeed in increasing her income. She is also planning on saving money for the education of her daughters. Miguel is the secretary. He has a large family. He is a driver and has his own car: he will use the loan to maintain his car and to buy tyres to keep on working and thus covering the expenses for his children. Mercedes is the treasurer of the bank. Her family is composed of 2 more members and she is a dressmaker. The loan she is requesting she will buy textiles of various quality and type in order to vary her models and her products. She is planning on buying a sewing machine with her savings. All the members are responsible and hard-working people working for an improvement in their life conditions and in their families’ quality of life. They are very thankful to Emprender and Kiva for the faith shown in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy different core products

loans.name: Molia

texts.en:
Molia T. is 35 and married with 9 children (ages 2 - 24).  She is starting a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Molia needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional young crops to raise.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Molia joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Molia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional young crops to raise

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
Virginia es una madre de familia de 35 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a sus hijos  en el caserío Lagunas del distrito de Mórrope, un distrito caracterizado por tener a la mayor parte de su población situada en áreas rurales que distan mucho una de la otra, sus principales actividades económicas son la agricultura y la crianza de animales, pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y se encuentra ubicada a una hora y quince minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de tres años a la venta de productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes en una bodega instalada en su domicilio. Allí ella atiende las necesidades de sus clientes los cuales siempre acuden a su establecimiento para adquirir productos de consumo diario que no pueden obtener facilmente dado que se encuentran alejados del pueblo de Mórrope. Este negocio le provee de ingresos con los que ayuda a su esposo a sostener la economía de su familia, ya que los ingresos que este percibe como agricultor no son permanentes.

La vivienda en la que reside se ha visto afectada por las lluvias que se presentaron durante los pasados meses, ella desea reparar estas fallas para vivir de un modo mas seguro y también desea invertir parte del dinero en la compra de productos con los cuales pueda ampliar su negocio, para lograr este objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles.

Virginia es una mujer entregada a su familia y que siempre trabaja para ayudarlos a salir adelante. Ella ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
Virginia, 35, lives with her husband and children in the Lagunas settlement in Mórrope district, a district known for having most of its residents in rural areas that are quite separated from each other. Its principal commercial activities are farming and cattle-raising. It is part of Lambayeque province and it is located an hour and fifteen minutes away from the city of Chiclayo. For over three years she has sold basic needs items and groceries in a store set up in her home. She tends to the needs of her customers who always visit her establishment looking for items of daily consumption that they can’t get conveniently because they are so far from the town of Mórrope. The store provides income that helps her husband support the family because his earnings as a farmer aren’t reliable. Their home has been adversely affected by the rains that occurred these past few months. She wants to repair the damages so that they can live more securely. She also wants to invest part of the funds purchasing some stock items for the store. To reach these goals she has called upon Edpyme Alternativa to request a 2000 new sol loan. Virginia is dedicated to her family and always strives to help them get ahead in life. She has collaborated with our institution in the past and has shown herself to be responsible and punctual with her repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair rain damage to her house.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
La señora Teresa de Jesús M. es socia del banco Comunal  La Paz, vive en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca, ubicada  en el valle del sur a 2535 metros sobre el nivel del mar, es la capital de la provincia del  Azuay y es  la tercera ciudad más importante del Ecuador. 

Teresa de Jesús tiene 49 años, se encuentra casada y en su unión conyugal concibió dos hijos que se encuentran de 29 y 27 años y ya  son casados,  vive sólo con  su esposo que trabaja como  chofer de un camión y viaja por varias ciudades del Ecuador. Ella vende productos naturales Herbalife hace ya diez años sólo durante sus momentos libres ya que viaja junto a su esposo comercializando papas, maíz, carbón  y todo lo que encuentren a precios convenientes.


Fue  invitada por su hermana a formar parte de este gran grupo de mujeres triunfadoras y es nuestra socia hace  un año, con el  crédito que le entreguen va a comprar multi vitamínicos, suplementos alimenticios entre otros productos Herbalife.

Su  meta es tener un negocio grande donde pueda comercializar varios productos para el hogar  y la familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Teresa de Jesus M. is a member of the La Paz Community Bank, and lives in the city of Cuenca, (located in the valley, south about 2535 meters above sea level) which is the capital of the province of Azuay, and is the third most important city of Ecuador. Teresa is 49 years old, is married and has two sons who are 29 and 27 years of age and are married. She lives alone with her husband who works as a truck driver and travels through several cities in Ecuador. She's been selling "Herbalife" natural products for ten years now during her free time, since she spends most of her time traveling with her husband selling/purchasing potatoes, corn, coal and everything they find at good prices. Teresa was invited by her sister to join this great group of women achievers and to become a member of this bank, a year ago. With this loan she will buy multi-vitamins, dietary supplements and other Herbalife products. Her goal is to have a business where she can sell more products for the home and family.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Co,mprar suplementos alimenticios, proteinas y multi vitamínicos Herbalife (To purchase additional supplements, multi-vitamins and Herbalife products)

loans.name: Isa

texts.en:
Isa F. is 41 and married with 6 children (ages 4 - 21).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Isa  has 3 years of experience in this business.  Isa  needs a loan of WST $1750 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Isa  joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Isa 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Maria De La Concepcion

texts.es: Maria De La Concepción tiene 47 años, su actividad económica es elaboración de ollas de aluminio. Hace más de 26 años que se dedica a este negocio, ya que ella inicia por cuenta propia, ella misma salía a venderlos después de elaborar una cantidad, recorría muchos lugares para ofrecer sus productos ya que son muy pesados, pero a pesar de esto no deja de luchar para mejorar los ingresos y así proporcionarle a su hijo lo necesario.  Así fue que poco a poco ella fue creciendo con su negocio. Pues siempre sueña con establecer un taller para generar más ingresos a su familia. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo destinado para la compra de materia prima como aluminio, moldes entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Maria De La Concepción is 47 years old. Her economic activity is making aluminum pots. She has been performing this activity for more than 26 years. She started on her own. She would go out by herself to sell them after making a certain quantity. She would go through different places, offering her products. They are very heavy, but despite this she won't stop fighting to improve her income and give her son everything he needs. In this way, little by little, she has grown her business. She has always dreamed of having a workshop to generate more income for her family. The loan she is asking for is for working capital destined for the purchase of raw materials such as aluminum, molds and more.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:

Tina needs a loan of WST $750 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Tina joined SPBD.    This is her 2nd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Tina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen es socia del Banco Comunal Belen.
Carmen es soltera, tiene 36 años y 5 hijos, Carmen vende comida de manera ambulatoria en el camal de la ciudad, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Carmen necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de platos, ollas.
Carmen sueña con tener una casa propia y que sus hijos salgan adelante.
texts.en:
Carmen is a member of the Belen community bank. Carmen is single, 36 and has 5 children. She sells food as a street vendor at the city slaughterhouse. She does this activity every day. Carmen needs a loan of 1,500 soles to invest in the purchase of dishes and pots. Carmen dreams of having her own house and for her children to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase dishes and pots.

loans.name: Mujer Virtuosa 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Rosa is the coordinator of her group Mujer Virtuosa (Virtuous Woman), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and children.

Rosa is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza, and believes that working with Esperanza will be help her to improve her life. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling cleaning products by traveling to the Capital to purchase bathroom cleaning products and handsoap to sell at a profit in her community. She will use the profits towards the education of her children, as well as purchasing a vehicle. Her long term goal is to be an asset to her community. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy cleaning products and soaps to sell.

Lamosa has 3 years of experience in this business.  Lamosa needs a loan of WST $3250 to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.name: Asuntina

texts.es:
Asuntina es socia del Banco Comunal Belen.

Asuntina es soltera, tiene 27 años y 1 hija, Asuntina compra panes del horno, producto que reparte a tiendas y también lo vende en un terminal terrestre. Además Asuntina se dedica a la siembra de verduras que vende en el mercado de abastos.

Asuntina necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de semillas. Los sueños de Asuntina son comprar un terreno para construir su casa y brindar buena educación a su hija.
texts.en:
Asuntina is a member of the Belen Communal Bank. She is single, 27 years old, and has a daughter. She buys bread for distribution to stores, and she also sells bread in a terminal. In addition, Asuntina grows vegetables, which she sells in the marketplace. She needs a loan of 600 soles, to purchase seeds. Her dream is to buy land to build her house and offer a good education to her daughter.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy seeds

loans.name: Sirari Group

texts.es: El grupo “Sirari” esta representado por la señora Masemia y conformado por 15 miembros de las cuales 12 son mujeres y 3 varones los cuales residen en la misma zona, la mayoría de las socias tienen su negocio y otras van a empezar uno nuevo y sobre todo cuentan con lo necesario para salir adelante. La señora Masemia  se dedica a la venta de empanadas y refrescos y también se dedica a la venta de cosméticos por catalogo, ella es casada y su esposo se dedica al transporte, ella desea poder dedicarse con un mayor capital a la venta de empanadas y es por esta razón que requiere del préstamo, ella tiene un niño pequeño y vive en la casa de sus suegros, ella desea poder tener ahorrar para en un futuro no muy lejano poder tener su casa propia. El resto de las socias se dedica a la venta de comida, carne, hamburguesas, cosméticos y al servicio domestico, entre los varones algunos se dedican  al transporte de pasajeros y los otros son empleados de la fabrica de Guabira todos los socios tienen muchos años de experiencia en cada rubro al que se dedican. La competencia en el  mercado en el que se desempeñan las socias no es alta pero las ventas no son muy satisfactorias por lo que se ven en la necesidad de cambiar de mercado para poder obtener mejores ingresos, muchas de las socias que son empleadas domesticas desean poder abrir un negocio que les permita estar mas cerca de su familia, es por esta razón que requieren del crédito que les servirá para capital de trabajo  y en otros casos para incrementar su mercadería, comprar repuestos para sus vehículos y motorizados que son su fuente de trabajo. La mayoría de las socias solo habían escuchado de estos créditos en grupo, pero se encuentran entusiasmados por este apoyo económico que les servirá para poder trabajar y para brindarles a sus familias una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Masemia represents the Sirari group, which is comprised of 15 members. There are 12 women and 3 men in the group, and they live in the same area. Most of the members have a business, and others are going to start a new one. Most importantly, they have what it takes to get ahead. Masemia sells empanadas and soft drinks. She also sells cosmetics by catalog. She is married, and her husband works in transportation. She wants to be able to put more capital into her empanada sales. That is the reason she needs the loan. She has a small child, and she lives in her husband’s parents’ house. She wishes to be able to have savings. In the near future she wants to be able to have her own house. The rest of the women sell food, meat, hamburgers, cosmetics, or provide domestic services. Some of the men work in passenger transportation, and the others are employed by the Guabira factory. All of the members have many years of experience in their fields. The competition in the market that the members work in is not high, but the sales are not very satisfactory. Therefore, they see the need to change markets to be able to get better earnings. Many of the members who are domestic employees want to be able to open a business that would allow them to be closer to their families. That is the reason that they need a loan, which would serve as working capital. In other cases the loan is to increase their merchandise or buy replacement parts for their vehicles, which they use for work. Most of the members had only heard about these group loans. But, they are enthusiastic about this economic support, which they will use to be able to work and to give their families a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth es socia del Banco Comunal Belen.

Elizabeth es soltera, tiene 23 años y 1 hija, Elizabeth viaja a la comunidad de Pucaloma en donde compra leche y quesos que vende en la ciudad de Ayacucho de casa en casa.

Elizabeth necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de leche y quesos. Elizabeth sueña con construir su casa y brindar una buena educación a su hija.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is a member of the Belen Communal Bank. She is single, 23 years old, and has a daughter. She travels to Pucaloma to buy milk and cheeses, which she sells door to door in Ayacucho. She needs a loan of 600 soles, to purchase milk and cheese. Elizabeth’s dream is to buy land to build her house and provide her daughter with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk and cheese

She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

texts.en:
Debora is the coordinator of her group La Buena Vida (The Good Life), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, rented structure with her husband.

She plans to use this loan to invest in her business of selling purses by purchasing them in the main markets in Santo Domingo and then selling them at a profit. She will use the profits to invest in first repairing her current home and then saving towards purchasing her own own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es: Gloria tiene 63 años D. edad, casada con Rosendo D. 66 años y juntos tienen dos hijos, Grermer y Edilson D. 29 y 21 años respectivamente, quienes ya son independientes. Todos ellos viven en su casa propia. Hace  algún tiempo atrás empezó con el negocio D. alquilar mesas D. billar, ubicado en una pequeña parte D. su domicilio. Paralelo a este negocio, se dedica también a la confección D. prendas D. vestir actividad que realiza esporádicamente. D. esta manera, Gloria atienD. a sus clientes, dándoles la mejor atención a los jóvenes que van a jugar a su local, eso le ha favorecido bastante en las ganancias por lo que se siente muy satisfecha. Por tal motivo desea mejorar las instalaciones D. su local, así como D. sus implementos D. juego, como: taco, bolas D. billar y algunas mesas que tiene mucho tiempo D. uso, ya que D. esa  podrá brindarle a su familia una mejor estabilidad económica. Este es su segundo crédito con MFP, por tanto se compromete a ser tan puntual en sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará tacos y bolas D. billar, además invertirá en la comprar D. tela para emprender el negocio D. confección D. prendas D. vestir.
texts.en:
Gloria is 63 years old, married to Rosendo (66 years old), and they have two children, Grermer and Edilson, 29 and 21 years old, respectively, who live independently. All of them live in their own homes. Some time ago, she set up a business renting pool tables from a small section of her house. Her other business is that of dressmaker, an activity she engages in sporadically. This way, Gloria attends to her customers, offering good service to the young people who play on her premises. This has paid off in earnings, for which she is proud. For this reason she wishes to improve her facility and playing equipment, such as cue, billiard balls, and some well worn tables. She would thus be able to offer more financial stability to her family. This is her second loan with MFP, and she commits to being punctual once more in her payments. With the money requested, she will buy cues and billiard balls, and invest in fabric to start up her dressmaking business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Jane Wilkie, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy billiard balls, cues, and fabric to start a dressmaking business.

loans.name: Selesa

texts.en:
Selesa Siaana I. is 30 and married with 3 children (ages 2 - 11).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting bananas for sale.  Selesa has 2 years of experience in this business.  Selesa needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 280 talas or US $117 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Selesa joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Selesa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.name: Malia

texts.en:
Malia Silomiga N. is 53 and married with 6 children (ages 10 - 29).  She owns a business venture, catching & selling ocean-caught fish.  Malia Silomiga has 3 years of experience in this business.  Malia Silomiga needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

In 2007, Malia Silomiga joined SPBD.   This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Malia Silomiga's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

texts.en:
Juana, 50, is the coordinator of her group La Union (The Union), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and two children.

Juana is excited to be taking her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by purchasing fabric to make the sheets, curtains and bed covers that she makes and sells. She will use the profits to repair her home as well as support her children in their college education. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Fabric
