loans.name: Haydee Del Socorro

texts.es: Haydee tiene 42 años, pues su actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general. Tiene mucha experiencia en el negocio ya que se inicio desde hace 4 años, fue con ingresos ahorrados de ella que inicio esta actividad, ella tiene 1 hija a su cargo. Ella posee muchos clientes los cuales son de la zona, por lo que les brinda además de buen servicio buenos precios, por este motivo es que los clientes regresan a su negocio. Sus sueños de Ella son incrementar su negocio y tener una pulpería como una fuente de ingreso fija. Este financiamiento será para la compra de materia prima como pantalones, camisetas, faldas y cosméticos.
texts.en:
Haydee is 42 years old and engages in selling general merchandise. She is experienced in this business which she started four years ago with her savings. Haydee has a daughter from whom she is responsible. She has many customers who are from the area and provides them good service and good prices so that they keep returning to her business.

Haydee dreams of expanding her business and opening a grocery store as a steady source of income. This loan will be used to buy merchandise such as trousers, shirts, skirts, and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Adela

texts.es: Adela es una trabajadora madre de 35 años, vive con su pareja y sus dos hijos pequeños en su casa propia. Hace algunos años atrás, Adela y su hermana se asociaron para vender comida en unos de los paraderos de buses más concurridos de la zona en la que viven. En donde ofrecen pollo a la parrilla, anticuchos (platillo tradicional elaborado a base de corazón de res y papas cocidas a la parrilla), entre otros. Las ventas de esta comida son buenas, esto es debido a la gran dote culinaria que poseen ambas hermanas, logrando captar clientes, quienes continuamente se acercan a su establecimiento para degustar de estos ricos platos. Adela se siente contenta con su negocio y para el futuro quisiera tener un gran restaurante, en donde pueda ofrecer de manera más cómoda sus platillos, es por eso que ella y su hermana trabajarán mucho para lograr el capital necesario y poder cumplir con sus sueños. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP y promete ser muy puntual en sus pagos, como lo fue en anteriores pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará ingredientes para la preparación de sus platillos, además de algunos utensilios de cocina y también de un toldo para ofrecer un mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Adela is a 35 year old working mother. She lives in her own home with her partner and their two children. A few years ago, Adela and her sister teamed up to sell food at one of the busiest bus depots in the district where they live. There they offer grilled chicken, “anticuchos” (a traditional dish made of beef hearts and potatoes cooked on a grill), and other dishes. Their foods sales have been good due to the great culinary skills that both sisters possess. They have attracted customers who continually return to their establishment to enjoy their delicious food. Adela is happy with her business and wants to open a large restaurant in the future where she can prepare her dishes more comfortably. She and her sister work hard to acquire the necessary capital to fulfill their dreams.

This is her third loan with MFP. Adela promises to complete her payments on time, like she has done with her previous loans. The funds she requested will be used to buy ingredients for preparing her dishes, as well as cooking utensils and a canopy so that she can provide better service.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients, cooking utensils, and a canopy

loans.name: Julio Adan

texts.es:
Julio Adan habitante de colonia los Laureles, es conocido como una persona muy trabajadora y honesta, su familia esta conformada por su esposa y dos hijos menores, de 7 años y  10 meses de edad,su esposa se dedica al cuido del hogar y de sus hijos.   Don Julio tiene como principal actividad el cuido de su pequeño inventario ganadero y actividades agricolas las que realiza en conjunto con su papá. 

Necesita de este financiamiento para compra de 6 terneros, puesto que considera que esto ayudara a mejorar sus condiciones de vida a nivel familiar.     

Este  cliente ha trabajado con esfuerzos personales y ha podido ir mejorando su situacion economica y hoy con este credito espera que sus esfuersos generen una estabilidad economica de manera mas rapida para poder vivir en mejores condiciones de vida junto a su familia.
texts.en:
Julio Adan lives in the Los Laureles neighborhood; he’s known as a very hard-working, honest person. His family is composed of his wife and two minor children, a 7-year-old and a 10-month-old; his wife cares for the home and their children. Julio’s main activity is caring for his small cattle herd and farming with his father. He needs these funds to buy 6 calves because he feels this will be very helpful in improving his family’s living conditions. This client has improved his economic situation through his own efforts. Today, however, he hopes that this loan will generate economic stability more quickly so that he and his family can live in better conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy calves.

loans.name: Aleyda Matilde

texts.es: Aleyda Matilde tiene 44 años tiene 3 hijos que están a su cargo ella se dedica a la venta de gaseosas y brinda el servicio de billares. Hace más de 9 años que se dedica a este negocio. La ubicación es en su vivienda porque la mayoría de sus clientes son de la misma comarca, ella se encuentra muy contenta con medio de ingreso Ella posee una gran cantidad de clientes a los cuales los atiende de manera muy amable y cálida, por esto y por sus buenos precios es que los clientes regresan a su negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es especialmente para capital de trabajo y así comprar productos necesarios para su local.
texts.en:
Aleyda Matilde is 44 and takes care of her three children. 9 years ago she started selling soft drinks and she has a location with billiard tables The business is located in her house since most of her customers are from the same area. She is very happy with the way she earns money. Aleyda has many customers who she sees to in a friendly and warm manner. Because of this and because of her good prices, her customers come back. The financing that she is asking for is especially for working capital and to buy the necessary items for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: María Eugenia

texts.es:
La señora  María Eugenia  Deleg es socia del banco Comunal  Feria libre ubicado en  la parroquia Ricaurte al noreste del cantón Cuenca. Limita al norte con la parroquia Sidcay; al este la parroquia Llacao, al sur y al oeste la ciudad de Cuenca. Teniendo como atractivo turístico un hermoso mirador que se encuentra en el barrio la Dolorosa junto a la planta de agua potable, en la iglesia parroquial se encuentran cuadros,  imágenes y reliquias muy antiguas que atraen a los visitantes,  aquí se prepara unos exquisitos cuyes, cascaritas y fritada que es lo mejor de la gastronomía de la ciudad.

María  Eugenia tiene 25 años, de estado civil casada concibió dos hijos que se encuentran de 10 años y 9 meses, su hijo mayor estudia en la escuela de la ciudad, su esposo es chofer de transporte urbano, y como no tiene casa propia todavía viven  en casa de su mamá compartiendo todos los gastos.

Nuestra socia estudio costura en una academia durante tres  años y ahora trabaja en un taller propio adecuado en su casa  hace seis  años,  elabora  delantales y muy pocas veces  al arreglo de ropa, no tiene un horario fijo de trabajo ya que trabaja según sus obras pero sí de  lunes a sábado. Lleva cinco años en el banco comunal gracias a su suegra que la incentivó a formar parte del mismo, con el dinero del credito solicitado comprará telas, hilos, cierres, encajes para la confección de sus prendas.

Su meta es llegar a tener un taller más grande.
texts.en:
María Eugenia Deleg is a member of the "Feria Libre" (Public Market) communal bank, located in the Ricaurte parish in the northeast part of the canton of Cuenca. It is bordered in the north by the Sidcay parish, in the east by the Llacao parish, and on the south and west by the city of Cuenca. A special attraction of the area is its beautiful scenic overlook, located in the Dolorosa neighborhood next to the drinking water plant. The parish church contains paintings, relics and religious images which are very old and attractive to visitors. The people of the region prepare delicious roasted guinea pigs, meat stews and fried pork skin, which are the highlights of the city's gastronomy. María Eugenia is 25 years old and married. She has two children who are 10 years and 9 months old. Her older child goes to school in the city. Her husband is a driver in the city transportation system. Since they do not yet have their own house, they live in his mother's house, sharing all of the expenses. María Eugenia has been studying dressmaking in an academy for three years, and she is now working in her own workshop, which was set up in her house six years ago. She makes work uniforms, and every once in a while she does clothing alterations. She does not have fixed working hours, since she works according to the orders she receives, but she works from Monday through Saturday. She has been a member of the communal bank for five years, thanks to her mother-in-law, who encouraged her to join. With the funds from the loan she is requesting, she will buy fabric, thread, zippers and lace for making clothing. Her goal is to be able to have a larger workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fabrics, thread, zippers, lace, etc.

loans.name: Fe Y Esperanza 2 Group

texts.en:
Angela is the coordinator of her group Fe y Esperanza (Faith and Hope), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure and is a single mother with one child.

Angela is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business, running a cafeteria, by purchasing pineapple, cheese meat and sauces. She will use the profits to invest in her home by changing the wooden walls to cement blocks and to educate her child. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy pineapple, cheese meat and sauces for her cafeteria

loans.name: Lucia Magdalena

texts.es:
Al igual que las otras socias  Lucia L. es  otra integrante del banco Comunal  Feria Libre,  vive en una casa prestada por su tía   con su esposo  que trabaja como chofer de transporte urbano y sus dos hijos de 6 y 3 años, el mayor estudia en una escuela de la localidad,  este banco esta situado en la parroquia Ricaurte  ubicada al noreste del cantón Cuenca. Limita al norte con  la parroquia Sidcay,  al este la parroquia Llacao, al sur y al oeste la ciudad de Cuenca.  Entre sus principales atractivos turísticos encontramos  un hermoso mirador en  el barrio la Dolorosa junto a la planta de agua potable, en la iglesia de la localidad encontramos imágenes de santos, cuadros y reliquias muy antiguas, su rica gastronomía atraen a los visitantes

Lucia pinta  en cerámica aprendió a realizar estas manualidades en un curso especial, recién encontró trabajo y su labor es pegar juguetes y pintarlos. También nos comenta que  se encuentra en su sexto ciclo dentro de su banco comunal invitada por su suegra, los créditos recibidos  le han beneficiado en su negocio y por ahora con el  préstamo  que recibirá va a invertir en la compra de  cerámica, pintura, pinceles  etc.  para la elaboración de sus artesanías.

Tiene como meta seguir un a curso de belleza para ser una gran estilista y montar su propio gabinete.
texts.en:
Like the other members of her group, Lucia L. is part of the Communal Bank “Feria Libre” (Open Market). She lives in a house provided by her aunt. Her husband works as a city bus driver and they have two children, ages 6 and 3. The oldest child is enrolled at the local school. This Communal Bank is located in Ricuarte Parish, which is in the canton northeast of Cuenca. Ricuarte Parish is bordered to the north by Sidcay Parish, to the east by Llacao Parish, and to the south and west by the city of Cuenca. Among the main tourist attractions are the beautiful lookout of the neighborhood of La Dolorosa next to the drinking water plant and the local church with its images of the saints and ancient paintings and relics. The rich food culture attracts many visitors.

Lucia took a special course in which she learned to make painted ceramics. She recently found work assembling and painting toys. In addition, she says that she is starting her sixth loan cycle and was invited to join the Communal Bank by her mother-in-law. The loans she received have benefited her business and will use her current loan to buy ceramics, paint, brushes, and other supplies for making crafts.

Lucia’s goal is to continue with her beauty courses so that she can become a great stylist and open her own salon.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ceramics, paint, brushes, and other supplies for making crafts

loans.name: Fuerza Divina Group

texts.en:
Clara is the coordinator of her group Fuerza Divina (Divine Force), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and two children.

Clara is excited to be taking her ninth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business making curtains, by buying the necessary fabric. She will use the profits to save for growing her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy fabric for making curtains.

loans.name: Etelvina

texts.es: Etelvina tiene 32 años, es una alegre mujer que vive con su casa propia en compañía de sus hijos Fredy y Leyla de 5 y 2 años respectivamente. La venta de Anticuchos es la actividad a la que se dedica, junto a su hermana, quien es socia en el negocio. De esta manera vende este tradicional plato, elaborado a base de corazón de res y papas cocidas con salsa y ají, en un paradero de buses donde hay mayor concurrencia de gente, siendo sus principales clientes los chóferes, pasajeros y vecinos de la zona. Este negocio le es rentable, por lo que espera mas adelante tener su propio restaurante, en donde pueda  preparar y vender sus deliciosos platillos, pero para ello deberá trabajar y juntar el capital necesario para realizar su sueño. Por el momento desea dedicarse íntegramente al trabajo para poder sacar a su familia adelante. Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual con todos sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará ingredientes para la preparación de sus paltillos así como una parrilla, además comprará mesas para dar mejor comodidad a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Etelvina is a 32 year old cheerful woman who lives in her own home with her children Fredy and Leyla, ages 5 and 2 respectively. She sells “anticuchos” with her sister, who is also a partner in the business. They sell this dish, which is made of beef hearts and potatoes cooked in a chili sauce, at a bus depot where there is a large influx of people. Their main customers are drivers, passengers, and residents of the area. This business has proven to be profitable, and she hopes to eventually open her own restaurant where she can prepare and sell her delicious dishes. However, she needs to continue working so that she can obtain the necessary capital to fulfill her dream. For now, Etelvina wants to devote herself entirely to moving her family forward.

This is her fourth loan with MFP. Etelvina promises to complete all of her payments on time. The loan she requested will be used to purchase ingredients and a grill for preparing her dishes. She also plans to acquire tables so that her customers will be more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients, a grill, and tables

loans.name: Feiloaiga

texts.en:
Feiloaiga P. is 65 and married with 1 child.  She owns a business venture, selling puletasi (Samoan formal wear).  Feiloaiga  has many years of experience in this business.  Feiloaiga  needs a loan of WST $1200 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Feiloaiga  joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Feiloaiga 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

texts.en:
Leonidas is the coordinator of her group El Milagro (The Miracle), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her two children.

Leonidas is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling beauty products such as makeup and creams. She will use the profits to continue to grow her inventory as well as contributing to her community. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Rosa Elvira

texts.es:
Rosa T.  es socia activa del Banco Comunal  Feria libre,  vive en  San Pedro de el Cebollar sector que se caracteriza por  la hermosa vista de la ciudad de Cuenca, su gente mayor se dedica a la agricultura y los más jóvenes buscan mejores oportunidades en la ciudad.

Nuestra socia tiene 61 años,  separada hace tres  años de su esposo ya que ella sufrió un derrame  y estuvo inválida  entonces él la abandonó, en su matrimonio concibieron diez hijos de ellos seis  son casados y viven de manera independiente,  mientras que sus cuatro hijos de 30, 27, 25, 23 años son solteros  y viven junto a ella, su hija de 30 años trabaja en su propia fabrica de ropa deportiva y es quien ayuda económicamente en casa, su hijo de 27 años se ha graduado de Economista pero aun no consigue trabajo, su hijo de 25 se encuentra en la universidad y cursa el 5to año de Arquitectura, y su última hija cursa el tercer año de economía, fruto de su trabajo ha logrado construir su casita propia.

Rosa se dedica a la agricultura y  venta de granos tiernos, legumbres, también cría pollos y chanchos y en sus tiempos libres  ayuda a su hija a trabajar en su taller, es una de las socias fundadoras del banco comunal pues ya lleva doce años gracias a una amiga,  nos comenta que los créditos le han beneficiado para el estudio de sus hijos, en su hogar y para el taller de su hija, con su nuevo crédito va a comprar tela, hilos, cierres, botones y más suministros para la confección de las prendas de vestir que elabora su hija.

Su meta es ayudar a su hija a comprarse un auto para facilitar  la entrega de sus prendas.
texts.en:
Rosa T. is an active member of the Communal Bank “Feria Libre” (Open Market). She lives in the Cebollar sector of San Pedro, which is known for its beautiful view of the city of Cuenca. Most of its residents engage in agriculture while the young people look for better opportunities in the city.

Rosa is 61 years old and has been separated from her spouse for three years. Her husband abandoned her after she suffered from a stroke and became invalid. Their marriage resulted in ten children, six of whom are married and live independently. Rosa’s other four children (ages 30, 27, 25, and 23) are single and live with her. Her 30 year old daughter works at her own business manufacturing sportswear and helps with the household finances. Her 27 year old son graduated with a degree in economics but has not yet secured a job. Her 25 year old son attends the university and is in his fifth year studying architecture. The youngest daughter is in her third year studying economics. The fruit of Rosa’s work has enabled her to build her own home.

Rosa is dedicated to farming and selling grains and legumes. She also raises chickens and pigs and helps her daughter with her business when she has free time. Rosa is a founding member of her Communal Bank, which she helped to establish twelve years ago with one of her friends. She says that the loans have benefited her by providing education for her children, a home, and a business for her daughter. With her new loan, Rosa will buy fabric, thread, zippers, buttons, and supplies for producing the clothing that her daughter manufactures.

Her goal is to help her daughter with purchasing a car to facilitate delivery of her garments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric, thread, zippers, buttons, and supplies for manufacturing sportswear

texts.es:
Vilma es socia del Banco Comunal Belen.
Vilma es casada, tiene 28 años y 3 hijos, Vilma junto a su esposo se dedica a la compra y venta de ganados, viaja a las ferias en donde compra los animales y los vende en la feria de Ayacucho.
Vilma necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ganado.
Vilma sueña con ampliar su negocio y que su hijo salga adelante.
texts.en:
Vilma is a member of the Belen Communal Bank. She is 28 years old, married, and has three children. Vilma and her husband buy and sell cattle. She travels to various fairs where she buys the animals and then sells them at the fair in Ayacucho.

Vilma needs a loan of 1050 PEN to invest in the purchase of cattle. She dreams of expanding her business so that her children can get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Martha Irene

texts.es: Martha Irene tiene 47 años. Su actividad económica es la venta de gaseosa y comedor.  Martha se dedica a este negocio desde hace 7 años, pues cuando dio inicio no tenía mucho capital, pues siempre busca la manera de generar ingresos para su familia. Pues anteriormente ella se dedicaba a docencia, anteriormente pues no le ajustaba para sufragar los gastos del hogar. Pues siempre había tenido las ideas de tener su propio local que le proporcionara ganancias fijas fue así como obtuvo. Este financiamiento será invertido en la compra de materia prima. Su deseo es tener su propio medio de transporte para comprar sus productos.
texts.en:
Martha Irene is 47 years old. She sells sodas and manages a diner. Martha has been in this business for seven years and had very little capital when she started. She always looks for ways to generate income for her family. Martha previously worked as a teacher, but this job was not enough to cover her household expenses. She always had ideas of opening her own business so that she could obtain a steady source of income.

This loan will be invested in the purchase of supplies. Her wish is to have her own form of transportation so that she can go buy products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Doris

texts.es: La Sra. Doris llego a las instalaciones de nuestra institucion por recomendacion de uno de nuestos clientes que ya habian sido beneficiado con en credito dentro de la institucion, la Sra. Doris vive en la zona de la Pampa de la Isla perteneciente a la cuidad de Santa Cruz Bolivia, cuenta con casa propia en la cual vive con sus tres hijos,  hace aproximadamente 1 año atras se habian separado con su esposo cuenta que fue dificil para ella la separacion pero supo reponerse por el bienestar de sus hijos, ahora ya se encuentra mejor, cuenta con negocio propio en su mismo domicilio esta es una tienda de barrio el la cual maneja desde hace 1 año, el monto del credito es para la inversion en el mismo negocio ya que comprará mercaderia, ya que por el momento no tiene competencia por donde vive ya que es la unica tienda de barrio, esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Doris was introduced to our institution by some of our customers who have benefited from a loan from our institution. Doris lives in the Pampa de la Isla area, an area that forms part of the town of Santa Cruz, Bolivia. She owns the house she lives in with her three children; she separated from her husband about 1 year ago: it has been difficult for her after they parted, but she managed to recover for the wellbeing of her children. Now she feels better and she runs her own business, a corner shop located in her house that she has been managing for 1 year. The amount she is requesting will be used to invest in her business by buying more products. There is not much competition in the area where she lives, as hers is the only corner shop there. She is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence shown in granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products to sell.

loans.name: Blanca Gladys

texts.es:
La señora Blanca Gladys G. es socia del banco Comunal  San Pedro,  vive en la Comunidad del mismo nombre  en  la  Parroquia Victoria de Portete que se encuentra ubicada en la parte suroccidental del cantón Cuenca. Limita al norte con la parroquia Tarqui, al este la parroquia Cumbe, al sur la periferia del cantón Girón y al oeste la parroquia San Gerardo perteneciente al cantón Girón y la parroquia Baños.  Un encantador lugar constituye El Portete de Tarqui donde se encuentra  un hermoso monumento en honor a los héroes de la Batalla de Tarqui, en este lugar se libró la batalla entre los ejércitos ecuatoriano y peruano, nuestro ejército estuvo comandado por el Gral. Antonio José de Sucre. 

Blanca tiene 36 años se encuentra casada y es madre de tres  hijos que se encuentran de 17, 15, 4 años,  sus dos hijos mayores trabajan en una vulcanizadora y ayudan un poco con la economía del hogar, su esposo es  albañil de oficio y  se encuentra construyendo  su casa y por el momento viven arrendando. Ella se dedica al bordado de  polleras  y fue su padre quien le enseño a realizar esta bonita actividad, también se dedica a los quehaceres domésticos en el cual trabaja de lunes a viernes de  07H30 hasta  las 16H00  y a  veces que le llaman a trabajar hasta los días domingos.

Se encuentra en su cuarto ciclo como miembro del banco comunal  invitada por su mamá y los créditos le han beneficiado su negocio de polleras,  su nuevo crédito va a invertir en la compra de pollos y chanchos y alimento  para empezar con un nuevo negocio.  Su meta es  llegar a tener un negocio de venta de polleras y que dios le conceda la salud para salir  adelante con su familia.
texts.en:
Blanca Gladys G. is a member of the San Pedro communal bank. She lives in the community of the same name in the parish of Victoria de Portete, located in the southwest part of the canton of Cuenca. It is bordered in the north by Tarqui parish, in the east by Cumbe parish, in the south by the edge of Girón canton, and in the west by San Gerardo parish in Girón canton and Baños parish. One nearby attraction is El Portete de Tarqui, where there is a beautiful monument in honor of the heroes of the Battle of Tarqui, which took place on this site between the Peruvian army and the Ecuadorian army commanded by General Antonio José de Sucre. Blanca is 36 years old and married. She is the mother of three children, aged 17, 15 and 4. Her two older children work in a vulcanizing plant, and they help a little with the household expenses. Her husband is a mason by trade, and he is currently building a house for the family. They are living in rented quarters for the moment. Blanca embroiders skirts; it was her father who taught her this attractive skill. She is also a domestic worker, and she works from Monday through Friday from 7:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Sometimes she is even called in to work until Sunday. She is in her fourth loan cycle as a member of the communal bank, to which she was invited by her mother. The loans have been beneficial for her skirt business. The new loan will be invested in purchasing pigs, chickens and animal feed to start a new business. Her goal is to be able to have a store where she sells her skirts, and she hopes that God will grant her health so she can help her family get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pigs, chickens and animal feed

texts.es:
Rocio es socia del Banco Comunal Belen.
Rocio es soltera y tiene 23 años, vive con sus padres, Rocio tiene un pequeño taller de confecciones en su casa, además trabaja en un taller de confecciones.
Rocio necesita un préstamo de 750 soles dinero que será invertido como parte de pago para comprar una maquina.
Rocio sueña con tener un taller grande con todas las maquinas y constituir una empresa de confección de polos.
texts.en:
Rocio is a member of Belen Community Bank.   Rocio is single, 23 years old and lives with her parents. Rocio has a small sewing shop in her home and also works at a sewing workshop.   Rocio needs a loan of 750 soles to be invested as part of a payment to buy a sewing machine.   Rocio dreams of having a large workshop, with all the equipment, and building a clothing company.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Kellogg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Alaine

texts.en:
Alaine S. is 20 and single with no children.  She owns a business venture of handicrafts.  Alaine has 2 years of experience in this business.  Alaine needs a loan of 1500 talas to purchase paints, brushes and carving equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or about US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Alaine joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Alaine's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  
http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: To purchase paints, brush and carving equipments

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Julio Cesar de 30 años de edad habita en la comaca El Jicaro de Nueva Guinea junto a su familia compuesta por su esposa Damaris Figueroa, y sus 3 hijos menores de edad, los cuales estudian primaria en la comarca. Julio desarrolla la actividad ganadera desde hace 10 años, logrando tener su propio inventario ganadero, ademas se dedica a la  venta de productos lacteos, comercialización de la producción de granos básico y venta de semoviente durante el año donde obtiene ingresos que le permiten el sosten familiar.  

Esta solicitando su 1er crédito para realizar la construción de una galera y corral, de esta menera desarrollar un ordeño limpio en condiciones de higiene, para vender un producto limpio y saludable para los consumidores. 

Su mayor sueño es mejorar la infraestructura de su finca, así  brindar mejores condiciones del manejo de su hato gandero, pues con esta mejora su finca seria de mayor valor y a su familia le dejaria un buen patrimonio cuando el falte.
texts.en:
Julio Cesar is 30 and lives in the town of El Jicaro de Nueva Guinea with his wife Damaris Figueroa, and their 3 children who study in primary school. Julio has worked raising cattle for the past ten years, and maintains a prosperous herd. He also sells milk products, basic grains and other agricultural products which allows him to sustain his family. Julio seeks his first microcredit loan to constuct a cattle pen and corral, in order to develop a milking station with adequate hygienic conditions for the production of clean and healthy products. His goal is to improve his production infrastructure to add value to his farm and expand his family's economic assets.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Cassetta, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of cattle pens and corral

loans.name: Marta

texts.es: Marta es una mujer muy emprendedora, tiene 45 años y vive al lado de sus dos hijos, quienes son su mayor motivo de salir adelante. Hace más de 16 años se dedica a la venta de enseres, piñatería y joyas, en un puesto que tiene dentro de un mercado de la zona en la que vive. Marta esta muy entusiasmada con su puesto, por lo que trabaja desde tempranas horas de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde vendiendo variedad de productos como joyas de reconocidas marcas, muñecas, objetos para fiestas infantiles, etc. Trata de mantener su establecimiento bien implementado, de esa manera pueda complacer a toda su clientela. Su mayor anhelo es colocar piso a su establecimiento y ampliarlo. Por ello trabajará  muy duro para concretar sus planes. Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual con todos los pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará el material necesario para instalar piso y de esa manera mejorar su infraestructura.
texts.en:
Marta, 45, is a very enterprising woman. She lives with her two children who are the motivating force behind her. For over 16 years she has sold home furnishings, piñatas and jewelry in a stall she has in a market near where she lives. Marta is very enthused with her stand so she works from very early in the morning until 6pm selling an assortment of products like well-known brand jewelry, dolls, children’s party supplies, etc. She tries to have her establishment well stocked so that she can please all her customers. Her greatest wish is to install a concrete floor and enlarge her establishment. She works hard to meet this goal. This will be her 4th loan with MFP and she pledges to be very punctual with her repayments. She will use the requested funds to buy the necessary materials to install the floor thereby improving its infrastructure.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To install a concrete floor in her establishment.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es: Norma tiene 33 años, casada con Adolfo de 40 años, quien se dedica a la agricultura, juntos tienen tres hijos, Wendy de 14 años, Andy de 09 años y Estrella de 05 años. Todos ellos viven en su casa propia. Desde hace varios años se dedica a vender Fruta de forma ambulatoria, dentro de uno de los mercados de la zona en la que vive, así como también a domicilio, donde previamente sus clientes le hacen el pedido respectivo. Mientras, su esposo Adolfo tiene varias chacras en Tingo María, ubicada en la selva central, lugar donde vive, ya que su oficio de agricultor no le permite descuidar de sus cultivos. Es por ello que Norma, cada 15 días viaja a esa ciudad para traer la cantidad de fruta que necesita para vender. En tanto, Adolfo va a visitar a su familia cada fin de mes. De esta manera, esta sacrificada pareja trabaja muy duro para sacar adelante a su familia, puesto que saben que todo esfuerzo tiene su recompensa. Este es su primer crédito con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual con todos los pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, lo utilizará para viajar a la selva y traer más mercadería, además quiere comprar cajas de madera, que es donde pone la fruta que ella ofrece.
texts.en:
Norma, 33 is married to Adolfo, 40, who is a farmer; they have three children: Wendy, 14, Andy, 9 and Estrella, 5, they all live together in their own home. She has been an itinerant fruit merchant for several years in one of the local markets where she lives; she also sells door-to-door filling previously placed orders from her customers. Meanwhile, her husband Adolfo has several fields in Tingo María, located in the central jungle, which is where he lives because farming does not permit him to neglect his crops. Because of this, Norma travels to that city every two weeks to bring the fruit she needs to sell. Adolfo comes to visit his family at the end of each month. This is how this very dedicated couple works hard and makes sacrifices for the success of their family because they know that every effort has its reward. This is her first loan with MFP and she pledges to repay in a timely fashion. She will use the funds to travel to the jungle to bring more merchandise; she also wants to buy wood crates which are what she uses to display her fruit for sale.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more fruit and wooden crates.

loans.name: Chera Mae

texts.en:
Chera Mae is the single mother of two kids. She is only 20 years old. She got involved in a hog-raising business because of her two children. She says that she has to work hard to be able to provide food for them. She also wants to save for their future. 

Currently, Chera Mae has one sow, one hog and five piglets. She says that it is not easy to sustain her pigs, so she joined CEVI to gain financial support. She applied for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos, which she will use to buy feed.

loans.use: To buy feed for pigs

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena, 50 years old, used to have difficulty looking for financial support for her hog-raising business. When she heard of CEVI, she immediately joined to gain access to its program. She says that she has no regrets about joining the MFI because it has been a big help to her business. She hopes its program expands so that more entrepreneurs can be helped. 

Elena is married with six children. She does her best to earn enough from her business so that she can provide for her family. She applied for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy feed for her pigs. She also needs materials for her pigpen.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda is a 59-year-old married woman from Surallah, South Cotabato, Philippines. She has eight children. Her eldest, who is age 36, does not live with them anymore. She is involved in rice farming and hog-raising. Her husband does the major tasks on the farm while she helps him keep it productive. She mostly spends time raising pigs. She says that she and her husband work hard to meet the increasing needs in their household. She also sought the help of CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines. She applied for a loan amounting to 15,000 Philippine pesos. She told CEVI that she will use the loan to buy farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She will also buy feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and feed

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.es: Vicenta R. reside en el departamento de La Unión, vive junto a su hija y dos nietos de 4 y 5 años de edad. A sus 63 años de edad, Vicenta trabaja día con día comerciando ropa para mujeres, la cual vende por los diferentes cantones y caseríos cercanos a La Unión, incluso ella prefiere caminar largos trayectos para llegar a lugares muy remotos, en los cuales a pesar del enorme cansancio y esfuerzo, los prefiere ya que son pocas las ventas que existen en esas zonas, en donde muchas personas la esperan para poder adquirir sus productos. Vicenta solicita un préstamo para poder invertir en su negocio, de manera que pueda comprar mayor cantidad de ropa y de esta forma obtenerla a precios más bajos lo cual le permite vender más barato y así obtener nuevos clientes. A pesar de su edad Vicenta se esfuerza día con día para poder obtener el sustento diario y así mismo para todos sus gastos personales.
texts.en:
Vicenta R. lives in the Department of La Union with her daughter and two grandchildren, ages 4 and 5. At 63, Vicenta is still working every day. Her trade is women’s clothing, which she sells in the communities and villages near La Union. She prefers walking to remote areas. To her, it’s worth the effort and fatigue; few people sell clothing in these places, so there are plenty of potential customers. Vicenta has requested a loan so that she can invest in her business by buying more clothing. If she buys more at once, she’ll be able to pay a lower price, sell for less, and earn more new customers. Despite her age, Vicenta works every day to earn a living and keep up with her personal expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing.

loans.name: Emilio Mardoqueo

texts.es: Emilio Mardoqueo M. P. de 30 años de edad, vive en el municipio de Delicias de Concepción, ubicado en el departamento de Morazán, lugar en el cual vive junto a compañera de vida, su padre de 62 años de edad y su madre de 50 años de edad quien se encarga de los quehaceres del hogar. Emilio es un joven muy trabajado quien debe esforzarse por llevar el sustento diario a su familia, ya que en la actualidad es el único que tiene trabajo. Emilio posee una tapicería en la cual se encarga de reparar todo tipo de muebles hechos a base de madera, es muy conocido en su zona de trabajo por realizar excelentes reparaciones. Él solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar una pick up con el cual pueda trasportar los muebles reparados para dejarlos a domicilio, esto le permitirá cobrar un poco más de manera que pueda obtener mayores ingresos lo cual sea de muchos beneficios para su hogar.
texts.en:
Emilio Mardoqueo M. P., 30, lives in Delicias de Concepción, Morazán department, with his life partner, his 62-year-old father and his 50-year-old mother, who is in charge of household chores. Emilio is a hard-working young man who must work hard to bring daily support to his family because he is the only one currently working. Emilio has an upholstery shop where he repairs all kinds of wood furniture; he is very well-known in his area because he makes excellent repairs. He is asking for funds with which to buy a pick-up truck so that he can transport the repaired furniture and make home deliveries. This will allow him to charge a bit more so that his income will increase thus providing many benefits for his home.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a pick-up for home deliveries.

loans.name: María Dolores

texts.es: María Dolores G.  D. M. D. 50 años D. edad, es una señora acompañada, quien trabaja vendiendo huevos D. forma ambulante, así mismo comercializa queso y crema, en las diferentes colonias D. Tonacatepeque, en el departamento D. San Salvador, lugar en el cual resiD. también. Así mismo su esposo es comerciante ambulante, forma en la cual ambos se han ganado la vida por más D. 10 años. María es muy trabajadora y dedicada a lo que hace por lo que su mayor deseo es poder aumentar la cantidad D. huevos  que comercializa y D. esta manera contar con la posibilidad D. ofrecerlos por mayor a tiendas y otros tipos D. negocios en los cuales se comercializan productos alimenticios. D. esta manera ella podrá contar con clientes los cuales compren por mayor, aumentando D. esta manera sus ventas. Es por esto que María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para realiza el deseo D. mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
María Dolores G. D. M. is a married woman of 50. She works selling eggs, cheese and fresh cream in the neighborhoods of Tonacatepeque, in the province of San Salvador where she is resident. Her husband is also a salesman, and together they have sustained themselves for the past 10 years. María is a dedicated and responsible worker. She strives to increase the quantity of eggs available in order to expand her sales to stores and other wholesale businesses. In this way she can supply her products to larger establishments for increased stability and sales volume. By expanding into wholesale supply, she hopes to greatly improve her business and profits.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Cassetta, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wholesale quantities of eggs

loans.name: Virgilio

texts.es: Virgilio Q. de 60 años de edad, reside en el municipio de San Martín, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador lugar en el cual vive junto a su compañera de vida, la cual se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar. El señor Virgilio posee un molino el cual alquila para que las personas muelan la comida, así mismo comercializa hielo, leña, maíz,arroz especias y otros productos más, todo esto con el fin de poder ganarse la vida de una forma digna. Virgilio desea mucho poder brindarle todo lo necesario a su esposa, quien le ayuda a atender el negocio, por lo que solicita un préstamo a través del cual el pueda comprar mayor cantidad de maíz, leña, y especias, los cuales son los productos que más vende, así mismo poder darle el mantenimiento necesario para el molino para ofrecer un servicio optimo y de esta manera contar con más clientes.
texts.en:
Virgilio Q., 60, lives in San Martín, San Salvador department with his life partner who is a housewife. Virgilio has a mill that he leases out to folks so that they can grind their food; he also sells ice, firewood, rice, spices and other products; all this aiming at earning a living in a dignified manner. Virgilio would very much like to provide everything for his wife who helps him with the business. He is asking for funds to buy larger amounts of corn, firewood and spices which are the items he sells the most. He would also like to provide maintenance to the mill so that he an offer optimal service thereby attracting more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood and corn.

loans.name: Gene

texts.en:
Gene, a 37-year-old farmer, plows a rice field and raises pigs to earn a living. He works hard on his farm to support his two children. His eldest child is 13 years old. He wants them to finish their studies and he is sending them to school. He wants to improve his farm to have greater earnings.

Gene heard that Community Economic Ventures, Inc. offers financial assistance to entrepreneurs like him. He joined and requested a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos to support his business on the farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: José Mauricio

texts.es: José Mauricio M. D.  de 53 años de edad, posee una tienda de productos comestibles, la cual esta ubicada en la ciudad de Soyapango, lugar en el cual también se ubica su hogar y en donde vive junto a su esposa la cual se encarga de administrar la tienda, así mismo vive junto a su nieto de 4 años de edad. El negocio esta ubicado sobre calle principal, así mismo es la única tienda que se encuentra en los alrededores, por lo que cuenta con mucha clientela fija, la cual compra a diario. Esto es de mucho beneficio para José ya que el negocio es bastante estable, es por esta razón que él solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar productos alimenticios como pan, café, pollo, huevos, ya que en la actualidad con lo que más cuenta es con golosinas y bebidas. Poder mejorar el negocio es de mucha importancia para José debido a que es la única fuente de ingresos que posee, razón por la cual él desea mucho mejorarlo para obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
José Mauricio M. D. is 53 years old and has a grocery store located in the city of Soyapango. His house is located in this same city. He lives with his wife, who is in charge of running the store, and his 4-year-old grandson. The business is located on the main street, and is also the only store found in the area, which lets him depend upon many regular customers who go there to do their daily shopping. This is very beneficial for José and has made his business rather stable. He is asking for a loan to buy products such as bread, coffee, chicken, and eggs, as right now he mainly has sweets and beverages. It is very important to José to improve his business since it is his only source of income. He desires to improve it in order to achieve higher earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bread, coffee, chicken, and eggs

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.en:
“Before, my harvest was only small because of financial shortage. But when CEVI came, my harvest improved because of my loans,” shares 42-year-old Ernesto. He is married with two children who go to school. He does his best to provide for his family, especially for his children’s education.

Ernesto is requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which he will use to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He likes CEVI’s program because of its low interest rate.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
“Farming was really hard for me before, because I had to borrow money from individuals who charge very high interest,” shares Josephine. She felt she was not really earning. In May, 2008, she learned of CEVI and the low interest rate it offers. She joined the MFI and has been earning little by little since then. She says that her loans really helped in improving the size of her harvest. She was even able to start raising pigs out of her income from the farm. Now, she mostly spends time raising pigs while her husband maintains the farm.

 Josephine requests a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos that she will use to acquire farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She will also buy feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and feed

loans.name: Ma. Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is a hard-working mother of five children. She is 44 years old and married. She grows pigs for a living. She also makes candies that she sells around her neighborhood. She said that sometimes it is hard to sell her pigs and candies because of competition but she is happy to share that she has regular customers. She hopes for her ventures to grow.

Lilibeth has been a member of CEVI for more than a few years now. She says that because of the financial support that she gained for her business, she was able to have 3 of her children finish high school. She dreams for all five of her children to finish college. She recently applied for a loan of PHP15,000 that she will use to buy additional piglets and feed, and also ingredients that she uses to make candies. She also wants to buy chickens that she could raise.

loans.use: To purchase feed and supplements.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane, 56, is a rice farmer in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She also owns a sari-sari store as additional income for her family. She is a mother of 3 children, her eldest is 17 years old. She started her business in 2008. She's now requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. for 15,000 PHP. This will enable her to buy farm supplies and groceries for her businesses.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and farm supplies.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is happy that her hogs are healthy. She said that she owes it to her loans from CEVI because she was able to acquire feed that she needed. She hopes for her business to grow more. She also said that her loans helped her to earn and enabled her to send her children to school. Now a widow, she works hard so that she can provide for the increasing needs of her household. 

Margarita would like to request for a loan of PHP15,000. She told CEVI that she would use this loan to acquire additional piglets and feeds.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets and feed.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is involved in a hog-raising business. She is 66 years old, married and has eight children. Her older children don’t live with them anymore. She said that she works hard to provide for the needs of her household. She has been raising hogs for more than a few years now and she is happy that it gives her income. She also opened a small store where she sells vinegar, sugar and other merchandise. She said that the store helps provide for some of their daily needs. She hopes to improve her family’s living condition and she does her best to achieve that. She applied for a loan of PHP15,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., where she is a member. If granted, she will use the loan to buy feed for her hogs and she will also purchase additional merchandise for her store.

loans.use: To purchase hogfeed and merchandise for the store.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en: 38-year-old Marilou is a married woman from South Cotabato, Philippines. She has children who go to school. She raises hogs for a living. She also retails rice at her sari-sari store. Last year, Marilou became a member of CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines. She was happy to have gained access to this program. She particularly likes its low interest rate, which she thinks is very helpful to small businesses like hers. She recently applied for another loan amounting to PHP10,000. She will use this loan to buy feeds and additional piglets. She will also acquire rice that she caqn retail at her store.

loans.use: To purchase feed and additional shop merchandise.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en: “I sold two hogs last December for 14,000 pesos ”, Rosa happily shares about her business. She has been raising hogs for almost three years now. She is 56 years old and has seven children. She is now a widow and does her best to provide for her children. Sometimes she feels like quitting but she gets motivated by her children to continue living. She also thanks God for the strength she has. One of her goals is to improve her family’s living conditions. She recently applied for a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI. She will use it to buy additional piglets and feed. This loan will help sustain Rosa’s business.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rosana, age 47, owns a store where she sells vegetables and other merchandise. She also raises pigs. She has four children, all of whom attend school. One of Rosana's dreams in life is to have all her children finish college and have successful lives. 

Rosana is a member of CEVI and is grateful and happy to have access to its programs. She tells us that her loans have helped both her business and her family. She is now applying for a loan of Php15, 000. She will use it to buy more vegetables and other merchandise for her store. She also hopes to buy additional piglets and food for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and other merchandise for her store

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en: Salvacion is 60 years old and grows pigs for a living. She is married and has three children. Salvacion used to have difficulties finding money to fund her business. In 2008, she learned of CEVI through her friends who were active entrepreneurs. She joined because she really needed financial support for her business. She said she has no regrets about joining because the MFI’s program has been very helpful to her until now. She is now requesting a loan of Php 15,000 that she will use to buy supplements and feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Myadagmaa

texts.en:
Myadagmaa is 36 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house. Her daugther, Tsendsuren, is 14 years old and attends a local secondary school. Her husband is a working engineer in a company. 

During the day, Myadagmaa operates an underwear-trading business at a local market called Narantuul. For her retail business, she purchases a variety of products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, and resells them for a profit. She started her business in 1999 with working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (about $36). After years of successful operations, she has managed to increase her working capital to a level exceeding 2,000,000 tugrugs (about $1,445) today.

Myadagmaa has good communication skills and her business is very important to her. She says, “I would like to provide a good education for my daughter.” She is requesting a loan to purchase a large amount of underwear to sell to her many customers.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Johna

texts.en: Johna, 28, is a resident of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She is a rice and pig farmer, managing a rice field and a piggery. She has two children to support; the eldest is 9 years old. She lacks capital, that's why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., and requested a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos. This loan will help her a lot by providing fertilizers for her rice field and feed for her pigs.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine, 40, is a rice farmer in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She needs farm supplies to operate in her rice field but she lacks capital so she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP. This loan will enable her to purchase the supplies needed for her farm. She is the mother of five children. Rice farming is the only way she can provide the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie, 46, is involved in both rice farming and pig raising businesses. She also manages a sari-sari (variety) store. She started her business way back in 2005.  She is now managing a one-hectare rice field in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.  She loves her work on the farm.  She is the mother of seven children.  She strives hard in order to provide the basic needs of the family.

She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to support financing her farm.  With this amount, she will be able to buy seeds and farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
This is Lorna, 43, a rice farmer from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.  She manages a rice field.  She also has a hog raising business.  Lorna supports her family of six children. The eldest is 21 years old.  She works hard in order to have a good harvest.

She is limited in her working capital so she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to get a loan.  Lorna is requesting 6,000 PHP to support her business in the buying of seeds and farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies and seeds

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of income for Lourdes, 49.  She is also involved in her businesses of quail raising and canteen vending. She has 100 quail and sells their eggs at her canteen. She supports her 9-year old child.

Lourdes joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to get a loan with low interest to finance her businesses.  She’s requesting 15,000 PHP to buy farm necessities so she can sustain her family.

loans.use: farm supplies and feed for quail

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en: 53-year-old Pacita has a hog raising business.  She started her business in 2008.  Her business is located in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.  She joined  Community Economic Ventures, Inc. this year, 2010, in order to finance her business while paying low interest.  Now she would like to request a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy more pigs and feed for her piggery business.

loans.use: pigs and feed

loans.name: Pelagia

texts.en:
Pelagia's rice farming business is improving with the financial help offered by micro-finance institutions.  She has been a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., an MFI, since 2008.  She was able to finance her business with a small interest charge.

Now she requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to continue to support her rice field.  She is glad that her daily needs are met by the income she receives.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Agapita

texts.en:
Agapita T. is from the village of Annafunan West, Tuguegarao City. She is 47 years old. Agapita is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Agapita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken for sale. Agapita is just starting this business.

Agapita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agapita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Agapita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Aiza

texts.en: Aiza is 26 years old, supporting three children in the family. She has a business of rice farming in Agusan Del Sur. She sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to access a loan. She will use the loan to buy the pesticides and seeds necessary for her farm. Having pesticides for her farm will help her make a good harvest. She requested a loan of 4,000 PHP. This amount will help her sustain her family and her business.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Alentina

texts.en: Alentina, 60, is a rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur. She started planting rice in 1997. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to financially support her farm. Now she has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP. This will be helpful in buying farm supplies necessary for the rice field. She is a mother of one child. With her rice farming, she provides the daily needs of her family.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo C. is from the village of Brgy. Curifang, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 53 years old, married, and has 5 adult-aged children. Reynaldo owns and operates a business providing recycling services. The main source of income for the business comes from hauling junk and other waste material for local businesses and community members. Reynaldo has been involved in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Reynaldo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynaldo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase used bottles and newspapers to sell. Reynaldo is requesting a new loan, his fourth, of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional waste and junk material to sell. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional waste and junk material to sell

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena D., 55 years old, raises pigs. She has seven children. She said she has piglets in her barn and she also has a one-hectare farm. She grows rice to be able to supplement the family income. She would like to request a loan of 6,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to improve her harvest. She likes the CEVI services because it gives micro-insurance coverage to all its clients.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Analie

texts.en:
30-year-old Analie tills a rice field in Agusan Del Sur. Rice farming is the only way she can provide the needs of her family. Analie supports three children. She needs additional capital to run her rice farming business. She lacks fertilizers and seeds. 

Community Economic Ventures, Inc. gives her an opportunity to access a loan to purchase what she needs for the farm. She requested a loan of 12,000 PHP. This will be helpful in buying supplies in order to produce a harvest in the future.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Emilio

texts.en: Emilio E., 58 years old, owns a small sari-sari store and sells various types of goods in Banga, South Cotabato. She has one child. She works so hard to be able to help her husband provide for all the needs in their family. In her store, she also displays feed because a lot of people are raising pigs in their location. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store.

loans.use: Additional merchandise to resell

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en: Arlene, 39, is a rice farmer in Agusan Del Sur. She works hard to earn a living in rice farming. She has requested a loan of 12,000 Php to support her business. She needs to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farm. She has been a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. since 2000. She likes the services it offers to entrepreneurs like her and has a low interest rate for the loan.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny I. has successfully harvested sixty sacks of rice from her 2-hectare (5-acre) farm. She wants to make it double and she needs additional capitalization to make it happen.

Jenny has two children and her eldest child is 18. Everything she earns from her farm goes directly towards her children’s needs. She started farming in 1996. Until now, she likes growing rice because it is what sustains her family.

Jenny requested a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. and will use the loan to buy farm supplies. She said, “What I like about CEVI is that they really have a good program that really helps the poor.”

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo G. is from the city of Bagumbayan, Tuguegarao City. He is 51 years old. Eduardo is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Eduardo owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and drinks to passengers in the bus terminal. Eduardo has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Eduardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eduardo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Eduardo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Jerry Y., 43 years old, started his piggery business last month. He was inspired by other clients of Community Economic Ventures Inc. who succeeded in their business. Aside from raising pigs, he also sells meat. He goes door-to-door to sell the meat.

The income, Jerry gets from his business goes towards the needs of his family. He has five children and all are studying. His eldest child is 15. He is working very hard to be able to provide all the needs of his family. 

Jerry is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy piglets and feed.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is the mother of two children. She started running a business in rice and pig farming in 1987. At present she manages a piggery and plans to buy more pigs. That’s why she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan and provide farm supplies for her businesses.

Arlene requested a loan of 7,000 Php. She hopes that with farming, the needs of her family will be met.

loans.use: To buy piglets and farm supplies

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina P., 55 years old, is a rice grower. She lives in Banga, South Cotabato. She has nine children and her eldest child is already 35.

Josefina maintains a 4-hectare (10-acre) farm but, because, she doesn’t own the land, she doesn’t get to keep all the harvest. Aside from rice, she also grows corn and cassava. She is planting several crops because she wants to earn more for her family’s needs.

Josefina would like to obtain a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. which she will use to buy farm supplies to increase her harvest. She chose CEVI because it has the smallest interest rate and it offers micro-insurance coverage to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy P., 39 years old, is a farmer and an accessory vendor in Banga, South Cotabato. She said she sells accessories, necklaces and wristwatches to maximize her time, especially because she has bigger needs in her family. She has two children and her eldest child is 10 years old.

Nancy dreams that all her children will finish their studies. She also dreams of a more stable business so that she will be able to provide whatever her children need. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 4,000 to buy farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and more accessories to sell

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon S. is from the barangay of Annafunan West, Tuguegarao City. She is 44 years old. Corazon is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Corazon works in someone else's service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing laundry services in the local community. Corazon has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide services. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Corazon from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Bonifacio

texts.en:
Bonifacio’s rice field needs additional capital to be successful. Bonifacio is a 47-year-old entrepreneur from Agusan Del Sur. He does rice farming to support his family. He’s a widower and has three children.

Bonifacio partners with Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because it has a low interest rate on the loan. He requested a loan of 11,000 Php. The loan will be helpful for him to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Boldbaatar

texts.en:
Boldbaatar S., 44, is married and is the father of three children. He and his family live together in a ger (the Mongolian traditional nomadic tent). His oldest two sons, ages 21 and 20, are university students; his youngest son, an 8-year-old, attends a local primary school.

Boldbaatar operates a shoe-manufacturing business with his wife. His oldest son, Bayrsaihan, helps with the business during the summer holidays. Boldbaatar has been operating his business since 1996, and has steadily expanded his business. He manufactures shoes at his home, and sells them in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. With his earnings, he has been paying his two sons' university tuition fees and providing money towards his family’s expenses.

Boldbaatar is an experienced shoe manufacturer who has been in business for many years. He is a very hardworking and honest person. He says, “Now, the most important thing for me is to pay my two sons' university fees until they graduate. After they graduate from university, I am planning to create my own shoe manufacturing workshop.”

Boldbaatar is requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of materials used to manufacture shoes.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of materials needed to manufacture shoes

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita L. is from the city of Annafunan West, Tuguegarao City. She is 56 years old. Teresita is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support extended members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Edioselyn

texts.en:
Edioselyn L., 42 years old, is a pig grower from Banga, South Cotabato. She started her business in 1998 and likes what she’s doing because she is able to earn income from this endeavor.

Edioselyn has three children and her eldest child is 11 years old. She works so hard to support their education. That is why today, she would like to establish her business.

Edioselyn would like to request a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy piglets and feed so that she will be able to raise more pigs for a better income.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Marilyn's Group

texts.en:
Marilyn T. is from the village of San Pedro, San Pablo, Aurora, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Marilyn is the group leader for a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marilyn T.'s Group.

Marilyn is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Marilyn owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand the range of products offered. This loan will be Marilyn's fifth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the range of products offered.

location.town: San Pedro San Pablo, Aurora, Isabela

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma C. is from Barangay Quezon, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Alma is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Alma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
