Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Alma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand the range of products offered. This loan will be Alma's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the range of products offered

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad is continually working in her rice field. She works hard in tilling the land to have an abundant harvest. However, she lacks capital to buy farm supplies. That’s why she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan.

Caridad requested 7,000 Php to supply her rice field. She has five children and hopes that her family will be sustained.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Emelina

texts.en:
Emelina D., 51 years old, lives El Nonok, South Cotabato. She has four children, the eldest being 27.

Emelina has multiple businesses: she supplies water, sells coconut juice, grows pigs and has a farm. She is doing all these things to be able to support the needs of her family. She said that she has more plans for her businesses and wants to make them better. That is why she needs additional capital to make it happen.

Emelina would like to request Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and piglets for her piggery business.

loans.use: To buy piglets and farm supplies

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife M. is from Barangay Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old. Marife is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Marife owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Marife has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marife joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marife has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to pay for services to increase crop yield. Marife is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This loan will be Marife's seventh loan from ASKI.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Leo James

texts.en:
Leo James C. is from the village of Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Neuva Vizcaya. He is 22 years old. Leo James is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Leo James owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motorcycle transport services. Leo James has been engaged in his business for over nine years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Leo James joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leo James has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Leo James is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Leo James from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Darlina

texts.en: Forty-two-year-old Darlina, who is married and has four children, manages a rice field in Agusan Del Sur.   She is requesting a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. for Php 7,000 in order to purchase farm supplies.  CEVI offers the lowest available interest rate and the loan would be of great help in financing her field.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Tursunova Ozodahon`s Group

texts.ru:
Озадахон, 30, замужем. Ее супруг работает прорабом.У нее  4 детей: дочерям 12 и 7 лет, сыну 10 и 2 года. 'Дети учатся в школе, самый младший ходит в садик.Клиентка занимается оптовой реализацией фруктов и овощей. Клиент на кредит планирует закупить для реализации помидоры, клубнику и огурцы. 

Потмахон, 51, вдова. У нее 5 детей: сыну 29 лет, дочери 21 лет, невестке 28 и внукам 2 года и 1 год. Сын занимается частным извозом пассажиров, дочь и невестка член крестьянского хозяйства. Клиент посеяла хлопок, а также присматривает за живностью. На кредит она закупит удобрения для хлопчатника.

Мадинахон, 19, замужем. Она  проживает вместе супругом и его родителями. Они с семьей посеяли хлопчатник, дом расположен на природе, часто сдают в аренду помещение отдыхающим. Кредит необходим для закупа минеральных удобрений.

Муминахон, 48, замужем. Ее супруг работает частным строителем. Ее старший сын частный строитель, а младший находится на заработках в РФ. Они также занимаются полеводством. Кредит запрашивается для закупа минеральных удобрений для хлопчатника.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Ozadahon is 30 years old, she is married. Her husband works as a foreman. She has four children: the daughters are twelve and seven and sons are ten and two years old. Her children go to school and the youngest one goes to kindergarten. She sells fruits and vegetables in wholesale. She plans to use the loan to buy tomatoes, strawberries and cucumbers for resale. Potmahon is 51 years old, she is a widow. She has five children: her son is 29, her daughter is 21 years old, her daughter-in-law is 28 and her grandchildren are two and one years old. Her son has a private taxi business and her daughter and daughter-in-law are members of the farmer's union. Potmahon sowed cotton and is also taking care of livestock. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer for the cotton. Madinahon is 19, she is married. She lives with her husband and his parents. Their family has sown cotton, also their house is located in the nature and they often rent it out to vacationers. They need the loan to buy a mineral fertilizer. Muminahon is 48 years old, she is married. Her husband works in construction. Her oldest son is also a construction worker and her youngest one is now working in the Russian Federation. They are also in agriculture. They are asking for a loan to buy mineral fertilizer for cotton.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, strawberries, cucumbers

loans.name: Doljinsuren

texts.en:
Doljinsuren A., 56, lives with her husband and two children in an apartment in Tuv province, Mongolia. She has a 22-year old son and a 19-year-old daughter, both university students. Her husband, Battulga, runs a transportation business while she has operated a cafe since 1993, steadily expanding it over the past 17 years. Doljinsuren cooks a variety of meals, and her friend Dolgor is responsible for the cafe's finances.

Doljinsuren has been paying for her children's university tuition fees and providing money for her family expenses with the proceeds from her business. A hardworking person and a very good mother and businesswoman, the most important thing to her is to be financially secure until her two children graduate their universities. She is now requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to use for her son's university graduation ceremony.

loans.use: To use for her son's university graduation

loans.name: Libertino's Group

texts.en:
Libertino S. is from the village of Mozzozzin, Santa Maria, Isabela. He is 47 years old. Libertino is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Libertino is single. To make a living, Libertino owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Libertino has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Libertino joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Libertino has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. Libertino is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Libertino from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Marilou's Group

texts.en:
Marilou G. is from the village of Padul, Solana, Cagayan. She is 28 years old. Marilou is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marilou is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Marilou owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Marilou joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Marilou from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Joomartbek's Group

texts.ru:
Жоомартбек, 20. Клиент холост, но живет с матерью, с братом который занимается реализацией цемента, с младшим братом который занимается сельским хозяйством, и с сестрой которая учится в 1-классе. Сам также работает со старшим братом. Кредит запрашивается для закупа цемента для дальнейшей реализации.

Анипахан, 32, замужем. Супруг занимается наемной работой, зарплата в месяц составляет около 40 долларов. У нее 5 детей: дочерям (12,9,7,1) лет, сыну 9 лет. Она занимается животноводством: откорм и разведение КРС. Клиентка имеет 2 беременых коровв, с июля месяца планирует реализовать молоко. На кредит она закупит минеральные удобрения на 5000 сом, и на 5000 сом распашет землю.

Гулкакы, 24, замужем. . Ее сын дошкольного возраста, за ним присматривает мать. Клиент занята оптовой реализацией древесины. Бизнесом занимается вместе с супругом. Древисину закупает у народа и реализует в разные районы по заказу. Кредит запрашивается для закупа древисины для увеличение товарооборота.

Гулсайрахон, 32, замужем. Супруг на заработках в РФ, занимается строительством. Она занимается полеводством, выращивание и реализация  сельхозпродукции. На земельном наделе (0,40 га), уже посеяли семена картофеля. Кредит нужен для закупа удобрений.

Мукарам, замужем. У нее 3 детей. Она вместе с супругом занимаются полеводством. В этои году посеяли хлопок. Кредит запрашивается для закупа минеральных удобрений. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Joomartbek is twenty. He is a bachelor and lives with his mother and brother who sells cement, as well as his younger brother who is in agriculture and sister who is in first grade of school. He also works with his older brother. He is asking for a loan to buy cement for future resale. Anipahan is 32, she is married. Her husband does work for hire and his monthly salary is $40 a month. She has five children: her daughters are twelve, nine, seven and one years old, and her son is nine. She does animal husbandry, feeds and breeds large cattle. She has two pregnant cows and plans to start selling milk starting in July. She will use the loan to buy mineral fertilizer with 5000 soms and will plow the land with another 5000 soms. Gulkaky is 24 years old, she is married. Her son is in preschool age, her mother looks after him. The client sells wood in wholesale. She is in this business together with her husband. They buy the wood from the people and sells to different regions. She is asking for a loan to buy wood and increase sales. Gulsayrahon is 32, she is married. Her husband is working in the Russian Federation in construction. She works in the fields, grows and sells crops. On her plot of land (0.40 hectares = about 1 acre) have already been sown potato seeds. She needs the loan to buy fertilizer. Mukaram is married. She has three children. She and her husband are in agriculture. This year they sowed cotton. She is asking for a loan to buy mineral fertilizer.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cement

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en: Nergui B. is 56 years old and lives with his wife in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent) in Tuv province, Mongolia. All of his children are grown up and live separately from them. Nergui's wife, Tsend-Ochir, receives a pension from the government. Nergui earns his living by operating a taxi service business. He has been operating his business since 2005, and is an experienced driver.  He spends his earnings on his family. He has been planning to expand and renovate his winter house. Nergui is a very hardworking and honest person. He is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to repair the car that he has been using for his taxi service.

loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Thinh's Group

texts.en:
Thinh T. T. is 45 years old. She lives in Co Duong village. She has two children who are going to school. She and her husband are farmers who grow vegetables and breed pigs. They have a monthly income of about 2,500,000 VND. With such a low income, they find it very difficult to raise their children. Mrs Thinh has participated in SEDA's microfinancing program since 2007 and has repaid punctually. She is very happy because she can save money each week. She is the group leader of a 6-member SEDA group loan. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy 50 chickens. Hopefully, this plan will turn a profit so that her family may afford to buy more household appliances.

About the other borrowers in her group: Lien T. T. is 40 years old. She sells chickens in the market. She wants to borrow 7.194.000 VND to expand her business. Dong T. T. T. is 32 years old. She is a hairdresser. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to invest in her shop. Trong T. T. is 46 years old. She wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND to breed chickens. Bac T. T. is 55 years old. She wants to borrow 2,398,000 VND to breed pigs. Tham T. T. is 37 years old. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND for her small business.

loans.use: to buy 50 chickens

loans.name: Nguyet's Group

texts.en:
Nguyet T. N. is 28 years old. She lives in Co Duong, Tien Duong, Dong Anh. She is married with two children. She makes tofu at home, and then she sells it in the market. She has been doing this work for two years. Not to waste, she also raises pigs and poultry. She has a monthly income of about $160. She has participated in SEDA's micro-financing program since 2007 and has repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 2,834,000 VND to buy beans to make tofu.

About the other one in her group:
Phuong T. N. is 34 years old. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to breed chickens.

loans.use: to buy beans to make tofu

loans.name: Joel's Group

texts.en:
Joel S. is from the village of Alimanao, Peñablanca, Cagayan. He is 31 years old, single, and the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Joel has had a motorcycle transportation service for over 8 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

Joel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in his business. This will be the first loan taken out by Joel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support his family. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a vehicle used in his transportation business

loans.name: Burabaeva Kenzhekan Group

texts.en:
B. Kenzhekan is the leader of the group. She is the resident of Balykchy.  Kenzhekan is 48 years old, she's married and has raised 2 daughters. Both of them are involved in education, the older one is a student of the 4-th year, the younger one studies at school, in the 11-th class. Her husband is engaged in agriculture and cattle breeding. Kenzhekan is engaged in increasing the livestock too, she sells about 3 sheep monthly, to cover family expenses. She also sells milk in order to make money. So she earns about 3000 soms (65.48$) per month. Money received from the loan, she'll spend to buy small cattle in order to increase its number. In future she wishes to repair the house and plans to save money to pay for her daughter's education in university.

T. Batina is 49, she's divorced and has 2 sons. The older one is 26, he works in the firm - "Aman Jol" located in Karakol. The other son is 18, he's a pupil of 11-th class. 10 years ago Batina began to work in Bishkek on Alamedin market, where she sold fruits and vegetables. The initial amount of her business activity was 1000 soms (21.82$). And now her income is 6000 soms (130.95$) per month. As a result she built a house for her older son and bought a car. Batina wants to get a loan in order to buy fruits and vegetables, and so to resell it further.

S. Dinara is the treasurer of the group. She's 37 years old and she's married. There are 4 children in their family: 3 sons and a daughter. A daughter and an older son studies at school, others are preschool age. Dinara works a teacher of chemistry and biology at school. Her husband is a constructor, when he's free he looks after the children and helps Dinara with housework. They need a loan to buy 30 chickens and seeds of potatoes for sowing. In future Dinara wants to repair the house, increase the livestock and educate her children.

K. Sabyrbek is 55, he's married and has a son. His son is 18, and he's a pupil of the 11-th class. Sabyrbek has his private store where he sells convenience goods. He started his business activity 15 years ago, with the initial amount of 10000 soms (218.24$). So now he earns 6000 soms (130.95$) per month. He needs a loan to purchase goods in order increase the turnover and the range of goods.  In future Sabyrbek wants his son to enter the university.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy small cattle

loans.name: Alymbaeva Mayramkul Group

texts.en:
A. Mayramkul is the leader of the group. Mayramkul is the resident of Karabalta, a small town nearby the capital - Bishkek. She's 50 years old, married and raised 4 children: 2 sons and 2 daughters. The older son is 21, he works in a police department. The other one is 19 and he's a loader. A 13 years old daughter studies at school, her older sister is 15, she works as a seller. Mayramkul's husband works in village police department, he's a deputy chief over there. 3 years ago Mayramkul got a loan, on money received she bought groceries for retail selling. The initial amount was 15000 soms (327,36 $). Her older daughter always helps her in their business activity. As a result of this activity they could buy cattle for breeding and now they earn nearly 4000 soms (87.3 $) per month. They need  a loan for purchasing consumer goods to increase the turnover and further resale it. In future she's planning to open a new store.

K. Edil is 37 years old. He's married and has 2 daughters. The older one is a pupil. Edil is engaged in private transportation of passengers around the city. He began his business activity 2 years ago, the initial sum was 1000 $.On this money he bought a car and began to transport passengers, so now he earns 8000 soms (174.5$) per month. His wife sells dishes on the market. Thanks to their activity they could buy 2 cows and 10 sheep. Money received from loan, they will spend on purchasing different dishes in order to increase a range and a turnover. In near future Edil plans to increase the livestock.

K. Daktoorkan is 43, she's married and has 3 children: a son and 2 daughters. Her son and an older daughter are students, the younger one studies at school. Daktoorkan and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding for 16 years, in order to make money she also sells milk. The initial amount of their business activity was 15000 soms (327.4$). They got these money from loan, so they could buy cattle and now their monthly income is 6000 soms (130.95$). Daktoorkan wants to get a loan, because they need money to cultivate the land. In future she wishes to buy a big house.

T. Gulzat is the treasurer of the group. She is 25. 2 years ago, she had 1500 soms (32.73$), and her sister suggested her to buy a sewing machine for providing sewing services. On this money Gulzat bought a machine, and started to sew different clothes for selling. Now she earns 4000 soms (87.3$) per month and she wants to get a loan, because she needs more fabrics in order to expand her business.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: for purchasing consumer goods to increase the turnover

loans.name: Meerim Osmonalieva Group

texts.en:
O. Meerim is the leader of the group. She's 36 years old. Meerim is married and has 2 children: a daughter and a son. Her son studies at school, he's 14 years old. And her daughter is just 3. Meerims's husband helps her with housework. Both of them are engaged in cattle breeding for about 15 years. They got cattle in inheritance. The initial amount of their business activity was 10000 soms (318.24$). Now they earn 4500 soms (98.2$) per month. Money received from loan, they will spend to buy a heifer for further breeding. In near future she plans to build a shed, repair the house, to buy furniture and to save money for her children's education.

O. Kachkyn is 54 years old; she's married and has raised 3 sons and a daughter. A daughter and an older son are married and live separately with their families. Other sons work in Bishkek.  Kachkyn's husband works a constructor, he also helps her with housework when he's free. Several years ago they got a loan in amount of 10000 soms (218.25$), on which they bought 2 calves in order to resale them. Kachkyn is engaged in cattle breeding for 10 years, she also sells milk to make money. Thanks to this activity she could marry her children. Now she wants to get a loan, because she needs money to purchase a heifer. Her future plans are: to increase the livestock, and to save money for her sons marriage.

M. Nazgul is 32 years old. She has 3 daughters and a son, the older daughter studies at school, the others are preschool age. Nazgul and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding for 10 years. In order to start their business, they got a loan in amount of 14000 soms (305.54$), on this money they bought a cow. Nazgul also sells milk for making money. Thanks to this activity they earn 6000 soms (130.95$) per month, so as a result they could buy a car and increase the number of cows. Now they need a loan to purchase a calf, after fattening it will be resold. In future they wish to build a new house.

O. Aksaana is the treasurer of the group. She's 33, married and has 3 sons. The older son studies at school, the others are preschool age. Her husband is engaged in transportation of passengers around a city. They started their business activity 5 years ago, with the initial amount of 70000 soms (1527.71$). The made money, having sold the harvest and so they could buy a car. Money received from loan, will be spent for repairing the truck. In future they want to change a car, open a store, and buy a house. 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to buy a heifer for further breeding.

loans.name: Leonora's Group

texts.en:
Leonora B. is from Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. She is 45 years old and the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Leonora is married and has three school-aged children. She sells kitchen supplies and products to tourists and local community members. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and makes approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Leonora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Leonora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en: Maria Fe is 56 years old and has four children. She is a rice farmer and her farm is situated in her town in Agusan Del Sur, Philippines. Maria Fe wants to have the best possible rice to sell. She is happy that her farm provides both food for her family and for their other needs. She wants to continue farming and hopefully increase her harvest. Maria Fe applied to Kiva partner, CEVI, and is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP, which she will use to buy farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs, such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Juliet's Group

texts.en:
Juliet R., from the town of Centro Sur, Alcala, Cagayan, is the 43-year-old leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Juliet, who is married and has five school-aged children, owns and operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She is just starting this business.

Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell and plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Oyunbaatar

texts.en:
Oyunbaatar U. is 49 years old. He lives with his wife and two children in Hentiy province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic tent). Oyunbaatar operates a shoe repair business. He shares his workplace, which is located near the largest local market, with a friend. He has been operating his business since 2000, and has built a loyal customer base over the past ten years. His daily revenue is 30,000 MNT, and his monthly revenue is 900,000 MNT.  He charges 2,500 MNT to repair one pair of shoes. 
Oyunbaatar's wife, Oyunbileg, is a nurse at a local hospital, and earns 220,000 MNT per month. Both of Oyunbaatar's children are university students. With his business profits, he has been able to purchase his own plot of land with a house and yard, and has been paying his two children's university fees. Oyunbaatar has a demand deposit in our bank, and deposits his daily revenue in it. It is therefore possible for us to monitor his revenue. He is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary materials and equipment to manufacture shoes. In addition, he will use the loan to finish building a new house for his family.

loans.use: To purchase materials and equipment

loans.name: Marvin

texts.en: Marvin P. lives in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. He is a farmer whose main crop is rice. He grows and sells rice so that he can provide whatever his family needs. He also manages a small sari-sari store. He started his business in 2009 and would now like to grow it. He is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP from Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI). He will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for his sari-sari store. He likes CEVI's service because it is very affordable.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for his store

loans.name: Rasha

texts.en:
Rasha Z. is a housewife from Gaza City in the Gaza Strip. She is the mother of one daughter and one son. Her husband works in the Palestinian National Authority.

The family has a general store where they sell items like food, sweets, and juice. Having a general store in Gaza is the best business to support a family, because the current situation there makes it harder to do other type of projects.

Rasha and her husband, Muhammad, opened the store three years ago because it's the only one on the street where they live. They wanted to expand it and buy more goods to sell in the store, so Rasha came to FATEN asking for a $1500 loan which will help them to attract a larger number of customers.

In the picture, Rasha's husband, Muhammad, is shown in their store.

loans.use: Purchase goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Noe

texts.en: Noe L. is 43 years old and has one child. He started his rice farm business in 1988 and he owns the land that he tills. The income that Noe gets from his business goes towards the needs of his family. He works very hard to provide for all his family's needs. Lately, he has been inspired by other clients of Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) who have succeeded in their businesses. Noe is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies to increase his harvest.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Byambasuren S. is a 42-year-old widow who lives with her 15-year-old daughter in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her daughter live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Byambsuren's daughter attends a local secondary school.

Byambasuren operates a tailoring business. She graduated from a four-month sewing training course in 1990. She has been operating her business since 1996, and has become an experienced tailor. Since 2004, she has rented a workplace to let her more easily provide her services to her many customers.

Byambasuren has been planning to grow her business and to improve her equipment. She is a very hardworking person and says, “I would like to grow my business and improve my family's standard of living by receiving a loan.” Byambasuren is requesting a 1,400,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary materials and equipment.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials and equipment for his tailoring business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 35-year-old father of four children, aged between 4 months and 11 years old. Two of the children are attending school. Joseph practises mixed farming in western Kenya near Kitale town. He has been in this business for two years and employs several employees on a casual basis. He sells his eggs to the local market. He also earns some income from a small kiosk he operates in the same area.
Joseph has requested his first loan from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, for 30,000 KES to expand his poultry project. He says the income from this project will enable him to educate his children to higher levels. He says that the main challenge with his business is the common poultry diseases in the area, which has lead to low production. In future, he hopes to expand his poultry farm and eventually venture into dairy farming. He adds that "he appreciates the flexibility in repayment to Juhudi Kilimo, that is, weekly, bi-weekly, and monthly."

loans.use: To expand his poultry project

loans.name: Litia

texts.en:
Litia O. is 51 years old, married, and blessed with five children. She and her husband work together to raise their big family. They are currently living at Talim, Binangonan Rizal, Philippines. Litia is a woman of good faith who wishes to conquer all challenges to achieve her family's dreams. 
Litia’s main goal is to build a sustainable business to meet the needs of her five children. To do this, she was encouraged to join Kiva partner, ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), a microfinance institution in the Philippines, in 2007. The previous loans she has received from ASHI were carefully invested in her sari-sari (variety) store. Since then, the business has been performing well and earning her sufficient profit. She is grateful that she has been able to educate her children using proceeds from her business as she continues to expand. Litia now needs a loan to boost her business for increased profitability.
Litia started her sari-sari store on her own initiative. She wants to continue her business, and is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP to use as additional capital to improve her business and income. Specifically, the money will be used to purchase five sacks of rice, charcoal, sugar, canned goods, cigarettes, fabric conditioner and other supplies for her store. 
Litia dreams of growing her variety store into a mini-grocery store and expanding it to other villages. Her family is her inspiration to pursue her business. She now feels very happy with ASHI's services as they give her a big chance to pursue her family's dreams. She hopes that they continue their services for a long time and help many families who want to get ahead.

loans.use: To purchase five sacks of rice, charcoal, sugar, canned goods, cigarettes, fabric conditioner and other supplies

loans.name: Roland

texts.en:
Roland is a warehouse engineer from Mukachevo, Western Ukraine. He works in a store selling bakery and pastry items wholesale and has been in this business for three years. His monthly profit is about 1,100 to 1,200 Grivnyas (approximately 140 to 150 USD).

Roland is seeking a 6,500 Grivnya loan to purchase good-quality electrical appliances for his house and thus improve the living conditions of his family. His family has had many financial struggles and Roland is finally happy to be able to offer them a better standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase electrical appliances for his family

loans.name: Norberto

texts.en:
Norberto D., 58 years old, is a rice farmer. He started his business in 2002 and owns the 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm that he tills. He works so hard to be able to help his family.

Norberto joined CEVI’s micro-credit program in 2006. He would like to obtain a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). He will use the loan to buy additional farm supplies to increase his harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lubele South Lacot Alice Group

texts.en:
L. Alice is twenty-eight years old, is married, and is blessed with two children, both schooling. She also has two dependents who are schooling, too.

Alice sells clothes which she has been doing for over six years. She is using the loan to purchase clothes from Kampala to sell in Pader. She is hoping very much to see her business shift and develop. More so, her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Tserennadmid

texts.en:
Tserennadmid D. is a 35-year-old widow who lives with her three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All three of her children, ages 13, 11 and 8, attend a local primary school.

Tserennadmid operates a clothing trading business at Narantuul, the largest market in Mongolia. She mostly sells clothing for children and young people. She sells her products at a large rented counter in a good location. She started her business in 2003 with her husband. Unfortunately her husband passed away two years ago, and since that time she has been operating her business alone.

Tserennadmid is a responsible and industrious person. Her three children are the most important thing to her, and she has been working hard to provide a better life for them and to raise them to be good people. She is requesting a 900,000 MNT loan to pay off the loan on her car.

loans.use: To pay off the loan on her car

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza J., 27 years old, is a rice farmer. She has two children and her eldest child is 9 years old and studying in grade four.

Riza started her business in 2004. Until now, she has grown rice because she sees a good potential in this kind of business. She helps her husband grow the rice and labors so hard so that she will be able to provide her family with an adequate supply of food.

Riza would like to request a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to increase her harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto P., 55 years old, is a rice farmer who tills a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm. He has nine children and his eldest child is 33 and already married. When he has a good harvest, he shares some of it with his children.

Roberto hopes that he will have an abundant harvest so that he will be able to provide his family with their needs. He would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will go far in buying farm supplies to increase his harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Rosaly

texts.en:
Rosaly N., 43 years old, owns a small sari-sari (variety) store. She has three children and her eldest child is 20.

Rosaly joined CEVI’s program in 2006 and stayed in the program until now because she likes the services. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 30,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) to buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store.

By obtaining the loan, Rosaly will be able to attract more customers and improve her income.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Delia's Group

texts.en:
Delia A. is from the village of Bannagao. She is 54 years old. Delia is the leader of a 5-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Delia A. Group.

Delia is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Delia owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Delia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Delia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Delia is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Delia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy new items to sell

loans.name: Hani

texts.en:
Hani A. G. is a father of three beautiful sons and daughters, Suhaib, Malak, and Habiba, who are five, four, and three years old, respectively. Hani is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority and a taxi driver after work hours. Hani drives people inside the city of Deer Al-Balah and between the cities of the Gaza Strip.

Hani lives in the An-Nusairat Refugee Camp in Deer el Balah City. Hani took a $2000 loan from FATEN to repair his car, which is shown in the picture. He has been using the car for taxi duty for 1-1/2 years. It makes a very good second income source due to the low salaries of Palestinian National Authority employees.

loans.use: Car Repair

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah L., 34 years old, is a rice farmer. She has a farm which she hopes will provide her family with their daily needs. Deborah has five children. She wishes to sustain her livelihood more, so as to be able to improve her family’s economic condition.

Deborah started her business in 1994. She wants to obtain a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. which she will use to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies like fertilizer

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Having six children is not easy, Delia H. says, and she doesn’t know anymore how will she budget their small income. Her husband works as a farmer and she is helping her husband maintain the rice field.

Delia is currently preparing her farm for planting and that is why she needs all the help to be able improve their harvest. She would like to obtain a loan of Php 7,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
Lucila B. is married and lives with her husband in the province of Rizal in the Philippines. She is an ambitious entrepreneur who has managed a doormat-making business in her community for almost 11 years. 

Lucila would like to receive a loan to purchase additional fabric made from different materials, including cottons, for her business inventory. She believes that having a greater variety and assortment of fabric will help her design different styles of doormats to match her clients’ particular design tastes. 

Since 1999, Lucila has been a loyal, dedicated, and proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines. Lucila has demonstrated solid performance on her previous loans. 

Lucila’s dreams are to expand her business and eventually open her own doormat-making factory in her neighborhood. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, she aspires to expand her business and generate steady income to support her family’s long term financial security.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics, cotton, and other materials for her doormat-making business.

loans.name: Josefina's Group

texts.en: Josefina Y.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She is 37 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of San Pedro. Josefina has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Josefina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase livestock to raise and sell. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. Josefina is the leader of a seven member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Josefina Y.'s Group". About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 21 years old. She is married has one child. 

She is a tailor. She will use this loan to purchase a large new industrial sewing machine that is faster and has a lot of features. 

She has been working in this business for a couple of years. She is a skilled woman who wants to develop her craft. She has good reputation in the district and, therefore, many customers come to her. Her income will rise so she can help her husband to pay for their living expenses.

loans.use: To purchase an industrial sewing machine

loans.name: Mamadjanova Zebikan Group

texts.ru:
Зебикан, 35, замужем. Супруг занимается представлением услуг на тракторе, занимается обработкой земли, зарабатывает $120 в месяц. У нее 4 детей: дочерям 12 и 10, сыну 7 и 5 лет. Клиент в астоящее время занимается сельским хозйством, выращиваением картофеля. Она на кредит планирует закупить минеральные удобрения для картофеля.

Жамилахан, 56, замужем. У нее двое сыновей. Старший сын строитель, заработок $120, младший сын член крестьянского хозяйства, невестка работает в школе Кебекбаева преподавателем. Ее супруг также член крестьянского хозяйства. Жамилахан активно занимается полеводством. На 0,91 га земли посадили картофель для реализации. На кредит планирует закупить удобрения для картофеля.

Замире 33 года. Ее супруг работает водителем. Она активно занимается откормом и разведением КРС. На кредит планирует закупить теленка для откорма и разведения.

Тургунали, 29. Он вместе с супругой занимается растениеводством. В этом году на земельном наделе посадили картофель. На кредит планирует закупить мин. удобрения для картофеля и для фруктового сада.


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Zebikan, 35, is married. Her husband makes $120 a month cultivating land with his tractor. Zebikan has 4 children: two daughters--12 and 10 and two sons--7 and 5. Zebikan grows potatoes. She will use this loan to purchase mineral fertilizer. Jamilahan, 56, is married. Her husband is a member of collective farm. Jamilahan has 2 children. Jamilahan's older son is a construction worker making $120 a month and her younger son is a member of collective farm. Jamilahan's daughter-in-law is a school teacher. On her 0.91 hectare (2.25 acre) parcel of land, Jamilahan grows potatoes she sells. Jamilahan will use this loan to purchase fertilizer. Zamira, 33, is married. Her husband is a driver. Zamira is a cattle farmer. She plans to use this loan to purchase a calf. Turgunali, 29, and his wife grow potatoes. They plan to use this loan to purchase fertilizer for their potato field and orchard.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: Fe A., 48 years old owns a small rice farm. This helps her buy the things that her family needs, like food, clothes and other basic necessities. She said that if she will not work hard on her farm, she won’t get anything for her family. Now, she is having difficulty in maintaining her 1-hectare farm because of financial constraints in the family. She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 9,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies, fertilizer.

loans.name: Herminia's Group

texts.en:
Herminia A. is from the village of Brgy. Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Herminia is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Herminia is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Herminia owns & operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Herminia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Herminia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Herminia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Herminia is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Herminia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia P. is a devoted mother to her two children. She lives in the beautiful province of Binangonan, Rizal with her family. She owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) store in their village. Despite many challenges in their life, they never gave up fighting against poverty.

She plans to utilize this loan of Php 19,000 to expand and support the maintenance of her general store,  the primary source of daily income. This loan will be used for additional capital to buy groceries for her general store.

During her 2 years at ASHI, she has shown very good performance as a member, and she is trusted by ASHI for her solid record. Aside from maintaining an excellent performance in her credit rating (basis of loans) in ASHI, Letecia has also cared for the needs of her family at home.

This loan will enable her to finally reach her dreams in life: to have a growing business,a  good life, and a happy family as well. 

Letecia believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty, as well as provide for the needs of her family. She is very grateful to ASHI and KIVA for the continuous love and support of her dreams.

loans.use: To buy groceries of her store.

loans.name: Lubele North Abalo Santina Group

texts.en: A. Santina is a hardworking businesswoman. She is a married woman, fifty years old, blessed with five children in schooling and two dependents. She has a bakery business and also sells beans as a side business. She has been operating her business for three months. She is using the loan to purchase bakery items, especially ingredients for making bread. His future plan is to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase bakery items, especially ingredients, for making bread.

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en: Gorret is a single mother and her children go to school. She owns a two-room house where she stays with six people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Gorret takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. Gorret owns a canteen near the Nakualbye Church of Uganda primary school where she sells samosas, pancakes, mandazi, donuts, fried groundnuts,  etc. and sells to all categories of people including students and teachers. She sells at retail and at wholesale. She works six days a week. Gorret   receives at least 10 customers a day. She has been in this business for seven years and with MCDT for four years.  She wants to use the loan for baking flour, cowpeas for making samosas and cooking oil. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own different canteens in different schools. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women in groups of five.

loans.use: To buy more baking flour, cooking oil and cowpeas

loans.name: George

texts.en: George M., 26 years old, is never tired of tilling his farm. He has two children. He said that his purpose and desire is to help his family have an adequate supply of food everyday. He will continue to do his best to sustain his livelihood so that he could still support his children, even though they are already married.  He would like to ask for a loan of PHP 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Kumarhan

texts.en:
Kumarhan is 52 years old and lives with her three children in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter, Amanjol, attends a university. Her two other children, aged 10 and 7, attend the local secondary and primary schools.  

Kumarhan operates a meat trading business in a rental space at a local market, called Ah Dam. She pays 6000 tugrugs (~ 4 USD) per month in rent. Kumarhan has been operating her business since 2004, and has built a loyal customer base. She sells prepared meat to local restaurants. Kumarhan sells an average of 20,000 tugrugs worth of meat per day. Her monthly profit is 150,000 tugrugs (~ 110 USD). Kumarhan has a great personality. She says, “My children are my happiness. I will take care of my children and will work hard to provide a better life for them. The most important thing is that I showed my children that even people who have a small amount of money can make a profit.” She is requesting a 200,000 tugrug (~  145 USD) loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase meat for her butcher shop.

loans.name: Magielyn's Group

texts.en:
Magielyn V. is from the village of Brgy.Bonfal Proper, Bayombong,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Magielyn is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Magielyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Magielyn owns & operates a furniture making business, and she sells general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Magielyn has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Magielyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magielyn repaid her previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Magielyn is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Magielyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en: When she started her business last 2001, her goal was to make her business grow to support her family. Gilda A., 45 years old, tills a small rice field which is 1- hectare in size. She has 4 children. Her eldest child is 10 years old. She wanted to have an abundant harvest but lacks capital to buy the entire farm supplies. She would like to request a loan of PHP 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will really help her go on in her farming business and to have sustainable income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more wood (plank) to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen A., is 40 and lives in Trento Agusan del Sur.  She is managing her farm alone and desires an abundant harvest. She said she learned to farm when she was just a kid. Her parents taught her everything. She wants to make her farm productive to be able to support the needs of her family. She would like to apply for a loan of 6,000 Philippine Pesos at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a single mother of seven children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She sells charcoal in Makerere Kikoni and wants to use this loan of 700,000/= to buy more bags of charcoal. She has other side businesses like selling raw food, selling firewood, etc. Margaret works from her home and sells to all categories of people at wholesale and at retail. Margaret works seven days a week and pays transportation from the villages of Luwero to her business centre in Makerere. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal from Luwero. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and get enough profit to build her own rental houses.  Margret decided to work with MCDT because it was working with poor women. Margaret owns the house where the family stays and they do have access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Hyde

texts.en:
Hydie H. is managing a small rice field. She has four children, the eldest is 14. Her husband is a farmer and they work together to improve their harvest to support their children. 

Now, the family is preparing the farm for another planting. They need additional money to buy farming materials. She would like to apply for a loan of 7,000 Philippine Pesos at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda G., 42 years old, is a tenant of a two-hectare rice field. She has one child. She helps her husband manage their farm so that they will have an abundant harvest to feed their family. She dreams of having her own farm someday, that is why she is doing her best to be able to prosper and improve their harvest. She would like to apply for a loan of 7,000 Philippine Pesos at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan M. sells maize flour and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock soya beans to sell. Susan is 31 years old and married to a policeman. They have four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock soya beans to sell

loans.name: Adelina's Group

texts.en:
Adelina D. is from the village of Brgy.Paniki, Bagabag,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 50 years old. Adelina is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Adelina is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Adelina owns & operates a business making & selling fish balls and other dim sum to the local community. Adelina has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Adelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelina repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI, which she used to purchase raw ingredients. Adelina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Adelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Irish

texts.en: Irish A., a 24-year-old rice farmer, has two children. Because her eldest child is already six years old, she is worried about how to manage their income when her child starts going to school. She would like to expand her rice farm and has been busy preparing it for the next planting. But, she said, she still needs additional money to complete the process. She wants to apply for a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and fertilizer.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret J. sells charcoal and bread from home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Margret is 33 years old and married to a small-scale farmer. She has three children in school  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Bisi

texts.en:
Bisi sells oranges wholesale to her customers. She buys her goods from traders who come from the village to sell in the city. She sometimes buys a lorry load of oranges to sell. She has been in the business for the past 16 years. She is very happy with the nature of her business because it gives her the opportunity to take care of her children's financial needs. 
She hopes for a loan of NGN80, 000 to purchase more oranges to sell to her numerous custumers and improve her profit.
Bisi is 58 years, married with 6 children. Her husband is an army officer and all of them live in Lagos.  She thanks all Kiva lenders for their assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more oranges to sell.

loans.name: Ajuk

texts.en:
Ajuk M. is currently in the business of selling local Sudanese bread cooked in oil. She is requesting a loan to purchase more baking flour and cooking oil.  

Ajuk is 29 years old and married to a businessman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more baking flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a single lady who doesn't have any children. Sarah takes care of additional family members.  Sarah is a teacher by profession and teaches knitting and weaving of sweaters, tablemats and other clothes. She has about 10 students whom she is training how to make sweaters and other clothing designs. She gets at least five customers a day. Sarah wants to use this loan of 500,000/= to buy more threads for sweater making, pieces of cloths and needles. Besides this clothing business, Sarah has some other side businesses. She sells at wholesale and at retail and makes clothing according to someone's wish.  Her major customers are the community around her and some schools and she works seven days a week. Sarah‘s business challenges include transportation and defaulting of her would be customers. Her goals and aspirations include owning a big vocational school, acquiring more knitting machines and even opening up more branches in Bwaise and Nakulabye. Sarah joined MCDT to acquire more capital and get more clientele.

loans.use: To buy more thread, needles and pieces of cloth

loans.name: Maria Charito's Group

texts.en:
Maria Charito A. is from the village of Brgy.Lantap,Bagabag,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Maria Charito is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Maria Charito is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Charito owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. Maria Charito has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maria Charito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Charito repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which she used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Maria Charito is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Maria Charito from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:
