ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Ijilsekhbayar

texts.en: Ijilsekhbayar is 41, widowed, and has a 12-year-old daughter, Bolor-Erdene, who attends a local secondary school. They live in a rental apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. In 2008, Ijilsekhbayar, started selling bricks to local construction companies. From the beginning, the business has been doing well, with business capital increasing from 500,000 MNT (~357 USD) to 2.3 million MNT (~1,660 USD). Ijilsekhbayar dreams of owning a larger brick factory that can meet the needs of larger construction companies. She also hopes her daughter will achieve a high level of education. Ijilsekhbayar is now requesting a loan to buy construction materials for her brick baking.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Ladu

texts.en:
Ladu M. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at a hotel and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of cassava flour and dried fish.  Ladu is 30 years old and is married to a nurse. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her hotel.

She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 8,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizer. She joined CEVI in 2009 and she is staying in the program because she likes its services.

She joined the CEVI program in 2009. She likes the CEVI services and feels secured of its insurance policy . Now, the family is preparing the farm for another planting. They need additional money to buy all the farming materials. She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 9,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies and fertilizers.

loans.name: Angelo's Group

texts.en:
Angelo D. Jr. is from the village of San Francisco, Baggao, Cagayan. He is 35 years old. Angelo is the group leader of a 22-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Angelo is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Angelo owns & operates a bakery; he bakes & sells bread in the local community. Angelo just started this business.

Angelo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angelo is requesting his first loan, for 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is married to a security officer. They have four children and all her children go to school. Sophia owns a restaurant in Makerere Kikoni near Nana Girls hostel. She wants to use this loan of 500,000 UGX partly to buy more foodstuffs like bananas, rice, Irish potatoes, cassava, yams, and beef plus groundnuts, beans and fish and partly to invest in second hand clothes. She wants to do both businesses concurrently. Sophia rents the business premises and mainly sells at retail only. She sells to all categories of people though her clients are mainly students from nearby hostels. Sophia works seven days a week. Business challenges include seasonality and thieves who usually break into her restaurant. She aspires to expand her business by employing three people and to build her own house. Sophia decided to work with MCDT because they were giving out timely loans. She rents her residence and has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and second hand clothes

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Kadykeeva Gulnara Group

texts.en:
K. Gulnara is the leader of her group. She is 30, married and has three daughters. The older one is a pupil and the others are preschool age. Her husband is engaged in fattening cattle and reselling them. He also takes part in cultivation and sowing, Gulnara and her husband have been engaged in this activity for 15 years. As a result, they added a heating system to their house and increased the number of livestock. Now they are involved in agricultural work on the field, so Gulnara wants to get a loan to purchase fuel needed for the cultivation and sowing process. In the future, they're planning to educate their children and purchase a pavilion to sell groceries and manufactured goods.

B. K. Zarema is 20 years old. She's married and has a little daughter. Zarema's husband works as a builder; in order to make more money he also cultivates the neighbors' land on his friend's tractor. Zarema sits at home with their little daughter and is engaged in cattle breeding. So she wants to get a loan to purchase a calf in order to increase the number of livestock. In the near future, as their daughter grows up, Zarema will start to work in a sewing workshop.  

T. Perizat is the treasurer of the group. She's 21, and studies at the university part time. Two years ago, with an initial amount of 2000 soms ($43.60), Perizat and her farther started to cultivate the land. In order to make money, Perizat and her mom also produce national products at home. With the money receive from the loan, they are going to buy fuel, which is necessary for the sowing process. After finishing the university, Perizat wishes to start her own business.

S. Gulzat is 40, and married with three children: two sons and a daughter. The older son and a daughter study at school, the other one is preschool age. Gulzat's husband is engaged in the private transportation of passengers in Bishkek. Two years ago, with 1000 soms ($21.81), Gulzat began to take orders for sewing quilts. As a result of this, she was able to marry her daughter and give a dowry of 30000 soms ($653.87). Now Gulzat wants to get a loan to purchase fuel needed for plowing and sowing the land. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.
Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fuel

texts.en: Joveta S., 46 years old, is a rice grower. She has a small rice field, which she has maintained for many years now, to ensure a supply of food for their family. Currently, she is happy with her business status. It’s gaining and improving every year. Now she needs a small amount of money to buy farm supplies and fertilizers. She would like to apply for a loan of PHP 10,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She chose CEVI because it provides not just loans but insurance coverage as well to all its clients.

loans.name: Teresa's Group

texts.en:
Teresa A. is from the village of Bungad, San Pablo, Isabela. She is 35 years old. Teresa is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Teresa is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Teresa owns & operates a business selling ice cream to the local community. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Teresa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Teresa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is married with six children and only four of her children go to school. Ruth stays in Kanyanya, a suburb in Kampala district.  The family gets three meals a day. She owns a stall selling raw food like bananas, cassava, fruits and vegetables and uses public transport to and from work.  Ruth has been with MCDT for five years and has had many loans. She wants to use this loan of 500,000/= to buy more bunches of bananas, sweet potatoes mangoes, oranges etc. Ruth works seven days a week. She hopes that in the future when she gets her profits she will open up a grocery shop. She joined MCDT because she wanted to get timely loans. Ruth owns the house where the family stays and has access to electricity and piped water at home. Monthly expenses include utility bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bananas, oranges, sweet bananas and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Nyota Group

texts.fr:
Kahambu W. E. est présidente du groupe de crédit  Nyota, habillée en robe noire, elle lève sa main sur la photo, cliente au 16e cycle de crédit, âgée de 34 ans, mariée, mère de 3 enfants, tous  vont à l’école. Son mari est petit commerçant de divers produits.
Kahambu W. E. vend des divers entre autres les valises, chainettes, robes, chemises, pantalons, boubou femme, jubés, souliers, etc.  dans son petit magasin, et parfois dans des familles amies preneurs de ses produits. Elle a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre reçu de son mari. 
Son capital initial était de 100$. Ce qui lui a permis de lancer une activité de vente de riz et peu après, en collaboration avec  son mari, son business a évolue jusqu'à créer une petite boutique. Il y a 13 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. 
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, Kahambu W. E. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant 6 valises, 4 boubous femmes, 6 blouses et 6 jupes, 10 chainettes Manzanza.
Le grand défi de Kahambu W. E., elle est encore locataire (à son domicile et au lieu de travail) alors  tous les profits de son business payent les charges de loyers estimées à 20$ par mois. Et parfois son bailleur lui exige de payer une garantie de plus de 9 mois.
Dans l’avenir, Kahambu W. E. planifie accroitre son business et quitter la banque communautaire vers le groupe solidaire qui offre beaucoup plus d’avantages opérationnels en terme du montant de crédit, de taux d’intérêt et de l’échéance de remboursement etc.
En outre Kahambu W. E. souhaiterait dans un futur proche, acheter une parcelle et si Dieu lui prête vie, acheter aussi une voiture.
 Dans le 10 ans, elle ambitionne ouvrir une deuxième boutique dans le centre ville de Goma. Elle compte s’approvisionner à la source dans le grand centre commercial mondial soit à Dubaï ou soit à Chine.
Kahambu W. E. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle a déjà équipé sa maison, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants et son business prospère bien. 
Ce groupe Nyota  est  composé de 16 membres majoritairement femmes.
texts.en:
Kahambu W. E. is the president of the loan group Nyota. Dressed in the black dress, she is raising her hand in the photo. She is a client on her 16th loan cycle, 34 years old, married, and mother of three children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a small trader of various products. Kahambu W. E. sells diverse products like suitcases, small chain jewelry, dresses, blouses, pants, women's boubous (traditional clothing), skirts, shoes, etc. in her small shop. Sometimes family friends buy her products. She began her business with her own funds from her husband. Her initial capital was $100. This allowed her to launch a business selling rice. A short time afterward, in collaboration with her husband, her business evolved into a small boutique. She has now done this work for 13 years. With a loan from IMF Hekima, Kahambu W. E. wishes to increase her sales by purchasing six suitcases, four female boubous, six blouses, six skirts, and ten Manzaza chains. Kahambu's biggest challenge is that she still rents (at home and at her workplace). Thus, all of her business profits go to pay her rent, estimated at $20 per month. Sometimes, her lessor insists that she guarantee nine months' payment. In the future, Kahambu W. E. plans to grow her business and leave the communal bank for a united group which offers many operational advantages in terms of increased credit, interest tax, and repayment deadlines. Moreover, in the near future, Kahambu wishes to buy a plot of land and, god willing, a car. In ten years, she intends to open a second boutique in the center of Goma. She plans on getting supplies from the world's large commercial centers, either in Dubai or in China. Kahambu thanks the IMF Hekima for the loans she received without any material guarantee because, thanks to these loans, she has already equipped her house, she manages to meet her children's needs, and her business is prospering. The Nyota group is made up of 16 members, the majority of whom are female.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of six suitcases, four female boubous, six blouses, six skirts, and ten Manzaza chains

Victoria is 58 years old, is married, and has eight children. Her husband is a retired civil servant.

Victoria is into craft work: she molds and sells local pots using clay and other materials. She has been in this business for a long time.

Victoria is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more materials to mold more pots to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

It is our source of livelihood that is why we keep our best to sustain it so that we could provide our family with all their needs”, says Lina E., a 43-year-old farmer from Trento Agusan del Sur. Now she is preparing the farm but still needs additional money to buy all the other farming needs. In addition to farming, she also raises pigs. She hopes to receive a loan of PHP 7,000 at Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

Mary B. is a 38-year-old widow who has one child. She is a hardworking woman who wants the best for her child.

Mary sells foodstuffs such as rice, beans, cooking oil, tomato paste and pepper. She hopes to expand her business. She needs a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie L., 24 years-old, rents land and maintains a rice field. She is also a sari-sari (general) store owner and sells a variety of goods.  She has one child. She helps her husband manage their farm so that they will have an abundant harvest. 

She dreams of owning their own farm someday, so is doing her best to be able to prosper and improve their harvest. She would also like to improve the size of her store.  

She is asking for a loan of Php 4,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to resell for her store and farm supplies for their farm.

texts.en:
Joy E. is married with four children and she is 35 years old. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home.

Joy sells clothes, sarongs and female shoes at retail prices and has been in this business for three years. She hopes to own a world-class supermarket in the future.

Joy is requesting a loan of NGN 40,000 to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.fr: K. Lydia est née en 1970 à Ekpè dans la commune de Sèmé-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à BOITCHA Pascal, Lydia est mère de cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Lydia vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Tchonvi, dans la commune de Sèmé-Podji, depuis quatre ans environs. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Lydia n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Lydia mène comme activité, la vente de produits vivriers et d'huile de palme à son domicile, et parfois de façon ambulante. Lydia exerce cette activité depuis sept ans environs et a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé à ALIDé. Dans l’optique d'agrandir davantage son activité et d'augmenter le stock de ses produits afin de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Lydie sollicite un deuxième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Lydia K. was born in 1970 in Ekpé, part of the Sèmé-Podji commune of Benin. Married to Pascal BOITCHA, Lydia is the mother of five children, some of whom are in school. For the past four years, she has lived with her husband and children in Tchonvi, in the Sèmé-Podji commune. The couple share coping with various family expenses. Lydia has never attended school. To meet her needs and those of her children, she retails fresh produce and palm oil primarily from her home, and sometimes as an itinerant vendor. She has been running this business for approximately seven years, and has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was fully repaid. She is now requesting a second loan, wishing to expand her activity and increase her stock of supplies to better meet her customers’ expectations.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fresh produce and containers of palm oil

texts.en:
Patience is 40 years old and is married with five children: a boy and four girls. Her husband is a carpenter and he also supports their home.

Patience fries and sells potato chips and is well known in her neighborhood for her chips. She hopes to grow her business so that it becomes bigger and stronger in the future.

Patience is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cooking oil and potatoes to fry more potato chips to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Monica W. sells and designs bedsheets and is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets to sell.  Monica is 29 years-old and is married with a husband that is a driver. She has two children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase a sewing machine for designing bedsheets.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase bedsheets to sell.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah Ordillo, 30 years-old is a rice farmer. Her husband is also a farmer. The income she makes from her farm is really helpful in ensuring the supply of food for their family. 

Leah would like to increase her harvest but needs a small amount of money to buy farming necessities such as fertilizers and farm supplies. She is asking for a loan of Php 4,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will lead to an increased harvest.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Uvbi

texts.en:
Uvbi sells cola nuts (an African nut containing caffeine) at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to be a major cola nut distributor in her city in the future.

Cola nuts are highly cherished in Nigeria and the demand for them is high. In some arrears in Nigeria cola nuts are eaten, while some people worship the cola nut and others just plant the cola nuts to make money. In Nigeria, the cola nut is presented at all traditional ceremonies and Nigerians believe that the cola nut does not understand the English language but only the local languages.

Uvbi is 47 years old and is married with seven children. Her husband is a commercial farmer and he also supports their home.

Uvbi is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cola nuts to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cola nuts to sell

loans.name: Ismail

texts.en:
Ismail O. is a 32 year-old married man from Gaza. He lives with his wife and four children.

In 2009, Ismail opened a small shop selling accessories and children's clothes. He hopes that with this loan, he will be able to buy all that he lacks for his shop.  He hopes that this will bring in more customers and increase his income.

loans.use: To buy accessories and children's clothes.

loans.name: Surur

texts.en:
Surur A. sells ice cream and bread at the market and is requesting a loan to stock onions and tomatoes to sell.  Surur is 40 years-old and a widow.   She has five children and they do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase onions and tomatoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more local household items to sell

loans.name: Faith Women Union Group

texts.en:
Suwah H. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Faith Women Union. A Grade 12 graduate, she is 49 years old, widowed, and has five children who range from 14 to 31 years old. She also takes care of a number of grandchildren.

For 19 years, Suwah has been selling clothes including lappa, shirts and dresses at Caldwell New Georgia North Market, located on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning. Suwah plans to use her 20,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 50,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more dry goods and dozens of shirts and dresses. Her goal is to grow her business, build a house and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Suwah is the one holding the sign. Inset is Harris W. at the lower right corner.

loans.use: To buy more dry goods and dozens of shirts and dresses.

loans.name: Mathida

texts.en: Mathida is a 53-year-old widow with nine children. Life as a widow is highly challenging, and she hopes to overcome the challenge. Mathida owns a grocery store selling groceries and drinks at retail prices, a business she has been in for a long time. Now requesting a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell, she says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more bags of garri to sell

loans.name: B. Catherine

texts.fr: L. B. Catherine est née le 25 Novembre 1982 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à ADJAMONSI Sylvain, un technicien, Catherine est mère de deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Catherine vit avec sa famille depuis trois ans au quartier Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Catherine vient en aide à son mari, en supportant avec lui, les différentes charges familiales. Catherine a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au secondaire. Mais depuis quatre ans, Catherine a commencé à vendre divers produits (œufs, lait, conserves de tomate et de sardine, galettes d’arachide, sachets, savons, allumettes, etc.) à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Catherine vend aussi des biscuits. Catherine a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et a bien effectué le remboursement. Catherine désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et accroître sa clientèle, raison pour laquelle Catherine sollicite auprès de ALIDé un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
B. Catherine L. was born 25 November 1982 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Sylvain ADJAMONSI, a technician, Catherine is the mother of two children, of whom one is attending school. For the past three years she has been living with her family in the Agblangandan borough, in the Sèmé-Podji commune. Catherine helps her husband by sharing responsibility for various family expenses. Catherine has attended school up to secondary level, but began four years ago to sell various products from her home (eggs, milk, canned tomatoes, sardines, peanut flat-cakes, plastic pouches, soap, matches, etc.). She also sells cookies as a side business. Catherine has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was fully repaid. She is now requesting a second loan, as she wishes to increase her stock of supplies and the number of customers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soap, milk, cookies, pasta, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Mawussé Amavi

texts.fr:
Cette femme a appris le métier de la couture, en 1994 elle a ouvert son propre atelier de couture qu’elle a appelé « LA GRACE DIVINE »,  plus tard elle a associé à ce commerce la vente des articles de mercerie, ainsi elle arrive à réaliser de grandes recettes.  Le commerce des articles de mercerie marche bien pour elle. Elle veut gonfler son stock de marchandises pour pouvoir satisfaire la demande de ses clients de plus en plus élevée raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter  des popelines, boutons,  satins, fils et autres
Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants.
texts.en:
After learning tailoring in 1994, this lady opened her own tailor store, that she called « LA GRACE DIVINE » (the divine grace), and later she included haberdashery in her business, so that she could make a good revenue. The haberdashery business is running quite well. She wants to improve her stock in order to respond to her customers' growing demand. For this reson she is requesting her first loan from WAGES, in order to purchase poplins, buttons, satin fabric, sewing thread and other goods. She is married and mother of two children.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of haberdashery supplies

loans.name: Mujahed

texts.en: Mujahed Khaled A. S., 22 years old and single from Bet Lahya, Mujahed, needs this loan to enlarge his chicken farm.  Purchasing new equipment for the farm will give him the chance to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy equipment for his farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nadiatou

texts.fr: Cette femme reste une jeune femme très dynamique, elle a 25 ans et est célibataire. Afin de subvenir à ses propres besoins, elle s’est lancée en 2007 dans le commerce des céréales, pour réaliser de grandes marges bénéficiaires sur ses ventes, elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays dans la ville d’atakpame. Elle fait face à une baisse de stock raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES pour la premier fois un crédit afin de s’acheter 3 sacs d’haricots, 8 sacs de maïs et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
This lady is a very dynamic young lady. She is 25 years old and single. With the aim of being able to provide for her own needs, she began to trade in cereals in 2007. In order to make large profit margins on her sales, she gets her supplies inland in the town of Atakpame. She is facing a decline in stock and for this reason is requesting a first loan from WAGES, in order to buy three sacks of beans, three sacks of corn and to cover the transportation costs for her merchandise.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Mabéa

texts.fr:
Cette femme est mariée et a 4 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d’agoè gbonvé qui est  un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de boissons locales alcoolisées appelées « tchoucoutchou » faite à base de sorgho ou de mil. Ce commerce lui réussit bien car cette boisson est très appréciée des togolais. Elle voudrait gonfler son stock pour accroître  son chiffre d’affaire. Ayant déjà obtenu du crédit de WAGES qu’elle a bien remboursé, elle sollicite de un second crédit pour s’approvisionner en sorgho et en bois de chauffage pour la préparation du tchoucoutchou.
Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants.
texts.en:
This woman is married with four children, and lives with her family in the Agoè Gbonvé borough, on the outskirts of Lomé. Her revenue-genertating activity is the sale of a local alcoholic beverage called “tchoucoutchou”, made from a base of sorghum or millet. This activity is rather successful as this beverage is quite appreciated by Togolese. She wishes to boost her stock supply to increase her turnover. She has already received one previous loan from WAGES which she repaid in full. She is now requesting a second loan to buy sorghum and firewood to prepare the tchoucoutchou.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sorghum and firewood

loans.name: Satybaldieva's Group

texts.en:
Satybaldieva Z. is the 26-year-old leader of the group. A resident of Balykch, she is married to a bus driver and has a two-year-old son. A year ago her friends suggested that she rent a container, so with an initial investment of 15000 soms ($326.87) Satybaldieva started to sell children's sportswear and jeans As a result of this activity she increased her turnover on 23000 soms ($501.2$) and now earns nearly 15000 soms ($326.87) per month. Satybaldieva is now requesting a loan to purchase summer-autumn assortments of children's sportswear and Jeanswear.

Asankadyrova C., 36 years old, has two daughters and a son, two in school and one of preschool age. Her husband works in construction, and in winter he's engaged in buying and reselling cattle. Four years ago, C. sold her pavilion and with the initial amount of 60000 soms ($1307.47) she began her business activity, buying 2 head of cattle, 25 sheep, and a house. A loan is now requested to purchase a heifer and two sheep, which will be sold after fattening.

Bekturova Z. is the treasurer of the group. She's 49 and has raised two children a daughter and a son. Her daughter is a pupil, and the son helps her in selling the cattle. Z.'s husband works as a security guard, earning 5500 soms ($119.85) per month. Z. is requesting a loan to purchase two heifers in order to increase their livestock.

Ryskulov S. is 44, married, and has a 4-year-old daughter. Within the month his wife will begin to sell fruits and vegetables in the market. S. and his friend work in the market too, selling vegetables and earning 5000 soms ($108.95) per month. With the money received from the loan, Syrpay plans to purchase hosiery and children's clothes in order to resell them. In the future he wishes to increase the turnover, install a new gate at home and purchase a container.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: For puchasing clothes that will be resold

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou  M. est une vendeuse de divers produits comme des pots de fleur, produits de lessive, des sacs, lampes, montres, chaussures … etc.  Elle est dans cette activité depuis 3 ans avec l’aide de son mari qui ne cesse de l’encourager. Agée de 36 ans, Madame Fatou M. est mère de 5 enfants et souhaitait un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour renforcer son business.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou M. sells various products such as flower pots, laundry detergent, bags, lighting fixtures, watches, shoes, etc. She has been in business for the past three years and receives continued encouragement from her husband. Mrs. Fatou M. is 36 years old, the mother of five children, and is requesting a loan for 100,000 FCFA to strengthen her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: resupply with various products

loans.name: Jesus Is Lord Group

texts.en:
Annie S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Jesus Is Lord'.  She is 42 years old, married, and has six children who range from 8 to 27 years old.  Annie was only able to attend school through 9th grade, because she began to have children.

For over 9 years, Annie has been selling dried goods like peppers, charcoal and seasonings on Capitol Bye Pass in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She says customers are attracted to her business because she has developed a good relationship with them. Her dream is to expand her business to a mini-store.

Annie plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 42,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more peppers, rice, and oil.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Annie is the one holding the sign. And Sarah is in the inset at lower right.

loans.use: To buy more peppers, rice, and oil for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more fish and kerosene to sell

loans.name: Gislaine

texts.fr: S. Gislaine  est née le 13 Août 1985 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Gislaine est mariée à OGNIN Eric, un instituteur. Le couple a cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Gislaine et son mari vivent depuis trois ans avec leurs enfants, au quartier Agbalilamè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Gislaine a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis cinq ans environs, Gislaine vend des céréales et du charbon de bois à son domicile, ce qui lui permet de se faire des revenus l’aidant à assurer les besoins de sa famille et à se prendre en charge. Gislaine achète ses produits à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Gislaine a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit à ALIDé et l’a bien remboursé. Compte tenu de la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle, Gislaine sollicite un deuxième prêt pour renforcer son activité et accroître son profit.
texts.en:
Gislaine S. was born 13 August 1985 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is married to Eric OGNIN, a schoolteacher. The couple have five children, of whom some are attending school. For the past three years Gislaine and her husband have been living with their children in the Agbalilamé borough in the commune of Sèmè-Podji. Gislaine interrupted her studies at the secondary level. For the past five years she has been selling cereals and charcoal from her home, and the earnings enable her to meet her own and her family’s needs. She buys her products in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which was fully reimbursed. Customer demand is currently such that she is requesting a second loan to strengthen her activity and increase her profits.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grain cereals (millet, sorghum, corn, etc.)

loans.name: Rizeq

texts.en:
Rizeq, who lives and works in Ramallah City, has been a perfume and accessories distributor in Ramallah District since 2005. He buys accessories, perfumes, make-up, etc., and distributes them in Ramallah City and to shops and stores in the neighboring villages. After five years in the market, Rizeq has become a well-known and hard-working merchant.

Rizeq asked for a $1000 loan from FATEN to start his own store where he will sell the products that he distributes, in addition to distributing them. Rizeq will use the loan to paint and decorate the store and prepare it to exhibit goods. 

Rizeq's job is rewarding and he hopes the store prospers and becomes a major one in the city of Ramallah.

In the picture, Rizeq appears in the FATEN office.

loans.use: Store start-up

loans.name: Good Friends Group

texts.en:
Klubo M. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Good Friends'.  She is 45 years old, married, and has four children who range from 11 to 23 years old.  She was only able to attend school through 11th grade.

For 10 years, Klubo has been selling cooking oil and pork at the Old Road Market, on the outskirts of Monrovia.  She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.  She started this business with the help of a friend; lack of sufficient working capital to buy more goods is her major challenge. 

Klubo plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cooking oil and pork.  Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Klubo is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil and pork.

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr: A 45 ans cette dame reste une dame très dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de  charbons de bois . le stock de charbons de bois est épuisé, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des sacs charbons de bois. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants.
texts.en:
At 45 years of age, this lady is quite dynamic. Her revenue-generating activity is selling charcoal. Her stock is at present depleted, and she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy sacks of charcoal. She is married and the mother of two children.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Gborbaah Group

texts.en:
Sarah K. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'Gborbaah'. She is 42 years old, married with 4 children who range from 13 to 28 years old. She also cares for 4 step-children. Sarah is a nurse by profession.

For 2 years she has been selling medical drugs at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. She started her drugs sales with a little  earned money. She sometimes faces problems with traveling from one place to another to sell drugs and also has problems with low working capital.

Sarah sells good drugs at a reasonable price to keep customers returning. Her goal and dream is to own a medical store and improve the living conditions of her family. She needs this loan to purchase more medications for sale.

In the photo that accompanies the profile, Sarah is holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase more medications for sale

loans.name: Bérénam

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits cosmétiques, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2007 et s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, son stock de marchandises s’épuise, elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de mèches, tissages et divers produits de beauté
Elle est mariée et a un enfant. Avec ce qu’elle gagne de son commerce, elle contribue aux charges financières de son foyer.
texts.en:
This woman generates revenue by selling beauty products. She has practiced this activity since 2007 and gets her supplies from Lomé’s main market. Her stock supply is decreasing to the point where she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy hair extensions, hair weaves and various beauty products. She is married and has one child. Her commercial earnings contribute to managing household expenses.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy beauty products

loans.name: Aakuvi

texts.fr:
Cette femme est a appris la couture, en 2005 elle a ouvert son propre atelier qu’elle a appelé « HAUTE COUTURE LA JAUVIALE » plus tard elle a associé à ce commerce la vente des articles de mercerie et de pagnes ainsi elle réalise de très bons chiffre d’affaire chaque jour. Elle veut agrandir le commerce de pagnes et des articles de mercerie raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de divers articles de merceries et des pagnes.
Elle est mariée et a 3 enfants.
texts.en:
This lady learnt the sewing trade and in 2005 opened her own workshop, whch she named "HAUTE COUTURE LA JAUVIALE". Later on she complemented this business with the sale of haberdashery products and "pagnes" (pieces of colourful West African fabric). She thus makes a good turnover every day. She would like to expand the "pagnes" and haberdashery business, and, for this reason she is requesting a loan from WAGES in order to buy various haberdashery products and "pagnes". She is married and has three children.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of haberdashery products and "pagnes"

loans.name: Flahn Town Women Group

texts.en:
Cecelia J. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called 'Flahn Town Women'. She is 45 years old, married, and has six children who range from 15 to 28 years old.  She was not privileged to go to school due to poverty.

For 19 years, she has been selling dried fish at the Flahn Town Market in Battery Factory, on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.  

She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish.  Her goal is to grow her business and get involved in a wholesale  activity and  continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Cecelia is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more fish.

loans.name: God Is Able Group

texts.en:
Weedor S. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'God Is Able'. She is 33 years old, married with 2 children who are 13 and 16 years old. She could not continue her education through elementary school.

For 4 years she has been selling general goods on a table at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. She started selling with a loan from her family. She faces problem with a low customer base due to her migrating from one business site to another. She renders good service to customers to keep them returning.

Her goal and dream is to increase her business size and give her family an education to have a better life. She plan to use her 10,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 46,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to purchase more goods for sale.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Weedor is holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for sale

loans.name: Fausto

texts.en:
Fausto M. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 50 years old. Fausto is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Fausto owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Fausto has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately  5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Fausto joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fausto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Fausto is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Fausto from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of his children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Thaer

texts.en: Thaer A. N. is a 22 year-old unmarried man from A. Hasera, Gaza. Thaer has a grocery store and he would like this loan in order to enlarge his business by buying new equipment.  This will allow him to increase his income.

loans.use: To enlarge his business.

loans.name: Today Sunshine Group

texts.en:
Deddeh W. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'Today Sunshine'. She is 38 years old, married with 5 children who range from 2 to 21 years old. She also cares for her husband. Deddeh could not continue her education through elementary school because she started having children.

For 6 years she has been selling provisions at the Wroto Town community in Sinkor Monrovia, Liberia. She started business with 1,000 Liberian dollars as working capital but now has more than 20,000 Liberian Dollars as working capital. Deddeh keeps her goods very clean in order to keep customers returning.

Her goal and dream is to purchase a plot of land to construct a house. She plan to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 36,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to purchase more provisions for sale.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Deddeh is holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Affoussatou

texts.fr: O. Affoussatou est née en 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Affoussatou vit depuis près de dix-huit ans à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmé-Podji. Mariée à RAZAK Mansourou, un revendeur, Affoussatou est mère de quatre enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la famille. Affoussatou n’est jamais allée à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et apporter une aide à son mari, Affoussatou mène comme activité la vente de divers produits de mercerie à son domicile. Affoussatou exerce cette activité depuis douze ans environs et a déjà bénéficié de crédits auprès de ALIDé. Affoussatou est une bonne cliente de ALIDé. Face à l’accroissement de sa clientèle, et ne disposant pas suffisamment de moyens pouvant lui permettre de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Affoussatou sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Affoussatou O. was born in 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Affoussatou has lived for almost 18 years in Lokokoukoumé, in the municipality of Sèmé-Podji. Married to Mansourou RAZAK, a retailer, she is mother to four children, of whom some attend school. The couple covers the various family expenses between them. Affoussatou never went to school. In order to provide for her needs and support her husband, she has an activity selling various haberdashery products from her home. She has been carrying out this activity for around twelve years and has already taken out loans from ALIDé. Affoussatou is a good client of ALIDé. As her customer base is growing and she does not have sufficient means to increase her business or satisfy better her customer demand, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of haberdashery products

loans.name: Asem

texts.en:
Asem is a 52-year-old husband and the father of three sons and one daughter. One of the sons is a school teacher who helps his father with household expenses. The other three children are college and high-school students. Asem is a literacy teacher.

Asem took a $1000 loan from FATEN to pay for his son's college tuition fees. He hopes that the son finishes his education and finds a good job, which will help his brother and sister continue their education.

In the picture, Asem appears at the FATEN office in Qalqilia.

loans.use: Pay for his son's college tuition

loans.name: Odette Meddiani

texts.fr: Cette dame s’est lancée en 2007 dans le commerce de charbons de bois, elle exerce son commerce dans son quartier et elle a l’avantage d’être  la seule à faire ce commerce dan son quartier, une partie de son stock de charbons de bois a été détruite par la pluie, voulant se réapprovisionner elle sollicite pour sa première fois un crédit de WAGES afin de s’acheter 46 sacs de charbons de bois. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.
texts.en:
In 2007 this lady set herself up selling charcoal. She carries out this business in her neighborhood and has the advantage of being the only person to do so. A part of her stock of charcoal was destroyed by rain, and as she wants to get fresh supplies she is requesting a first loan from WAGES, in order to buy 46 sacks of charcoal. She is married and mother to one child.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more salon materials to boost her business

loans.name: Omolala

texts.en: Omolala has a hair dressing salon where she makes lovely Nigerian and western hair styles for her customers. She also sells hair extensions. She loves this business because she makes her customers look good. She hopes to grow to become a world class salon in the future. She is 37 years old, married with two children. Her children are doing well at school. Her husband is a welder and he also supports their home. Omolala is requesting a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Women Together #2 Group

texts.en:
Marie T., holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Women Together #2. She is 39 years old, single with five children between 9 and 22. She could not continue her education through high school due to financial problems.

For five years she has been producing and selling a locally made washing soap, called Iron Soap, at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia.

She started her business with 2,000 Liberian Dollars and now has 7,000 Liberian Dollars as working capital. Her problem is the large number of competitors at her business site. Marie sells quality soap to keep customers returning. Her goal and dream is to expand her business into a factory and improve her family's living conditions. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to purchase oil and caustic soda to produce more soap.

loans.use: To purchase oil and caustic soda to produce more soap.

loans.name: Fatheya

texts.en:
Fatheya R. is a 53-year-old wife and the mother of two daughters and two sons. Her husband is a retired teacher who owns land in the Jenin area where he grows seasonal fruits and vegetables.

Fatheya wants to help her husband work the land and improve its produce. Therefore, she took a loan from FATEN to purchase a greenhouse to grow more vegetables and fruits. Fatheya says that this will increase their income and improve the family's situation.

Fatheya likes taking care of plants, as is apparent from the background of the picture, where she stands at her front yard.

loans.use: Purchase a greenhouse

loans.name: Papa God Group

texts.en:
George J. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Papa God. He is 37 years old, single with an eight-year-old child who is in the 4th grade. He also cares for two siblings. George is a high school graduate but could not continue his education through college due to poverty.

For almost two years he has been selling mobile phone recharge cards and exchanging local currency to United States Dollars at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. George started his business with about 14,000 Liberian Dollars and now has more goods and cash on hand. He sometimes faces problems with people bringing counterfeit currency to exchange. George sells recharge cards at a reasonable price and exchange currency at a low rate in order to keep customers returning. His goal and dream is to ensure the growth of his business and improve his family's living conditions. George plans to use his 10,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 47,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to purchase more recharge cards for his business.

In this photo, George is holding the sign. Sam F. is inset at the lower right because he was not in attendance at the group's meeting when the photo was taken.

loans.use: To purchase more recharge cards for his business.

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Cecelia T.. holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Sister. She is 29 years old, single with three children between 8 and 12 years old. Cecelia did not have the opportunity to go school due to lack of financial support.

For three years, she has been selling foods like rice, oil and fish on Broad Street, down town Monrovia, Liberia. She started by selling cold water but moved up to selling food. Cecelia prepares her food in an attractive way to encourage customers to keep returning. Her goal and dream is to own a restaurant in the future. Cecelia plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice and oil. Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To purchase rice, oil, and other cooking materials

loans.name: Seydina Ousmane

texts.fr: Monsieur Seydina Ousmane N. né en 1986 est un jeune célibataire très dynamique. C'est un menuisier de métier mais s'active également dans l'aviculture depuis 4 ans pour diversifier ses activités et faire face aux difficultés du métier de menuisier dues à la rarification des marchés. Cependant, il compte acheter avec ce prêt des poussins, aliments et matériels de volaille pour augmenter sa production et de gagner plus de marchés.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydina Ousmane N. was born in 1986 and is a very dynamic young single man. He is a carpenter by profession but in order to diversify his activities and cope with the difficulties of the carpentry trade resulting from a scarcity of customers, he has also been active in poultry farming for four years. With this loan he is planning on buying chicks, food and equipment for poultry farming, so he can increase his production and get more customers.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chicks, food for poultry and equipment for poultry farming

loans.name: Muna

texts.en:
Muna A. O. is a wife and a mother of five daughters from Jenin city, and BA degree student. Her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee and owns bee cells where he produces honey to sell, but still the family income is relatively low and doesn't cover family and university expenses.

Muna took a $500 loan from FATEN to cover her tuition fees, hoping that once she graduates she will be able to support the family and help her husband Oqba cover household expenses.

Oqba, Muna's husband, appears in the picture above at FATEN's office because Muna doesn't accept having her picture published online.

loans.use: To pay off tuition fees

loans.name: Group Of Family

texts.en: Cecelia K., holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Group of Family. She is 60 years old, married with five children. Cecelia did not have the opportunity to go to school due to lack of funds. For 30 years she has sold fish on a table at the Jacob Town market in Paynesville, Liberia. Cecelia gives good service to customers to keep them returning. She started selling with a loan from her family. Cecelia lacks good shelter in the market hall for her business. Her goal and dream is to own a shop to increase her profit. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to purchase more fish for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more fish.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Fathma

texts.fr: Madame Fathma S. âgée de 46 ans est veuve en charge de ses enfants. Elle gère son propre commerce depuis 15 ans en aménageant une petite boutique chez elle. Son activité consiste à vendre des denrées alimentaires, produits de lessive et tout produits qui entre dans la marche quotiedienne des femmes ménagères. Elle sollicite un prêt de 200 000 FCFA pour renforcer la boutique.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fathma S. is 46 years old and a widow who supports her children. She has been managing her own business for the past 15 years in a little shop she fitted out in her home. Her activity is the sale of foodstuffs, washing products and all other products which housewives are likely to buy. She is requesting a loan of 200,000FCFA to strengthen her shop.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get fresh supplies of goods

loans.name: Leela Group

texts.en:
Betty T. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Leela Group. She is 40 years old and is married with five children who range from 14 to 20 years old. She also cares for two siblings. Betty could not continue her education through 6th grade due to lack of support.

For 25 years Betty has been selling foodstuffs such as pepper, garden eggs (eggplant) and okra at the Red Light market in Paynesville, Liberia. She started her business with 50,00 Liberian dollars as working capital. She sometimes faces problems with so many competitors around her business site.

Betty’s goal and dream is to grow her business and improve the living conditions of her family. She plans to use her 16,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 70,000 Liberian dollar loan to purchase more garden eggs, pepper and okra for sale.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Betty is holding the sign. Darlington T. is inset at the lower right because he was not in attendance at the meeting when the photo was taken.

loans.use: To purchase more garden eggs, peppers and okra for sale

loans.name: Serigne Mory

texts.fr: Monsieur Serigne Mory N. est un marchand ambulant depuis 7  ans. Il vend diverses marchandises comme du pain de singe, de l’arachide, du piment, poivre …. etc. Il compte avec son business nourrir sa femme et ses  trois petits enfants dont le plus âgé vient de souffler sa onzième bougie. D’ailleurs ce prêt va lui permettre de renforcer et de positionner son commerce
texts.en:
Mr. Serigne Mory N. has been a street vendor for seven years. He sells various articles such as “pain de singe” (baobab fruit), peanuts, pimento, pepper, and so on. He depends on this business to support his wife and three young children, the oldest of whom has just had to blow out the 11th candle on the birthday cake. This loan would allow him so strengthen his business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various articles for resale

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr: A. Chantal est née en 1987 à Togbato-Oudjra et est mariée à GNONLONFOUN Sylvain, un commerçant. Le couple a deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. La famille vit ensemble au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis quatre ans. Chantal assure avec son mari, les diverses charges familiales. Chantal n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour assurer ses besoins, et contribuer aux charges de la maison, Chantal vend de l’huile d’arachide à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Chantal commercialise des cartes de recharges téléphoniques. Chantal s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Chantal a déjà obtenu un crédit de ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Chantal ambitionne rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux répondre à la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle. C’est donc pour augmenter son stock de produits que Chantal sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Chantal A. was born in 1987 in Togbato-Oudjra and is married to a trader, Sylvain Gnonlonfoun. The couple has two children, of whom one is in school. The family has lived together in the neighborhood of Avotrou in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin, for four years. With her husband, Chantal provides for the various family expenses. Chantal did not attend school past elementary level. In order to meet her needs and those of her household, Chantal sells peanut oil from her home. Secondly, Chantal sells rechargeable phone cards. Chantal buys her stock in Dantokpa, the international market in Bénin. Chantal has already received a loan from ALIDé, which she has fully reimbursed. Chantal hopes to build up her business and better respond to the many demands of her clientele. Thus, it is to increase her backstock of products that Chantal asks for a second loan.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying drums of peanut oil

loans.name: Lord Abett Group

texts.en:
Augustine S. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Lord Abett. He is 29 years old, is single, and has one child who is three years old. Augustine was only able to attend school through 12th grade.

For six years, Augustine has been selling provisions like soap, body cream hair grease, and toothpaste on Mechlin Street, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He sells in a friendly manner which keeps his customers returning.

Augustine plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more provisions like soap, body cream, hair grease, and toothpaste. His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Augustine is the one holding the sign. Inset at the lower left is Regino G..

loans.use: To buy more soap, body cream, hair grease, and toothpaste.

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en:
Kehinde is the mother of four and she is 50 years of age. She sells and supplies building materials like sand, gravel and granite and she has been in the business for about twelve years.

With her years in the business, Kehinde is well-known and she has numerous customers. She is very happy with her business improvement but wants more growth in future. She wishes to improve her business so that she can make more profit to reinvest and take good care of her family.

Kehinde needs the loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more building materials like sand, gravel and granite to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials like sand, gravel and granite to sell

loans.name: Fermin

texts.es: El Sr. Fermín O. tiene 42 años de edad, esta casado hace 10 años, tiene 2 hijos pequeños que van a la escuela del pueblo, su pequeños ingresos están referidos a la producción de palmito, producto que  por su inestabilidad de precios hizo que, produjera un desequilibrio financiero en su hogar, en tal sentido la razón del crédito, tiene como objetivo la limpieza del terreno, para ya comenzar a cosechar y comercializar los tallos, ahora que los precios de mercado del producto están en alza, y de esta forma equilibrar nuevamente su pequeña economía hasta la próxima cosecha.
texts.en:
Mr. Fermín O. is 42 years old and has been married for 10 years. He has two young children who attend the local school. His humble income is from cultivating palm hearts. The variations in the price of this product have created an uncertain financial situation in his home. His goal for the loan is to clean his land to begin to harvest and sell the stalks, since they currently have a high market vaule. This will allow him to balance his budget until the next harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Semira

texts.en:
Semira M. makes and sells local brew and wines at home and is requesting a loan to also stock crates of beer to sell.  Semira is 32 years-old and is married with a husband that is a businessman. She has three children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.fr: Madame AÏssatou N. est aide-comptable au niveau de l’hôpital depuis 6 ans. Avec sa carte professionnelle, elle est autorisée à vendre à certains des produits médicaux dentaires comme du genre claf 1g, ampi 1g, bresto (10) …. Etc.  C’est ainsi qu’elle sollicite un prêt de 250 000 FCFA pour s’approvisionner en produits dentaires pour développer son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. AÏssatou N. has been an accountant's assistant at a hospital for six years. With her professional card, she is authorized to sell certain medical and dental products like claf 1g, ampi 1g, bresto (10), etc. Thus, she is asking for a loan of 250,000 FCFA to stock up on dental products to build up her business.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying dental products for resale

loans.name: Porferia

texts.en:
Porferia, 58, is married to Alfredo. They have seven children; the oldest is thirty-five.  She works hard to supplement her family's needs.  She spends most of her day keeping their farm free of pests and weeds. Porferia hopes to improve her next harvest and her earnings.

Porferia is applying for a loan of Php12, 000 from CEVI to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: Buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 39 years old and married with three children.  She is a proven entrepreneur well known in her business of selling cassava.  She has been in this business for about 22 years.  The hours of her business are from 6 am until late in the evening hours.  

Vestine is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to satisfy the demands of her customers by purchasing a large quantity of cassava.  With her client satisfaction, Vestine expects to earn more profits which will allow her to build her own house.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of cassava

loans.name: Hannan

texts.en:
Hannan J. sells beer at her bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Hannan is 31 years-old and is married with a husband that is a builder. She has three children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her bar.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen P., 37 owns a sari-sari store owner and is a farmer from Banga Agusan del Sur.  She started her business in 1996 and uses her income to help educate her three children.  Her oldest child is in high school.  She dreams that someday her children would be able to finish their studies.  Helen would like a loan of Php 15,000 to buy more merchandise to sell.  Helen joining the CEVI credit program in 2009.  CEVI gives insurance coverage to all the members.

loans.use: Buy additional merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is happy farmer. She is 46 years old and started tilling her own land a couple of years ago.  Thelma and her husband both work hard to keep their farm productive.  One of Thelma's goals is to have all their seven children finish college and find suitable jobs. 

Thelma recently applied for a loan of Php12, 000 from CEVI to buy farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She hopes to have an abundant harvest so she will have enough income to pay for school enrollment.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Nyantid

texts.en:
Nyantid E. sells groundnuts and simsims (sesame seeds) at the market and is requesting a loan to also stock maize and cassava flour to sell.  Nyantid is 39 years-old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has four children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase maize and cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Mama

texts.fr: Madame Mama D. est mère de 2 jumeaux âgés de 3 ans et d’un petit enfant d’un an. Elle est vendeuse de divers éléments depuis 12 ans.  Commençant dans le métier de l’aviculture, Madame Mama D. se voit complètement virer dans le commerce de tissus, draps, poulets et de moutons. Elle compte avec ce prêt acheter des draps à Touba (ville religieuse située à 180 Kms de Dakar) et des moutons  à Kaolack sa ville d’origine. Cependant, elle va élever ces moutons pour préparer une opération Tabaski (fête du sacrifice qui va se fêter en Novembre prochain). Ainsi, ce crédit va lui permettre de développer et renforcer son commerce.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mama D. is mother to three-year old twins and a one-year old baby. She has been selling a variety of items for the past 12 years. Having started her working life with poultry-farming, Mrs. Dialla completely changed direction by taking up the sale of fabrics, sheets, chickens and sheep. She is planning on using this loan to buy sheets in Touba (a religious town which lies 180 kilometers from Dakar) and sheep in Kaolack, the town where she comes from. She will raise the sheep in order to prepare for an "opération" (a fair initiated by the government where sheep will be sold directly to consumers) held at Tabaski (a sacrificial festival which will be celebrated next November). This loan will allow her thus to develop and strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get fresh supplies of goods

loans.name: Mila

texts.en: Mila B., 34 years old, lives in Trento Agusan del Sur.  She started her rice farm in 2008 and it sustains her entire family.  The income she gets from selling her harvest goes towards her child's education and for other basic need of her family.  At the moment, Mila is focused on how she will be able to improve her harvest.  That is why she requested a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and for other farming needs.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Elshad

texts.en:
Elshad M. is a 48-year-old trader who sells women’s clothes in the central market of Sabirabad city where he lives with his wife and three children.

Elshad started his business twelve years ago and, since that time, he has become very successful in his business. Usually he buys clothes from Baku city which is about three hours away from his city. It takes him a day to purchase all the clothes and then come back.

Elshad has very good taste and knows the demands of his customers. He applied for a 1,000 AZN loan in order to purchase seasonal clothes.

loans.use: To purchase more seasonal clothes

loans.name: Alberto

texts.es: EL SR. ALBERTO Z. TIENE 40 AÑOS, ESTA CASADO HACE YA 8 AÑOS, TIENE 2 HIJOS PEQUEÑOS QUE VAN CURSANDO EL NIVEL PRIMARIO, SU ACTIVIDAD ECONOMICA ESTA REFERIDA A ALA AGRICULTURA, ESPECIFICAMENTE A LA PRODUCCION DE BANANO. AL SER QUIEN SOSTIENE SU HOGAR Y BUSCA OFRECERLES A SUS 2 PEUQEÑOS HIJOS UNA MEJOR CALIDAD DE VIDA PUESTO QUE EL TRABAJO AGRICOLA EN EL TROPICO ES MUY DURA, PRETENDE MEJORAR  E INCREMENTAR SU PRODUCCION A TRAVES DE ESTE CREDITO QUE LE PERMITIRA LOGRAR EN PARTE SUS OBJETIVOS, EL EMPEÑO Y EMPRENDIMIENTO QUE LE DA A SU ACTIVIDAD A LA CUAL LE DEDICA GRAN PARTE DEL DIA INTERCALANDO SU TIEMPO TAMBIEN CON EL CUIDADO DE SU NIÑOS A LA VEZ ENSEÑANDOLES DE SU TRABAJO PARA QUE MAS ADELANTE EN UN FUTURO, PUDAN SOSTENERSE ECONOMICAMENTE DE FORMA INDEPENDIENTE MEJORANDO SU CALIDAD DE VIDA.
texts.en:
Mr. Alberto Z. is 40 years old, has been married for eight years, and has two young children who are in primary school. He works in agriculture, specifically with banana cultivation. He is responsible for providing for the home's expenses and he seeks to offer his two young children a better quality of life. Agricultural work in the tropics is very hard, and he intends to improve and increase production with a loan that will help him accomplish his goals. He demonstrates a lot of effort and hard work at his job, which he does for the majority of the day, but also has time to care for his children and teach them about his work so that someday in the future they will be able to support themselves financially and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improved banana production

loans.name: Karane

texts.en:
Karane J. sells used clothes and shoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock first class clothes and bedsheets to sell.  Karane is 29 years-old and is married with a husband that is a director. She has three children and they go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

Kiva partner BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and bedsheets to sell.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en: Lorena O., 36, uses her income to send her four children to school.  She is a rice farmer and has been growing rice since 1998.  She likes growing rice and dreamed that someday she will have a big farm.  Lorena would like a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies and to pay for labor.

loans.use: Farm supplies, payment for labor.

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en: Felilpa is a 54-year-old rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur.  She is married to Ricardo and they have five children. The eldest no longer lives with them. “My rice farm is doing quite well, by God’s grace”, shares Felipa.  She hopes to improve her harvest by working extra hard.  Felilpa applied for a loan of Php10, 000 from CEVI to buy farm fertilizers and other supplements.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Achike

texts.en:
Achike R. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock onions, cooking oil, etc., to sell.  

Achike is 31 years old and married to a policeman. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions, cooking oil, etc., to sell

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie, 27, lives in Agusan Del Sur and has 3 children.  She earns just enough money as a rice farmer to meet her family's needs.

She has joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and requests a loan of Php 7,000 to expand her business, with the hope that it will be sustainable in the future.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Loreta
