texts.en: Loreta was looking for financial support for her rice farm when she came across CEVI a couple of years back. For her, it was the best of timing. Loreta, a 46-year-old married woman with three children who all go to school, helps her husband maintain their rice farm and keep it productive. She is very thankful for the financial assistance gained upon joining CEVI. She recently applied for a loan amounting to Php12,000 which, If received, will be used to acquire the necessary inputs her farm lacks, such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Matha

texts.en: Mrs. Matha M. is a farmer who lives in the village of Thecho. She owns a piece of land on which she grows green vegetables which she sells in the local market every morning and evening. She uses her income to pay for her daughter's education, and is applying for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm. Mrs. M.'s husband Raj is a laborer who builds houses; their daughter is in the 10th grade.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Assinath

texts.en:
Assinath is 28 years old and married with two children and five dependents between the ages of 1 and 10 years old.  Assinath has been struggling to sell a variety of goods in her small shop, as shown in her photo.  In addition, she sells some drinks and pastries.  Assinath has been in her business for about nine years and her shop is open from 6 am to 9 pm every day.

Assinath is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her shop by adding a variety of goods, mainly foodstuffs like rice, sugar, beans, etc.  With these additional goods for sale, Assinath hopes that she will earn more profits as well as create many sources of income which will finally result in creating jobs for people in her community.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods (mainly foodstuffs like rice, sugar, bean,s etc.)

loans.name: Wevina

texts.en: Wevina C., 51 years old, is a farmer and a sari-sari store owner. She sells a variety of goods and at the same time grows rice in Trento Agusan Del Sur. Wevina has two children, the eldest eight years old. Because a very small capitalization impedes her dreams of expanding her business, she is requesting a loan of Php 14,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy additional merchandise for the store as well as farm supplies.

loans.use: Additional merchandise to resell and farm supplies

loans.name: Nida

texts.en: Nida, a 45-year-old mother of four children in Agusan Del Sur, is able to sustain her family through rice farming. Her farming income enables her to send her children to school. Nida is requesting a loan of Php 7,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help her to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Sanu Maiya

texts.en: Mrs. Sanu Maiya M. lives in the village of Thecho, which is located in the Lalitpur district. Thecho is growing quickly and most people who live there are farmers. Mrs. M. and her husband, Mr. Ganesh M., have one son. Her husband makes a living as a secondary school teacher and their son is a driver. Mrs. M. makes a living as a farmer, growing green vegetables which she sells in the local market. She has applied for a loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for her farm.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Sergio

texts.es:
El Sr. Sergio vive en el barrio Toborochi zona Pampa de la isla de la cuidad de Santa Cruz, se encuentra alquilando un domicilio que consta de 2 cuartos, en la cual vive con sus cuatro hijos y su esposa la Sra. Maria.
El se dedica al servicio de transporte urbano, cuenta con un vehiculo propio el cual fue adquirido con su esfuerzo propio, ademas de esto tambien tiene conocimiento de mecanica automotriz, actualmente no cuenta con un taller bien establecido pero tiene lo escencial que son las herraminetas de trabajo, su esposa la Sra. Maria apoya tambien con otro ingreso de la venta de comidas, el mismo que es comercializado en su domiclio, el fin del prestamo solicitado sera invertido en la construccion de un mini galpon y elaboracion de un letrero que indique su nuevo taller mecanico, su objetivo es llegar a colocar un taller mas comodo para la buena atencion de sus clientes. El Sr. Sergio es un apersona responsable y trabajadora con muchas ganas de superacion,esta muy agradecido con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Sergio lives in the Toborochi neighborhood, Pampa area, of Santa Cruz, Bolivia. He is renting a home with 2 rooms in which he lives with his four children and his wife Maria. He works for a shuttle service. He owns his own vehicle which he acquired through his hard work. He also knows auto mechanics and currently does not have a well established workshop, but he has the essentials which are the tools. His wife Maria also helps earn money by selling food from their house. The requested loan's purpose is to invest in the construction of a garage and making of a sign indicating the new mechanic's workshop. His goal is to make a more comfortable workshop to better serve his clients. Sergio is a hardworking and responsible person with desire to improve. He is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the confidence shown by giving him this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Gerrit Larsen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a garage

loans.name: Mojisola

texts.en:
Mojisola sells and supplies foodstuffs like bags of rice, beans and gallons of groundnut (peanut) oil. She travels outside Lagos to buy her goods. She has been in the business for the past seven years

Mojisola is 38 years old and she has one child. She lives in Lagos with her husband, who is a Navy officer.

Mojisola hopes for the loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs like rice, beans and groundnut oil to sell. This she said will reduce her traveling expenses, attract a greater discount and earn more profits.

Mojisola says thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs like rice, beans and groundnut oil to sell

loans.name: Ma. Linda

texts.en: The family of Ma. Linda, 42, is entirely dependent on the rice farm she and her husband till. While she is happy that their last harvest was good, she still hopes to increase its size.  Now preparing the farm for the next planting, she is applying to CEVI for a loan of Php 8,000 to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Prem Kumari

texts.en: Mrs. Prem Kumari M. is 39 years old and lives in the village of Thecho, Lalitpur, in a single family home with her husband, their son and their daughter. Her daughter is in the 8th grade and her son is in the 4th grade. She and her husband, Rabindra M., earn a living by making traditional idols. In Nepal, this type of work is very famous and the demand for their output is increasing. The couple has applied for money to buy raw materials to make more idols to meet the needs of their customers. Mrs. M. will use the additional income made possible by this loan to ensure a better education for her children and raise the living standards of her family.

loans.use: to buy raw materials used to make traditional idols

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma, a 45-year-old mother of four children in Agusan Del Sur, supports the basic needs of her family through rice farming.  She is now requesting a loan of Php 14,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to help support and sustain her business.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en: Raquel L., a 40-year-old mother of two, is a rice grower and sari-sari store owner from Trento Agusan del Sur, using her income to provide for her family's needs. She started her livelihood in 2005 and is working hard to realize her dream of having a bigger farm. Raquel is now requesting a loan of Php 11,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to buy farm supplies to grow her harvest and additional merchandise for her store.

loans.use: Farm supplies and additional merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Olga Katherine

texts.es: Se acerca el mes D. Mayo y con ello día en que Colombia conmemora a las madres, creado originalmente como “un día D. madres por L. paz”, que luego se convirtió en un día para cada familia en honor a su madre y se ha convertido en una fiesta en muchos lugares del mundo. En este mes D. Mayo se genera una gran dinámica comercial, porque se hace reconocimiento no solo a las madres biológicas, sino a todas las mujeres madres, o a quienes ocupan el papel D. madre. D. aquí se derivan  hermosos detalles y regalos dirigidos por jóvenes, adultos, niños, hombres y mujeres, a  suegras, hermanas, cuñadas, amigas y vecinas. Esta es L. razón por L. cual Olga Katherine D. L. R., mujer D.  gran experiencia en mercadeo, se prepara, invirtiéndole al negocio una mercancía ajustada a esta celebración, para hacer su oferta en el mes D. Mayo; elL. también decora, con motivos que expresan el amor D. madre, su otro negocio donD. presta el servicio D. fotocopiado e impresión; así lo ha hecho durante 4 años, en los que ha construido su mercado; hoy su clienteL. ha anticipado sus  pedidos D. vestidos, perfumes, carteras femeninas y necesita un crédito por valor D. $ 1.500.000 y   para poder responderle oportunamente está  solicitándolo su 5° financiamiento a L. Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Olga dice que los créditos logrados en esta organización,  le han servido para solventar su economía familiar, porque cuando elL. se inició como comerciante  en el año 2006, vendía solamente mercancía y tenía pocos clientes, y generaba pocos ingresos para su familia;  ahora no solo son familiares y vecinos sus clientes  sino también referidos D. sus amigos y ha logrado mas utilidades, porque además agregó otro negocio: el D. servicio D. fotocopiado e impresiones que le da L. oportunidad D. compartir su tiempo, entre las actividades productivas, reproductivas y domésticas. Ahora sueña con tener su propia casa, sacar adelante L. educación D. sus tres hijos en las edades D. 1 a 9 años, incrementar su negocio en ventas e infraestructura, y sobre todo continuar con su servicio D. calidad en L. atención a su especial clienteL., porque Olga Katherine, vive en el popular barrio CiudadeL. 20 D. Julio, y su ubicación L. aprovecha muy bien, teniendo en cuenta que en él interactúan residencias familiares, negocios estacionarios y ambulantes y está muy cerca al Estadio Metropolitano D. BarranquilL., escenario seD. del equipo D. futbol muy querido por los costeños “El Junior”
texts.en:
May is approaching, and with it the day that in Colombia commemorates mothers, created originally as "a day of mothers for peace", which later became a day for each family to honor its mother and has become a holiday in many parts of the world. In this month of May sales are high because recognition is given not only to biological mothers, but to all women who mother, or who fill the role of mother. Beautiful tokens and gifts are given by youths, adults, children, men and women, to mothers-in-law, sisters, sisters-in-law, friends and neighbors. This is the reason Olga Katherine D. L. R., a woman experienced in marketing, prepares by stocking her business with merchandise tailored to this celebration, to sell in the month of May; she also decorates her other business, where she offers photocopy and printing services, with motifs expressing love for mothers. She has done this for four years, the time in which she has run her business. Now her customers have given her orders for dresses, perfumes, and purses, and she needs a loan for 1500 Colombian pesos to be able to fill these orders. She is asking for her fifth loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. Olga says the loans she has received from this organization have helped her cover her household expenses, because when she began her life as a businesswoman in 2006, she only sold merchandise and had few customers, and earned little for her family. Now her customers are not only relatives and neighbors but also people referred to her by their friends, and she has maD. more profit because she also added another business: the photocopy and printing service that gives her the opportunity to diviD. her time among business and domestic activities. Now she dreams of having her own house, moving ahead with the education of her three children (ages one to nine years old), expanding her business' sales and infrastructure, and above all continuing with her quality service to her special customers, because Olga Katherine lives in the popular CiudadeL. 20 D. Julio neighborhood, and her location is very advantageous for her. In the neighborhood there are family residences, shops and traveling businesses, and it is very near the Metropolitan Stadium of BarranquilL., the home field for the "El Junior" soccer team, which is very popular with the coastal residents.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise including dresses, perfumes, and purses

loans.name: Maricor

texts.en:
Maricor M., 22 years old, owns a small rice farm. She uses her income to provide the basic needs of her family, things like food, clothing and medicine.

She started her farming when she was married. She helps her husband till the farm so that they will have an abundant harvest.

She is asking for a loan of PHP 11,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies, which she hopes could improve her harvest. She said she likes the services of CEVI because it also offers micro-insurance coverage to all its clients.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Sarmila

texts.en: Sarmila M. lives with her husband and two sons in Thecho, Lalitpur, a fast-growing part of Nepal. Her older son is studying in the fifth grade and her younger son is in pre-school. Mrs. M. and her husband, Saroj M., earn a living making different types of traditional brass religious idols. She used a previous loan from Kiva to buy raw materials to make additional items to sell. Now she is applying for a new loan for the same purpose because she is committed to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy raw materials for her business

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita, 32 years old, is a rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur.  She manages a rice field.  She also has a sari-sari store business.  She supports her family of four children and works hard in order to have a good harvest.

She is limited in her capital, so that’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail herself of a loan.  She’s requesting 7,000 PHP to support her business.

loans.use: For farm supplies

loans.name: Purita

texts.en:
Purita used to spend most of her time tilling her rice farm with her husband. When she was able to buy piglets, she focused her time raising them while her husband maintained the farm. She hopes to be successful in all her ventures and she also wants her family to be happy.

Purita is a member of CEVI and this is her second time to ask for a loan. She says that her first loan helped a lot in sustaining their rice farm and the pigs that she raises. She applied for a loan in the amount of PHP 7,000, which she will use to buy farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. She will also buy feed and supplements for the pigs.

loans.use: For farm supplies

loans.name: Constance

texts.fr: M. Constance est née en 1980 et vit depuis vingt ans environs à Sainte Cécile, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Constance est mariée à DOHOU Honoré, un soudeur, et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Constance vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la maison. Constance a bien vite abandonné l’école et a appris ensuite la coiffure. Constance exerce cette activité depuis une dizaine d’année. Parallèlement, Constance vend aussi des mèches, des pommades et d’autres produits de cheveux dans son atelier de coiffure, situé dans son quartier. Constance a déjà obtenu deux fois de prêt à ALIDé et les a tous bien remboursés. Constance désire agrandir davantage son atelier par l’achat d’autres produits de cheveux, ce qui lui permettra de mieux répondre à sa clientèle et de se faire plus de profits. C’est pour ce fait que Constance sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième crédit.
texts.en:
Constance M. was born in 1980 and has lived for around 20 years in Sainte Cécile, a district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Constance is married to Honoré DOHOU, a welder, and is mother to one child who attends school. She lives with her husband and child. The couple shares the various household expenses. Constance left school at an early age and learnt the hairdressing trade. She has been carrying out this activity for around ten Years. At the same time, she also sells hair extensions, creams and other hair products in her hairdressing salon, which is situated in her neighborhood. Constance has already had two loans from ALIDé and has repaid them both without problem. She would like to expand her salon by buying more hair products; this will enable her to respond better to customer demand and make more profit. For this reason, Constance is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair extensions, creams and beauty accessories

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of living of Susan, 64. She supports ten children in her family and her rice field is just enough to provide their basic needs.

Susan joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan to finance her business with a low interest rate. She’s requesting 7,000 Php to buy farm necessities so as to sustain her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lucebel

texts.en:
Lucebel N., 27 years old, owns and manages a small sari-sari (variety) store and also has a farm. She has two children, her eldest child being 6 years old. She would like to ensure that her children have a better future.

Lucebel wants to have a bigger farm in the future and that is why she labors so hard to be able to save money to realize her dreams. She would like to apply for a loan of Php 11,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise for her store and farm supplies for her farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies plus additional merchandise for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is the mother of two young children and her eldest is only aged three. Victoria is 39 years old and married to Edgardo. She dreams that her children will someday go to school and finish college. She and her husband work hard to supply food for their family and they’re also trying to save up for their children’s future.

Victoria and her husband both till a rice farm of their own. The farm currently needs inputs so she applied for a loan of Php 6,000. She will buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs once she receives the loan.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Teodoro

texts.en:
Teodoro, 39, lives in Agusan Del Sur where he has a rice-farming business. He devotes his time to working in his rice field.

Teodoro heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. that offers financial support to entrepreneurs like him, and he later joined on 2009.

Teodoro’s business is continually growing and now he is requesting a loan of 12,000 Php. This amount will be helpful to sustain his business with a low interest charge.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary sells planks at retail prices to her customers in Ibadan. She has been in this business for a long time and she uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers. She hopes to grow her business in the future.

Mary is 42 years old and is married with four children. Her children attend school and she hopes they become graduates very soon.

Mary is a hardworking woman and she is so determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more planks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more planks to sell

loans.name: Ganga Maiya

texts.en: Mrs. Ganga Maiya M. makes a living selling groceries in the village of Thecho. She opened a store in her home seven years ago as a way to improve her family's living conditions, and now sells a range of items such as rice, maize, noodles and biscuits. In order to help meet rising demand from her customers, she has applied for a loan to invest in her small business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell to her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila L., 51 years old, is a rice grower from Trento, Agusan del Sur. She has four children. Her eldest is 19 years old. She dreamed of sending all her children to school but then she has limitations because at the moment her family has financial problems. That is why she would like to focus on her business. She dreams of having a bigger farm someday. 

She would like to ask for a loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to improve her harvest.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Oluyole

texts.en:
Oluyole H. sells loudspeakers at retail prices to his customers. He loves this business because he is the only person in his neighborhood that sells these goods.

Oluyole is 55 years old and is married with four children. He is also a grandfather and this gives him joy.

Oluyole is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more loudspeakers to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more loudspeakers to sell

loans.name: Viateur

texts.en:
Viateur is 41 years old and married with three children who are 8, 10 and 12 years old.  Viateur has been a butcher for a long time ago.  The hours of his business are from morning until late in the evening hours.

Viateur is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase his sales.  With this additional business, Viateur will also start to sell the meat of goats, sheep and pigs.  If successful, Viateur will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow him to start saving and reinvesting in his business by creating many sources of income, as well as create jobs for the people in his community.

loans.use: A large quantity of various meat for sale.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita, 46, spends a lot of time managing her rice-farming business. She enjoys working on the farm because it provides for the food, shelter and clothing of her family. She is married to Wilfredo and they have five children.  

She would like to continue working on her farm for the sustenance of her family but is limited as to financing the business. That’s why she joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc.: to be able to take a loan intended for her business. She requested a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, enough to buy materials and supplies she needs for the farm.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Maria Luz

texts.en: Ma. Luz L., 27, uses her business income to provide for her three children's needs. At the moment, her eldest child is studying in a primary school. Ma. Luz L. started her business in 2004.  She would like to ask for a loan of 4,000 PHP from Kiva / Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will  use the loan to buy farm supplies. Hopefully, she will be able to double her harvest and provide enough income for her family.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 38 years old and is married with a child who is 12 years old and attends school.

Florence is a friendly and hardworking woman. She sells motor spare parts and loves this business because of the profits that she makes. She has been in this business for a long time and she hopes to excel in her business.

Florence is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie was given the opportunity to manage a rice farming business, and she maintains a rice field in Agusan Del Sur.  She is now 42 years old with 6 children to support, the eldest 6 years old.  She strives hard so that she can send her children to school and have them finish their studies.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asked for financial support for her business. She requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and seeds for the farm.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Céline

texts.fr: L. Céline est née le 31 Octobre 1980 et est mariée à BONOU François, un enseignant. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a près de huit ans que Céline vit au quartier Gbèdjromédé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle y vit avec ses enfants et son mari. Céline subvient, avec l’aide de son mari aux différents besoins de sa famille. Pour y arriver, Céline a commencé, il y a un an, la vente de tissus et des tenues pour femmes par le système de distribution dans les quartiers voisins du sien. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Céline se ravitaille. C’est la première fois que Céline sollicite auprès de ALIDé un concours financier, qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de renforcer son activité, pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Céline L. was born October 31, 1980 and is married to François Bonou, a teacher. The couple has three children, all of whom are in school. It was been nearly eight years that Céline has lived in the Gbèdjromédé neighborhood in Contou, the economic capital of Bénin, with her children and husband. With the help of her husband, Céline provides for her family's needs. In order to do so, Céline has begun, for the past year, to sell fabric and clothing for women, using a system of distribution in the neighborhood. It is in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin, that Céline resupplies. This is the first time that Céline has asked ALIDé for monetary aid, which will allow her to increase her profits and support her business, in order to better satisfy her clientele.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fabric

loans.name: Eusebio

texts.en: Eusebio is a 46-year-old married man from Trinidad, Bohol. He has a 9-year-old child whom he dreams to have a bright future. He has a small sari-sari (convenience) store that currently lacks merchandise. Eusebio wants to acquire vinegar, sugar and other products to meet the needs of his customers (neighbors and people around his community). He applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP from CEVI to buy this merchandise. He is hopeful that the loan will be granted and that he will have supplies for his store.

loans.use: additional merchandise

loans.name: Krishna Devi

texts.en:
Mrs. Krishna Devi M. is a resident and grocery shopkeeper in the village of Thecho, one of the developing villages of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in her region are engaged in farming. She opened her grocery store two years ago to improve her family's standard of living. She has one son, in grade 10, and one daughter, in grade 5. Her son helps his mother in her grocery store.

Mrs. Krishna Devi M. is requesting a loan of 25,000 NPR to buy various grocery items such as rice, maize, and snacks to expand her shop.

loans.use: to buy goods for her grocery shop

loans.name: Maria Cecilia

texts.en: Maria Cecilia L. is 41 years old and a rice grower. She uses her income to provide her family with adequate supplies of food, clothing and other basic needs. She is grateful to God because she is doing well in her business. She has one child who is 12 years old. At the moment, she is starting to save money for her child's college education. She would like to apply for a loan of 4,000 PHP to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en:
Marie Louise is 26 years old and married with one child who is 1 year old.  Marie Louise is well known in her business selling spare parts and this is her second successful year in the business.  Marie Louise works from 8 am to 6 pm every day.

Marie Louise needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that she can increase the size of her business by adding a larger quantity of different spare parts. With this loan, Marie Louise hopes that her profit will increase so that she can create some new sources of income as well as create more jobs for the people in her community.

loans.use: To stock a larger quantity of different spare parts

loans.name: Ma. Arlyn

texts.en:
Maria Arlyn, photographed here with her 2-month-old child, hopes to have a big grocery store someday. She is 35 years old and married with six children. She lives in Trinidad, Bohol, with her family. Her store is currently located at her house. She and her husband work their best to be able to send all their children to school and hopefully have them finish college someday. 

She wants to grow her store so she could also earn more and sustain their needs. She applied for a loan of 3,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, which she will use to buy sugar, oil and other merchandise she will sell at her store.

loans.use: Additional merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and kerosene to sell.

loans.name: Bijeshwori

texts.en:
Bijeshwori N. is a resident of Tangal, Lalitpur, and lives with her husband and one son. Tangal is a very busy shopping area of the Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses. It is especially famous for brass, copper, and bronze pots and utensils in different varieties.

Both Mrs. N. and her husband sell traditional stone statues. They started this work six years ago. They buy ready-made traditional statues and sell them in their shop. For this job, business owners need a lot of capital to invest in their shop.

The demand for these traditional statues is increasing constantly. To meet the demand of the customers, Mrs. N. is requesting a NPR 30000.00 loan to buy traditional stone statues to meet the demand of the customers. Their main targeted customers are foreigners.

loans.use: To buy stone statues

loans.name: Ram Payari

texts.en:
Mrs. Ram Payari N., 47 years old, lives in Tangal, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family household with her husband and three sons.

Her husband, Mr. Badri Man N., and her three sons make traditional idols. In Nepal, idol-making work is very famous, and the demand for idols is also increasing. They now need money to buy raw materials to make more traditional idols to meet the demand.

She seeks NPR 30000.00 loan to buy raw materials for making traditional idols.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making idols

loans.name: Leoncie

texts.en:
Leoncie is 42 years old and married with five children who are 10, 14, 16, 18 and 20 years old.  Leoncie owns a small shop selling a variety of goods such as juice, soaps, body lotion, cooking oil, etc.  This is her 21st successful year in this business. The hours of her business are from early in the morning until late in the evening hours.

Leoncie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by adding foodstuffs such as rice, beans, peas, Irish potatoes, etc.  With these additional goods for sale, Leoncie hopes that her profits will increase and allow her to continue taking care of her family and keep reinvesting for better financial stability in the future.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods such as juice, soaps, body lotion, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.en: Primitiva raises pigs to earn a living. She is 56 years old, married, with six children. She joined CEVI in 2005 but withdrew her membership to take a break. She rejoined because she thinks its program is really helpful to entrepreneurs like her who lack additional capital for their businesses. She recently applied for a loan of PHP 6,000. She will use it to buy additional piglets that she can raise. She will also purchase feed and supplements.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en: Boniface A. is 39 years old, married with 4 children.  He sells medicines at retail prices to his customers. His wife sells groceries to also support their home. Boniface loves this business because of the-one-on-one interaction with his customers.   He is requesting  a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. He says thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Marie Solange

texts.en:
Marie Solange is 26 years old and married with two children who are 3 and 4 years old.  Marie Solange struggles to sell a variety of goods, mainly plastic items usually used at home.  Marie Solange has been in her business for about two years. The hours of her business are from 6 am to 8 pm every day except Saturday.

Marie Solange realized that her working capital is not enough, and she wants to start selling drinks in her shop. She would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Marie Solange will hopefully earn more profit which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business for better sustainability. She really hopes that she will start saving for a better education for her children in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods, mainly plastic items

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Sumitra

texts.en:
Mrs. Sumitra S. is a grocery store keeper in the village of Chappagaun, lalitpur. She opened her grocery store to uplift the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of grocery goods, such as rice, maize, noodles, and biscuits, in her shop. Now due to increasing demand for grocery goods in her area she is requesting a 30,000 NPR loan to invest in her shop.

Mrs. Sumitra lives in a single family home with her husband and one daughter. Her husband is a laborer in house construction work, and her daughter is studying in pre-primary school.

loans.use: To buys grocery goods

loans.name: Willer

texts.en:
45-year-old farmer Willer plows a hectare rice field. He strives hard on his farm to support his three children. His eldest child is 14 years old. He wants to send his children to school so they can finish their studies. He wants to improve his farming to have greater earnings.

He heard that Community Economic Ventures, Inc. offers financial assistance to entrepreneurs like him. He joined and requested a loan of 12,000 PHP to support his farm business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Rosalita

texts.en:
Rosalita is a 49-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has one child who is now 25 years old. She started farming in 1989, and it has been the source of her income since. In 2005, she was introduced to Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI), an MFI in the Philippines. It was new to her, but she was interested in joining because she needed financial support for her farm. She said that she is happy she joined five years ago because the MFI’s program has been very helpful in maintaining her farm. She is now applying for a loan of 50,000 PHP, which she will use to buy farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer. She will also buy other farming materials that she needs.

“Asenso Loans are a new product offered by CEVI for clients showing strong performance in previous loans, and who need a larger loan in order to continue to develop. CEVI recognizes the importance of helping people out of poverty, as well as providing continuous support and training as these clients progress. CEVI aims to provide financial services, not only to our poorest clients, but also to our developing clients who should be rewarded for the way in which they display promising business skills. Please help us provide support for these clients.”

“CEVI has increased its portfolio significantly over the past 5 years. Based in Bohol, they have 22 branches throughout the Philippines, and will soon be adding two more branches. CEVI has recently been awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. Social performance monitoring is imperative in order to measure a microfinance institute’s effectiveness. The fact that CEVI is participating in this process speaks volumes. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. Please feel free to take a look at the CEVI website.”

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Alaba

texts.en: Alaba E. is 27 years old, married with 3 children. Her eldest child is 6 years old. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. Alaba sells clothes by hawking them on a cart within her community in Ibadan, Oyo state. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She is requesting a loan amount of N60,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. Alaba says thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mina K., who opened her cosmetics shop two years ago to improve her family’s standard of living, sells a variety of goods, including cream, makeup materials, and glass bangles. She spends her income to help her husband, Raghu Raj K., a government worker, cover the family’s expenses and is now requesting her second loan of 15,000 NPR to buy additional cosmetic goods for her shop.

The mother of two children, a son and daughter, Mina lives in a single family home with her husband and two children. Her daughter is taking the BSC (nursing) course, and her son is studying in university. Both also help her in her shop.

loans.use: To buy cosmetic goods

loans.name: Laetitie

texts.en:
Laetitie is 26 years old and married with two children.  Laetitie has been a proven entrepreneur in the business of raising hens.  This is her third successful year in this business. She starts at 6 am and works to 4 pm every day.

Laetitie is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for building her poultry business.  Laetitie hopes that the number of hens to be sold will increase as well as the profits.  With her profits, Laetitie hopes to continue to  develop herself and acquire many sources of income as well as create jobs for people in her community.

loans.use: To build a poultry where to rear hens

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en:
30-year-old Bumi is married and has one child. She lives and runs her business in Lagos. She owns a beauty salon and sells hair extensions, hair cream and hair treatments to earn a better living. She started the business 3 years ago and she has been able to use her years of experience to attract and retain more customers. 

Bumi wants her business to grow into a first class beauty salon in the future. She hopes for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell. This, she said, will increase her productivity and profitability, which will enhance her business growth and improve the living standard of her family. She appreciates all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell.

loans.name: Rama Shahi

texts.en:
Rama Shahi T. is a grocery shopkeeper in Sainbu-Bhaishepati, Lalitpur. She opened her grocery store five years ago, to upgrade her family's standard of living. She sells different types of groceries in her store. She is proud to help her husband fulfill the needs of the family. She sells a variety of groceries, such as rice, maize, noodles, and biscuits, in her shop. Now she is requesting a 25,000 NPR loan to buy different kinds of grocery items for her shop.

Mrs. Rama Shahi T. lives in a single-family house with her husband and two sons. Her husband works in a private office. Her older son is a house painter, and her younger son is in grade 12.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Akeem

texts.en: Akeem is a welder and he has been in this business for a long time. He is a hard-working man and he is determined to excel in his business. He is 45 years old and married, with 3 children. His wife sells cooking oil to support their family. He is requesting a loan of N70,000 to purchase more welding materials to boost his business. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more welding materials to boost his business

loans.name: Aboubakal

texts.en:
Aboubakal is 35 years old and married with two children who are 3 and 6 years old.  Aboubakal is well known in the business of selling spare parts and this is his third successful year in the business.  Aboubakal works from 7 am to 8 pm every day.

Aboubakal needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that he can increase the size of his business by adding a larger quantity of different spare parts, mainly those used on cars of high level (Mercedes Benz). With this loan, Aboubakal hopes that his profits will increase to the extent the he is expecting, so as to create some sources of income as well as more jobs for people in his community.

loans.use: To purchase additional spare parts for sale

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: La Sra.  Julia es nacida en la cuidad de Cochabamba de 53 años de edad, se vino de la ciudad de Cochabamba, buscando trabajo y conocio con el que ahora es su esposo y se quedo a vivir en Santa Cruz, ya radica en esta cuidad hace mas de 20 años en donde conformo su familia que esta compuesta por su esposo y dos hijos, actualmente vive en alquiler en el barrio los claveles de la zona Pampa de la Isla, es una persona muy amable, se dedica a la venta de verduras, esta actividad lo realiza ambulando calle por calle la mercaderia es transportada en un Carreton jalado por un par de caballos, los cuales facilitan su trabajo, su esposo el Sr. Hernan se dedica a la albañileria en su mismo barrio, el prestamo solictado sera para aumentar su mercaderia, e ir juntando de poco a poco para la compra de un lote y luego construir su propia casa, nos comenta que esta muy agradecida con nuestra institucion por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Julia, 53, was born in the city of Cochabamba. She left there looking for work and met her present husband in Santa Cruz; she has lived in this city for over 20 years and it is here that she formed her family composed of her husband and two children. She rents her home in the Los Claveles neighborhood in Pampa de la Isla zone. She is a very kind person who sells vegetables from a wagon pulled by two horses through the city streets; the horses make her work much easier. Her husband, Hernan, is a bricklayer in his neighborhood. She is asking for funds to increase her stock merchandise and to save up little by little to buy a lot on which to build their own house. She comments that she is very grateful with our institution for the trust placed in her by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegebables.

loans.name: Fasilatu

texts.en: Fasilatu sells groceries and sarongs at retail prices. With these businesses, she supports her husband in meeting the basic needs of their family. She is 45 years old and married, with 3 children. Her husband is a bricklayer and he also supports their family. She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more groceries and sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Biola

texts.en: Biola sells prepared food, drinks and juice in her shop and she has been in the business for the past 6 years. She is happily married with 4 children and she is 46 years of age. She lives in Lagos with her husband, who is a mechanical engineer.  She wants to expand her business in order to increase her profit. She needs a loan of NGN60,000 to purchase more food items and drinks to sell.  She says thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more food items and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata C. est âgée de 53 ans, mère de 8 enfants et vit dans une famille nucléaire avec son époux et ses enfants à Fana Coura un des quartiers la ville de Fana, Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.
 Fatoumata, après plus de 10 ans d’expériences, dans son activité de vente de céréales, elle vient de faire connaissance de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso qui occupe  de nos jours une place importante dans son activité.
Elle est à son quatrième prêt individuel et tous les précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Pour le nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, trois tonnes de céréales avec les fournisseurs venant des environnants de Fana.
Elle effectue sa vente sur place dans son magasin à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle espère avoir 129 000FCFA de bénéfice au cours de son cycle de prêt qui servira à couvrir les dépenses de la famille et les dépenses liées à l’activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatoumata C., age 53, is the mother of eight children and lives in a nuclear family with her husband and children in Fana Coura, a district in Fana City, Region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali. With over ten years of experience in her business selling grains, she was recently introduced to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, which has an important place in her work these days. She is on her fourth individual loan, and all the previous ones have been repaid. For the new loan, Fatoumata intends to buy three tonnes of grain from suppliers from the Fana area. She makes her sales locally in her store. Her customer base is composed of women and men. She hopes to obtain 120,000 francs CFA in profit over the course of her cycle. The profits will be used to cover family expenses, as well as those associated with her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Levocatte

texts.en:
Levocatte is 50 years old and married with children between the ages of 3 and 15 years old.  Levocatte is well known for her business selling a variety of goods, mainly cosmetic goods like body lotion, soaps, Colgate (toothpaste), etc. as shown in her photo.  This is her fourth successful year in her business. She works from early in the morning until late in the evening hours.

Levocatte is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand her shop by purchasing a large quantity of foodstuffs, mainly rice, peas, beans, wheat, etc.  With this additional business, Levocatte hopes that she will earn more profits to help her take care of her family and keep reinvesting for better progress in her business.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods, mainly cosmetic goods like body lotion, soaps, Colgate (toothpaste), etc.

loans.name: Nilsa Del Socorro

texts.es:
Desde el año 2004 por iniciativa propia Nilsa Y. C.,  inició su negocio con  la ayuda de su esposo y el objetivo de incrementar los ingresos del hogar, porque siempre ha pensado en la educación de sus tres hijos menores de edad, y en construir para ellos un  mejor futuro.

Con su negocio ha afianzado sus potencialidades emprendedores, su carácter independiente y todo esto acompañado con el hecho de participar en proceso formativos empresariales,  la han llevado a fortalecer su desempeño organizacional en la microempresa de mercancías en punto de venta, que es de su propiedada, donde comercializa papelería en general, calzado, vestuario para damas accesorio, juguetería. Nilsa quiere fortalecer la oferta de sus servicios y para este propósito está aplicando a su cuarto crédito, ella requiere un monto de $1.300.000 que invertirá en la compra de artículos de miscelánea como accesorios femeninos, collares, aretes, cintas,  cartulinas y útiles escolares.

Nilsa sueña con el crecimiento de su negocio, por eso siempre está invirtiendo en él y buscando nuevos clientes, para   poder ofrecerle a sus hijos mejores niveles educativos; ella vive muy satisfecha en el barrio Galán de Barranquilla  y resalta de este sector  un alto nivel de civismo, solidaridad y trabajo en equipo, que han permitido la convivencia pacifica y la realización de actividades donde todos sus moradores  ponen y el estado también, para mejorar el entorno como ocurrió con la pavimentación de sus calles.
texts.en:
In order to help her husband increase household income and always thinking of her three children’s education and in building a better future, Nilsa Y. C. started her business in 2004. Her business has solidified her enterprising potential, her independent character and all of this has gone hand in hand with business training that has made it possible for her to strengthen the organizational development of her micro enterprise consisting of assorted merchandise sales. She offers a variety of stationery supplies, shoes, women’s clothing and accessories and toys. Nilsa wants to strengthen her offer even more so is asking for her 4th loan valued at $1.300.000 that she will use to buy assorted merchandise like: women’s accessories, necklaces, earrings, belts, and construction paper and school supplies. Nilsa dreams with her business’ growth so she is always investing in it and looking for new customers so that she can offer her children advanced educational levels. She lives very contentedly in Barranquilla’s Galán neighborhood, an area that stands out due to its high level of civic pride, solidarity and teamwork that have made possible a peaceful coexistence and the neighborhood’s ability to reach common neighborhood improvement goals with help from the State like it was with the paving of the streets.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted merchandise like: women's accessories, necklaces, earrings, belts, construction paper and school supplies.

loans.name: María

texts.es: María tiene 28 años, casada, tiene una pequeña hija, quien debe velar por ella ya que su salud es delicada. Juntos viven en su casa propia. El negocio al que se dedica, es la venta de pescado en un puesto que tiene dentro de unos de los mercados más concurridos del Balneario de Ancon.  Para ello, su esposo la ayuda atendiendo al público. Su rutina diaria es desde muy temprano ir al muelle a conseguir los productos frescos del mar, en que luego le da la respectiva limpieza, para ser vendidos rápidamente en su puesto, por ello su ritmo es muy agitado, ya que siendo un producto perecible tiene que venderse lo mas pronto posible. María se siente contenta porque trabaja al lado de su esposo, ya que a veces tiene que faltar a su puesto para atender su hija. Su mayor anhelo es tener un negocio más amplio, pero por el momento es continuar con su trabajo para que pueda darle un mejor beneficio a su hija. Este es su sexto crédito con MFP, por tanto promete en ser bien puntual con todos sus pagos, como lo fue en el ciclo anterior. Con el crédito que solicita, comprarán más pescado para que puedan generarse más ingresos.
texts.en:
María, 28, is married and has a daughter who she must watch over because her health is delicate. They live together in their own home. She sells fish in a stand that she has in one of Ancon’s beach resort’s most popular markets. Her husband helps her take care of customers. Her daily routine consists of going to the fishing pier very early to obtain the freshest products from the sea. Once she cleans them properly they must be sold quickly. Her work pace is quite agitated because this is a perishable product that must be sold as quickly as possible. María is very happy to be working alongside her husband because sometimes she has to miss going to her stand to care for her daughter. Her greatest wish is to have a larger business but for the moment it is to continue working so that she can provide a better benefit for her daughter. This is her 6th loan with MFP and she pledges to be as punctual with her repayments as she was in the previous cycle. She will use the requested funds to buy mO. fish to earn mO. income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish.

loans.name: The Women´s Bank Progressing Together (Banco Mujer Avanzando Juntas) Group

texts.en:
This group’s name, "Banco Mujer Avanzando Juntas," translates as "The Women´s Bank Progressing Together". The eight women members of this group live in Shiroles, Limón, located in the hot and humid Caribbean region of Costa Rica. This will be the group’s first loan with Fundación Mujer. 

The members are engaged in various productive activities. For example, some members are involved in animal rearing. These women will use this loan to invest in the purchase of livestock such as piglets or chicks as well as nutrients to feed them. The rearing and selling of livestock necessitates the construction of a house for the animals. As a result, this loan will also be used to make general investments in the construction of pens for animals. The women who are involved in pig rearing will need at least three months before they can butcher and, in turn, sell their pork products. 

Other group members are involved in clothing and catalogue sales. These women plan to use this loan to purchase clothing, cosmetics, kitchen items and various other products, which they will sell to members of their community.  Clothing items to be purchased include pants, blouses and children´s clothing. 

Some of the women are engaged in the harvest of plantains. For these members, this loan will be used to invest in the purchase of small plantain plants which will be planted for harvest. Due to the abundant amount of wildlife in Caribbean Costa Rica, in order to ensure the quality of plantains, it is necessary to protect them. For this reason, this loan will also be used to purchase protective bags that will be placed over plantains throughout their journey to maturity. 

Ingrid M. A. is a 29-year-old mother who lives with her husband, daughter and nephew. Ingrid has a business selling perfumes: she collects orders in the Shiroles community and travels every 15 days to the closest big city (Limón) to make purchases.  This loan will be used by Ingrid to purchase perfumes that she will sell in her community. 

Ingrid’s main goals are to dedicate as much time as possible to selling perfumes and to provide financial support to her family. She hopes this loan will help her to increase her working capital and put her in a position to purchase more products for sale. She strives to be able to offer her family money when they need it. 

Ingrid says that the members of this group have lived in the same region for their whole lives; for this reason, the members know each other well. Additionally, many of the group members are related.  She says that she likes the group lending model because it allows the members to assist each other when necessary.

loans.use: For the purchase of perfumes to sell

loans.name: Feyisetun

texts.en: Feyisetun produces and sells bean flour. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with his customers. He hopes to expand his business to make it bigger and more secure.  He is 42 years old and married, with 5 children. His children are doing well at school and this makes him happy. He is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more beans to process into bean flour to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more beans to process into bean flour to sell

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkola, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Tiontala, sous préfecture de Massigui, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté et font le commerce de céréales et d’habits.
Ces femmes du groupe Benkola sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des céréales auprès des producteurs du  village  et environnants.  
Mariam Sidibé qui connaît le secteur du commerce de céréales dans lequel elle évolue depuis plusieurs années, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter,  trois sacs de 100kg des céréales. 
Elle s’approvisionne en céréales le plus généralement à Massigui et à Dioïla et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Massigui et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
All the women of the group Benkola are married and average 40 years of age and three children each. They live in traditional extended families in Tiontala, sub-prefecture of Massigui, Region of Koulikoro, in the 2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.  They know one another though ties of community and kinship, and they work in the commerce of grains and clothing.  The women in the group are on their third solidarity loan, which will be used for buying grains from producers in and around the village.  Mariam Sidibé, who is familiar with the business of grains in which she has been working for several years, intends to use her loan for buying three 100-kg sacks of grain.  She stocks up for the most part in Massigui and in Dioïla, and she sells retail, locally at the market. And she accepts cash and credit from a customer base composed of women and men. She plans on making an average monthly profit of 300,000 francs CFA that will be used for covering day-to-day family expenses, and the rest will be reinvested in business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying grains

loans.name: Agusta

texts.es: LA SRA. AGUSTA S. Y., TIENE 41 AÑOS DE EDAD ES UNA MUJER MUY LUCHADORA, TIENE 3 HIJOS MENORES DE EDAD, QUE DEPENDEN DE ELLA. ES PERSPICAZ AL DETECTAR LA NECESIDAD DE CRECER EN SU ACTIDAD, PROYECTANDO MEJORAS EN SU PUESTO DE VENTA PARA ASI CONSOLIDAR SUS INGRESOS, A TRAVES DE UN CREDITO QUE LE PERMITA OFRECER UN MEJOR SERVICIO A SU CLIENTELA, LO QUE LE ASEGURARIA A LA VEZ SU CONSOLIDACION Y FORTALECIMIENTO DE SU MEDIO DE VIDA, QUE SE VEERIA REFLEJADA EN UNA MEJOR EDUCACION Y EJEMPLO PARA SUS PEQUEÑOS HIJOS EN LO QUE SE REFIERE A LA LUCHA POR MEJORAR SU CALIDAD DE VIDA Y LA SUPERACION.
texts.en:
Augusta S. Y., 41, is a very tenacious woman. She has three minor children that are dependent on her. She was keenly aware that she needed to enlarge her business making improvements to her sales stall so that income would improve. She is asking for funds that will make it possible for her to offer better service to her customers which will lead to the consolidation and strengthening of her means of support. This, in turn, will be reflected in a better education and employment for her youngsters with respect to the struggle for improved quality of life and betterment.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To improve her sales stand.

loans.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr:
Madame Kadiatou  S. est âgée de 51 ans et mère de 6 enfants. Elle  vit dans une famille nucléaire avec son époux et ses enfants  à  Fana Coura un des quartiers la ville de Fana Région de Koulikoro République du Mali. 
Kadiatou, installée à son propre compte il y’à un bon moment, ne fait que s’épanouir davantage dans son activité, chose souhaitée par nous donateur (Soro Yiriwaso) dans son activité de restauration.
Réconforté par la situation de notre cliente, nous venons de constater du progrès dans son activité. Elle a correctement remboursé tous ses prêts précédents.  
Avec ce  nouveau prêt, elle compte acheter, deux sacs de 100kg de riz, des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration et le reste pour les ingrédients de jus, complémentaire à l’activité principale. 
Elle s’approvisionne sur place et vend ses plats alimentaires à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant, les passagers en partance à Bamako constituent l’essentiel de sa clientèle.  
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 40.000FCFA par  mois  qu’elle utilisera pour les dépenses de la famille et de son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadiatou S. is 51 years old and mother to six children. She lives in a nuclear family with her husband and children in Fana Coura, one of the districts of the town of Fana, in the region of Koulikoro in the Republic of Mali. Kadiatou has been working for her own account for quite a while and is blossoming in her restauration business, which is what we, her lender (Soro Yiriwaso), want. Comforted by our customer's situation we can see the progress she has made in her business. She has repaid all her previous loans without incident. With this new loan, she is planning on buying two 100kg sacks of rice and condiments for resauration; with the balance she will buy ingredients for juice, which is complementary to her main business. She gets her supplies locally and sells her dishes to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash. Passers-by leaving Bamako constitute the bulk of her customers. She is expecting to make a profit of 40,000FCFA a month which she will use for family expenses and her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for restauration business

loans.name: Modibo

texts.fr:
Monsieur Modibo Traoré est âgée de 33 ans, père de 3enfants et vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec son époux et ses enfants  dans le quartier Fana coura, sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.
Pour des raisons purement économiques, Modibo s’adonna au commerce il y’à environ cinq ans de cela.
Après avoir correctement remboursé les prêts précédents, il vient de renouveler sa demande pour un nouveau prêt. 
Il compte acheter deux sacs de 50kg de sucre, trois cartons de thé, cinq paquets de savon, un bidon de 20litres d’huile alimentaire, des paquets de bonbon et des boîtes de conserves alimentaires.
Il s’approvisionne le plus généralement à Bamako presque chaque deux semaines en gros avec les grossistes du grand marché. Il vient revendre dans sa boutique en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice d’environ 30 000FCFA par mois avec lequel il va faire face à ses dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
Mr. Modibo Traoré, age 33, is the father of three children and lives in a traditional family with his wife and children in the Fana Coura district, sub-prefecture of Fana, Region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.  For purely economic reasons, he has been devoting all his time to commerce for the past five years.  After having correctly repaid the preceding loans, he just renewed his request for a new one.  He intends to buy two 50-kg sacks of sugar, three boxes of tea, five packets of soap, a 20-liter container of vegetable oil, packages of candy, and some canned foods.  He stocks up on bulk goods from wholesalers at the big market, for the most part in Bamako, almost every two weeks.  He then sells the goods retail in his store, accepting cash and credit from a customer base composed of women and men.  He hopes to make profit of about 30,000 francs CFA per month that will be used for addressing day-to-day expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying store merchandise

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Madame Salimata Kamaté est âgée de 44 ans et mère de 6 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec son époux et ses enfants  à  Fana Coura un des quartiers la ville de Fana Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.
Salimata fait diverses activités telles l’habillement, la préparation et vente de jus de boissons etc.
Afin d’avoir des ressources financières complémentaires pour supporter la concurrence de plus en plus rude, elle décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elle a correctement remboursé tous ses prêts précédents et compte utiliser ce nouveau pour  se constituer un important stock d’ingrédients (sucre, gingembre, des arômes etc.) pour la fabrication de jus.
Elle s’approvisionne en matière premières au niveau de la ville de Fana.
Les jus sont vendus  sur place et en ambulant en espèce et à crédit avec une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle estime avoir un bénéfice prévisionnel de 100 000FCFA qui servira de soutenir les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
Ms. Salimata Kamaté, aged 44, is the mother of six children.  She lives in a monogamous family with her husband and children in Fana Coura, a district in Fana City, Region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.  Salimata has diverse businesses, such as clothing, making and selling juice beverages, etc.  In order to have supplemental financial resources for addressing the tougher and tougher competition, she decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  She has properly repaid all her previous loans and intends to use this new loan for building up a significant stock of ingredients (sugar, ginger, flavorings, etc.) for making juices.  She stocks up on basic supplies in Fana City.  The juices are sold locally door-to-door.  Cash and credit are accepted from a customer base composed of women and men.  She thinks she'll have a projected profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used to cover day-to-day expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying ingredients for making juices

loans.name: Wroto For Business Group

texts.en:
Martha T. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Wroto For Business. She is 48 years old and is a widow with six children who range from 12 to 30 years old. Martha could not continue her own education through high school due to family problems.

For fifteen years Martha has been selling provisions at the Airfield Wroto Town community in Sinkor, Monrovia, Liberia. She started her business with 4,000 Liberian dollars as working capital but now has about 30,000 Liberian dollars. She sells in an open area during the dry season in order to keep customers returning.

Martha’s goal and dream is to improve her business and build houses. She plan to use her 16,250 Liberia dollar portion of this 68,500 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase some charcoal and more provisions to improve her business.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Martha is holding the sign.

loans.use: To purchase some charcoal and more provisions for her store

loans.name: Ololade

texts.en: Ololade is 47 years old, married, and has four children. She sells building blocks in Ibadan, Oyo State, and has been in this business for a long time. She loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction with her customers. Ololade hopes to own a block industry in the future. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more materials to mold more building blocks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to mold more building blocks to sell

loans.name: God With Us Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the “God With Us” group. They are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in order to further strengthen their businesses.

The leader of the group is thirty-five-year-old Daniel G. (pictured second from right). Born in Kono, eastern Sierra Leone, Daniel is single with no children. He sells bread and has been in the bread business for a year now. With his share of the loan, he will buy working materials like a bag of flour, sugar, yeast, and a table.

loans.use: To buy working materials like a bag of flour, sugar, yeast, and a table

loans.name: Tawopanneh Group

texts.en:
This group is named Tawopanneh, a Temne phrase meaning: “Let us hold ourselves together”. The members are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 each in order to further strengthen their businesses.

The leader of the group is forty-two-year-old John K., pictured in the middle in the group photo. Born in Lunsar, a small town in northern Sierra Leone, John is married to a businesswoman and they have three children. John sells used-clothes and has been running this business for two years now. With his share of the loan, he will buy a bale of used-clothes to add to his current stock.

loans.use: To buy a bale of used-clothes to add to his stock

loans.name: God In Woke Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of “God In Woke” group from the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each in order to expand their businesses. In this way, they can make more sales, better profits and consequently improve on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Fatmata K. who is pictured on the left. Born in Makeni, the forty-eight-year-old is married and has six children. Fatmata sells locally-dyed cloth (gara lappers) and has been in this business for many years now. With this loan, Fatmata will expand her business: she will buy working materials like cotton, inks, caustic soda, powder, rubber bowls, gloves, etc.

loans.use: To buy working materials like cotton, inks, caustic soda, powder, rubber bowls, gloves, etc.

loans.name: Sorry For We Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Sorry For We” group from the city of Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 800,000 each in order to expand their businesses. In this way they can make more sales and better profits, consequently improving on their standard of living.

The leader of this group is Marie C.. Born in Makeni, the thirty-one-year-old is married and has three children – two in primary school and the other not of school-going age.

For five years now, Marie has been selling rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), fish, onions, Margi (used to give sauces a sweet taste), etc. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by buying more rice, palm-oil, pepper, onions, etc., wholesale to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, palm-oil, pepper, onions, etc., wholesale

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou Touré est âgée de 43 ans, père de 5 d’enfants et vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec ses épouses et ses enfants dans le hameau de Fantobougou, sous préfecture de Fana, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.
  Cultivateur de son état, Monsieur Touré fait également le commerce de céréales depuis maintenant plus de 5 ans. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, il  décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son  troisième prêt, les précédents ayant été correctement remboursés.
 Avec ce nouveau prêt, il compte acheter quatre tonnes de céréales.
Il s’approvisionne en céréales auprès des petits détaillants au niveau de sa résidence et  dans les villages environnants et la vente s’effectue au marché de Fana le plus généralement en gros à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, il estime réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 200.000FCFA au cours du cycle qui sera utilisé pour couvrir des dépenses liées à la scolarisation de ses enfants et à l’activité elle-même.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou Touré, aged 43, is the father of five children and lives in a traditional family with his wives and children in the hamlet of Fantobougou, sub-prefecture of Fana, prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.  As a farmer, he has also been doing commerce in grains for over five years. Concerned about satisfying his customers further, he decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his third loan.  The previous ones have all been properly repaid.  With this new loan, he intends to buy four tonnes of grain.  He stocks up from small retailers where he lives and in surrounding villages.  He sells at the Fana market, for the most part wholesale, to a customer base composed of women and men.  With this loan, he thinks he will make an average profit of 200,000 francs CFA over the course of the cycle.  The profits will be used to cover expenses associated with schooling his children and with the business itself.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying grains

loans.name: Elva

texts.es: la Sra. Elva llego a nuestra oficina con la intencion de solicitar un  prestamo en grupo, pero al final se desanimaron y sacaron con otra persona y se garantizaron ambas, Doña Elva vive en el Barrio los claveles de la zona de la Pampa de la Isla en donde tiene su casita propia en la que vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, cuenta con una tiendita de barrio en su mimso domcilio y por las noches vende cena (comida), con su tiendita viene trabajando desde hace 3 años y la venta de comida desde hace 1 año, el dinero solicitado sera para aumentar su capital en la venta de comidas, ya que tiene mucha demanda, su objetivo es llegar a colocar en su mismo domicilio una pension para lo cual le falta la infraestructura, una parte del dinero tambien sera invertido en aquello en la compra de material de construccion. "agradezco a la institucion por haber confiado en mi persona argumentala Sra. Elva.
texts.en:
Elva approached our office with the intention of asking for a group loan. However, in the end they were discouraged and decided instead for a joint loan with just one other person; they act as each other’s guarantor. Elva lives in the Los Claveles neighborhood in Pampa de la Isla zone; she owns her own house where she lives with her husband and four school age children. She has a small neighborhood grocery store in her home and has sold prepared food in the evenings for about a year; she has had her store for about 3 years. The requested funds will be used to increase her food sales because demand is high. Her goal is to set up a small eatery in her home but she lacks infrastructure. Part of the money will be used to buy building materials and supplies. Elva states: “I am grateful to the institution for trusting me.”

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For building materials and supplies.

loans.name: C 3540 Dushyigikirane Group

texts.en:
Pauline is a lady of 38 years who is commonly known in the business of sewing various styles of clothes. She desired to work in a group and she is now the president of a group called “Dushyigikirane”. This is their third successful year in this business and the business hours are from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day.

Although Pauline and her team have been in this business for about three years, their earned profit is still too low to expand meaningfully and they believe that a small amount of additional capital would bring a positive change.  For that reason, Pauline and her team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase some additional sewing machines as well as clothing items which, in turn, will make them more efficient, effective and more successful.

loans.use: To purchase additional sewing machines and clothing items

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en:
Kehinde is 40 years old, married, and has two children who are doing well in school. To earn a living, she sells underwear and babywear in Lagos. She has been in this business for four years and is doing well. She is a very energetic and determined woman who is engaged in the struggle to pull her family out of poverty by increasing her family's financial stability.
Kehinde has been a good client of Kiva partner, LAPO, for some years. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more underwear and babywear to sell. She expresses her gratitude to all Kiva lenders for their financial empowerment.

loans.use: To purchase more underwear and babywear to sell

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es: Raquel tiene 33 años, ella vive con su esposo Agapito de 29 y sus hijos Haysa de 13 años y Claudio de 7 años. Juntos viven en su casa propia. Hace más de un año y medio se dedica a vender zapatos, es entonces que Raquel viaja cada quince días a la ciudad de Chiclayo,  al norte del país, ciudad muy conocida por la buena fabricación de artículos y ropa de cuero. De esa manera se abastece de la mercadería necesaria, en este caso de zapatos, para luego ser vendidos a un mayor precio en el lugar donde vive. Es así que puedo cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes que previamente le hacen el pedido y pasado un tiempo empieza con la cobranza, siendo el pago en dos cuotas. Su mayor anhelo es tener una tienda dentro del mercado más concurrido de su ciudad. Por ahora solo se dedicará a su trabajo, que le brinda la independencia que necesita y al mismo tiempo cuidar de sus hijos. Este es su primer crédito con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual con todos los pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, invertirá en el viaje a Chiclayo y abastecerse de zapatos, de acuerdo al pedido del cliente.
texts.en:
Raquel is 33 years old. She lives with her husband, Agapito, who is 29, and their two children, Haysa, 13, and Claudio, 7. They live together in their own house. Raquel has been selling shoes for more than a year and a half. Thus she travels every fifteen days to the city of Chiclayo, in the north of the country, a city that is well known for its good manufacture of leather clothing and other leather articles. In this way she supplies the necessary merchandise, in this case shoes, to be sold later at a better price in the place where she lives. This is how she is able to fill the requests of her customers who previously placed orders with her, and then she begins collecting the payments, which are made in two parts. Her greatest dream is to have a shop in the busiest market in the city. For the time being, she will dedicate herself to her work, which offers her the independence that she needs, and at the same time to the care of her children. This is her first loan with MFP, and she promises to be very punctual with all the payments. She will invest the loan that she is applying for in trips to Chiclayo and in supplying shoes according to the customer's order.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes to fill the requests of customers

loans.name: Ngoyangi Group

texts.en:
Korpo B. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Ngoyangi. She is 45 years old, single, and has two children aged 22 and 26. She also cares for other relatives living with her. Korpo did not have the opportunity to go to school.
For the last five years, Korpo has been selling charcoal at the Oldest Congo Town in Paynesville, Liberia. She started her business with 10,000 LRD as working capital but now has more than 20,000 LRD as working capital. She has a good stock in order to encourage customers to continue returning. Korpo sometimes faces problems with transporting goods from one place to another. Her goal and dream is to build a house in the near future. She plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to purchase more charcoal to improve her business.
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Korpo is holding the sign. Richard is inset lower right.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal

loans.name: Sidonie

texts.fr: Née en 1984 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, K. Sidonie est mariée à AGBOKI Janvier, un menuisier. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés.
